REVIEW: May 13 2009 	Great hotel the Waldorf	I travelled to NYC with my daughter last week. We had organised to stay at a private club for the 1st 4 nights. We were delighted with the accommodation there, it was 1st class, however they were full for our last night and I had to find somewhere equally as nice, and decided on the Waldorf.Well! What a lovely experience! We were SO sorry we had not spent the week there!!! The room was large and the beds so comfortable. The buzz of the reception, lobby & bar area was electric. I did find the bar and restaurant expensive: but there is a Starbucks on the premises and so many restaurants nearby....u are never stuck for somewhere to eat in NYC!!Our ONLY problem was, that the fire alarm went off at 2am !! It was a false alarm...so could have been worse.New York is such good value, I look forward to my next trip. I will be staying at the Waldorf for the full duration of my trip!Cant wait!

May 12 2009 	Old fashioned hotel good location	We chose Waldorf-Astoria because the incredible offer on their site (pay in advance, no change of dates, no refund, a room for around 230USD). As we could not find anything better at this rate we thought that trying such a world famous hotel would be fun. In fact the hotel is nothing special, I would say it is fairly average. The rooms are clean but a bit run down, you can see that they have not been redecorated or renovated in decades. The TV is at least 15 years old. We stayed on the 10th and had absolutely no view, only the offices in front of us...I would have been a bit dissapointed had I paid the normal rate......When we arrived nobody offered any help with the luggage and I was a bit surprised to see the internet service for almost 5USD per minute (we came from Central America on our way back to Europe and had no laptop). I was a bit shocked that this was the world famous Waldorf, but with the price I paid it was worth it. I would definitely not pay the normal rate as it would be far too much for this service and quality. I personally prefer smaller, friendlier places and Waldorf-Astoria is definitely none of the above.

May 11 2009	A little underwhelming!	Treated my Mum to a two night stay at the Waldorf Astoria over Christmas 2008. I unfortunately expected a lot more from this hotel, and was a little disappointed with the stay.Check-in was incredibly slow and ended up leaving bags with the bell captain and walked around Manhattan to kill time until our room was ready. Ended up with room 1455 which had fairly average furnishings. The curtains needed a good clean, the surfaces were all a bit grotty and the telephone hadn't ever been cleaned! The bathroom was pretty average but they did provide nice toiletries. The room did have two very comfortable double beds with lovely soft pillows, sheets and gorgeous feather quilts. Had a wonderful porter who was extremely friendly and very knowledgeable. Most of the staff we came across were very helpful. No wireless internet access in rooms. To use the business centre downstairs it was a fee of $4.99 to log on, then 80c per minute thereafter. I did get random wi-fi behind the lobby by the public telephones but it dropped out frequently. My advice is to find an internet cafe!Don't drink at Starbucks inside the Waldorf at the 5th Avenue entrance. It's way more expensive than every other Starbucks. After eight previous stays in NYC, I'd prefer to be over on the 8th or 9th Avenue side of Times Square for proximity to cheap and cheery restaurants and bars. 5th Avenue was a little short of eateries at night, but did find a nice little Italian place called San Martin on 49th between Lex and Park. Great food and service was fabulous. I'm sure the East Side has great places to eat, but given the weather on Christmas Eve, we didn't venture too far away. Would I stay there again - No. I think it's overpriced and over-rated. For that kind of money, I'd try the W Hotel or spend the extra money on Broadway shows!

May 9 2009 	Excellent service though comes at a price	We held our annual conference at the Waldorf in June 2008. The whole atmosphere in and around the hotel makes you feel nostalgic... as if you had stepped into a movie from the 1940s. Highly recommended... though comes at a steep price if you are purely a room guest. We have compared a lot of plush NY hotels and frankly, the cost differential isn't too much.Let's get down to the basics:-Accomodation:- Most rooms are slightly larger than standard hotel rooms that you would find. Though I must mention, that we had a few rooms that extremely large and had enough space to fit in cars.Location:- Right in the heart if midtown Manhattan. Conveniently located for sight seeing as well as business meetings. Taxis, subways, buses... you name... right at the doorstep of this hotel.Service:- The service levels have been immaculate, especially considering that we were hosting a conference with over 200 people participating. The hotel staff is dedicated enough to ensure that your needs are met ontime, everytime.Food:- We had requested special Indian dishes for lunch and dinner... and honestly, the Paneer Makhanwala and Maa-ki-daal were as good as you would find in most Indian restaurants. Otherwise, haveing lunch or dinner in their restaurants can turn out to be a very pricey affair.Cheers....

May 9 2009 	Very Disappointing	I stayed at the Waldorf for two night on business. I was quite excited because of its history and name, but came away disappointed. I stayed on the 6th floor, the room was small, view of a brick wall, dated furniture and no wireless internet. I ordered room service for room service, 2 eggs/coffee and juice and it was $53. For the price, there are a ton better options and I'll never stay there again.

May 5 2009 	Traditional Glamour and Charm	We were 'upgraded' to this hotel by our travel agents, so found ourselves based here for a two-night stay by happy accident. Our room was allocated to us on arrival at 10.30am and we were delighted to discover it was a very spacious twin room decorated traditionally (lots of florals going on!). The bathroom was somewhat dated but was perfectly adequate for a short stay with good supply of towels and toiletries.We found the bars and restaurants in the hotel to be almost prohibitively expensive, but this is probably due to the weak Sterling when we visited. That said, we had a couple of drinks in the bar near the lobby - everyone just seemed to be having the most lovely time in there and we didn't want to miss out! The hotel is well located for first time visitors to New York who want to do all the sights - we were able to walk to most landmarks, although there were always plenty of taxis to be had nearby if needed. It's always a comforting feeling in a big city to pop back to the hotel to drop off shopping/freshen up before heading back out - and the Waldorf was located centrally so as to allow us to do this. Overall, this hotel is the very meaning of 'faded glamour'. Whilst I'm glad we experienced the charm of the Waldorf I would probably pick a more contemporary hotel for future visits to New York.

Apr 27 2009 	Great First Time Stay at the Waldorf	My husband and I celebrated our anniversary at the Waldorf in April 2009. We stayed for an extended weekend and we had the time of our lives. Upon checking in, we asked for an upgrade and were given a minisuite on the 42nd (top) floor. We found out this suite also doubles as a second bedroom for the Royal Suite, which used to be the part-time home to the Duke and Duchess of Windsor. The room was absolutely beautiful and had windows that faced 50th Street and you could also see Park Avenue. There was a small foyer, that included a wetbar and refrigerator. Then the bedroom/living area, which had the most comfortable king bed I've ever slept in, along with a desk and chair, couch, armchair, coffee table, end tables and entertainment center with TV. To the right of the bedroom was a small changing area with a closet where the safe was kept along with luggage racks, iron and ironing board. Through the dressing area was the bathroom, which had a tub and separate shower area. We could not have asked for better service. The hotel was convenient to everything and there were a couple subway stations within a block or two. We would definitely love to return to the Waldorf someday, but there are so many other cities/countries we want to see first.

Apr 27 2009 	Average	This is a large, impersonal, busy hotel. We had a one bedroomed suite which was spacious enough for a family of four. The bedroom and lounge were in good condition, comfortable and clean but felt cold and dark even on the sunniest of days. The bathroom was old and very dated. We heard no traffic noise. Drinks and food were expensive.I found the location of Sunday brunch in the main foyer next to the check in desks to be rather odd.I was surprised at the lack of security at this hotel, as anyone could just wander in.The hotel is ideally located and within easy walking distance of many attractions.

Apr 26 2009 	A perfect stay.	From arrival to departure everything was superb. The room was clean and spacious and the staff were just wonderful throughout.There is a guided tour of the hotel, which was actually a really great experience. We learned a lot about the history of the hotel and got to see parts of the hotel you would not normally see as a guest, including the kitchen. I would happily recommend it and I would happily stay again.

Apr 25 2009 	Honeslty?.....I stayed for the name!	The Waldorf is extremely elegant, and as the famous hotel it is i certainly wasn't disappointed. The rooms were not huge but immaculate, and I loved the bathroom, really bright with loads of mirrors! The bed was fabulous (mind you, its so exhausting sighseeing you would sleep on a washing line!) However in New York you spend very little time in your room anyway! It has to be said the people watching in the Waldorf was fabulous full of tux's and ball gowns and me in my Ugg boots! I have to be fair I only stayed in the hotel because of it history but it really did make my trip to New York special!

Apr 24 2009 	Not worth the moneyyou are only paying for the name.	Thought I would celebrate my 50th birthday with three friends.The holiday wasnt cheap,we saved for a year.We had requested adjoining rooms,didnt get them and later told there was no adjoining rooms anyway.Rooms we basic and cold.Heating didnt work and it had been snowing when we were there.Grafitti scraped on bedside cabinet,shower/bath knob was missing,electric sockets not working.Best of all my friends felt very let down that the hotel hadnt even left a card as the knew I was celebrating my 50th[I didnt mind] so they complained and when we got back in on the first evening there was a bottle of cava and a box of four chocolates left in my room.Only thing was they took the money from my friends credit card for them.They did not reply to my letter nor my emails.I would stay clear of this hotel.

Apr 21 2009 	A Fantastic Hotel Experience!	I too read the not-so-flattering reportst about the Waldorf-Astoria before I left. I did not get the chance to choose a hotel because we were part of a group. I was pleasantly surprised by my WA experience! The service is second to none. They took care of anything we asked for. One night, I needed to ice my foot. Within minutes after asking, I had an ice bag at the door. The decor was upscale and very elegant. The hotel room was large and spacious. The only part of the hotel that showed any age was the bathroom plumbing. I was ok with that though. We had the opportunity to have dinner in the Bear and Bull. Quite expensive, but very nice. A drink in the lobby was about twice what it would have been anywhere else. The food at our two group breakfasts was super, and a perfect way to start the day. Would I stay here again...probably not since it's a "been there, done that" kind of thing. I do prefer the Crown Plaza on Time Square to this hotel. Would I recommend this hotel? Absolutely! It's a great place to experience atleast once.On a side note...we noticed what we thought were hookers in the lobby very late one evening. Not sure if this is something you see in other NY hotels but the were there to "see" someone. I'm not sure if they were allowed upstairs or not. (GROSS)

Apr 21 2009 	Nice Place....middle of road for NYC.	Wife and I stayed at the WA for a long weekend with friends. Location is central in Midtown which makes it easy to get around. The WA's famous name makes it sound more appealing than it really is. I am not going to rip on the hotel because it is nice but lets face it...It is an old place....and you can sort of tell it. I think the management has done a great job with what they have but the WA is aging and it is easy to tell in some spots. The hotel apparently does not have AC and heat...they only have one or the other. the temp was 80 degrees in NYC but the AC in the hotel had not been switched on. Our room was not uncomfortable but our friends did complain. they were told to open a window and they provided them with a small oscillating fan. It was funny to see this cheap little wal mart fan blowing around a room in the WA. Our room was small but it was well appointed. the bath towels were top notch and the bed was very nice. the 42 inch flat screen was cool too. check in service was polite and the concierge was very helpful. Bartenders were cool and recommended great restaurants. The WA is nice and everyone is as nice as they could be but honestly the place was a little disappointing. Overall, I think the problem that I, and all of our friends, had with WA is that the hotel itself does not live up to its big name. when you say WA you think of timeless elegance and oppulent accomodations. Not bashing the WA but we are just used to something a little nicer and i think most seasoned travelers would be on the same page.

Apr 21 2009 	Beautiful Hotel good service challenged experience.	The Waldorf is a beautiful Hotel with comfortable beds and a helpful staff. Its location is perfect, near the liveliest spots but far enough to allow for a good nights rest. Now for the not so great, our non-smoking room was a smoking room with an air-ionizer placed in it. The hotel double charged our account for our stay, only after placing a hold for 100 dollars a day over the initial quote for the possibility of "incidentals" (ie. minibar, internet use etc). This brought the on hold amount from our bank account to 240% of the initial quote. In the staffs defense, after being told by the desk attendant I was wrong and the charges were correct, the manager called and corrected their mistake, 24hrs later it was corrected, both on paper and in my bank account. The television remote never worked, but we were so tired from running at city speed we didn't have time to notice. The rooms were clean and comfortable. The staff, attentive and courteous, with the exception of the desk clerk,were always professional. I had high expectations for this hotel, but found myself disappointed when I had to correct another billing issue at check out, this time an incorrect charge for the minibar, of course in the hotels favor. Everything here is specifically designed to seperate you from your hard-worked for dollars. Enjoy your stay here, but double check all billing, and be prepared to direct attention to poorly handled billing procedures. Don't be too nice to make a stand, you will be taken advantage of.

Apr 18 2009 	Convenient Luxury	Elegant art deco lobby. Beautiful entrance - especially from Park Ave. We had the corner room on the 12th floor and it was lovely.Only complaint is that it is a huge hotel. (you don't get that "personal service" feel like from small boutique hotels - there is a long line at the check-in, long wait on the phone, etc.)Great location - centrally located.LOVED telling the cabbie - "Take me to the Waldorf!"

Apr 17 2009 	Great stay in NYC	My wife and I booked at the Waldorf for a romantic getaway this month and were pleasantly surprised at the accommodations. We booked the romantic package(champagne & breakfast in bed). and were pleased to be upgraded to a tower one bedroom suite, above and beyond the package suite. The restaurants are a bit pricey, we at Qdoba across the street for dinner one night. Had lunch at the Peacock restaurant in the hotel and would say that it is fair, although the fact that it is off the lobby and the people watching was great. When booking in NYC I recommend considering the Waldorf simply based on value. I am looking at booking another trip to NYC and the Waldorf is only about $40 more than the Hampton Inn, so for the extra money I will stay at the Waldorf based on it's status and proximity to local attractions.

Apr 16 2009 	After not expecting much I was pleasantly suprised once there!	After reading the reviews on this I traveled to New York not expecting much from the hotel. Well I must say I was wrong. The hotel is in a fantastic location and I would say that if you were to use all the facilities, which I did not, then it would be worth the money. The rooms were very clean and the staff more than happy to help.Despite the fact my first room was on the small side after requesting a larger room I was given a corner room which proved to be larger, although some bathroom space was compromised. Not to big a problem as that is an area I do not tend to spend much time in.The location was excellent. A 4,5,6 subway round the corner, a ten minute walk to Grand Central and about the same to Times Square. All in all I would recommended you stay here if you get a relatively good deal.

Apr 14 2009 	Great location enjoyable stay	We were really apprehensive with all the previous negative reports, but we have to say we had a great time. When we first arrived, the room we were given was not big enough for my wife and two sons. We enquired with John, the very helpful check in clerk, who moved us the next day to a large corner room.We were on floor 12, which is barely half way up the main hotel building on the front (Park Avenue) corner and we heard almost no noise from passing traffic. You hear the odd car horn but what else would you expect in one of the busiest Cities in the world.We did not eat in the Hotel as we found it very expensive and not suitable for children. The hotel lobby and reception are however stunning and the staff are all very helpful and accommodating. We will return to this hotel on our next trip to NY and our experience does not reflect some of the other entries on Trip Advisor.

Apr 9 2009 	Lovely Hotel	We spent 4 days at the Waldorf Astoria to celebrate my 60th Birthday, we didn't eat in the Hotel as we were out from morning till night sight seeing. On the morning of my birthday I was going to have a lovely bubble bath and champagne, only to find there was no water, we couldn't even have a wash. Disappointing to say the least, we were told that no rooms had any water and that it did eventually come on , but unfortunately we had left to go shopping by then.

Apr 9 2009 	Great historic hotel with modern amenities	This hotel is a gem. The room was a typical size for NYC, the bathroom was really nice, and the bed/linens were comfortable. The decor was impeccable, and the service was great. We would recommend this hotel to anyone.

Apr 7 2009 	OMG the perfect hotel perfect room and perfect staff!!!	My husband and I went to New York for our wedding anniversary and chose the Waldorf because of it's name and also we were offered a pretty good rate. We stayed on the concierge floor (actually 2 flights up on 28) because continental breakfast was included, and we might get a better view up higher. It was the best decision ever! Our room was BEAUTIFUL, with a loungeroom, walk-in-robe, king size bed, fireplace, and although the view wasn't spectacular, it was decent. We just loved going down to the 26th floor for breakfast. Seeing the gorgeous fresh food laid out on proper silver ware and greeted with a smile and kind words each morning was fabulous. Breakfast included cereals, fresh fruit salad, yogurts, smoked salmon, bagels, a selection of breads, freshly brewed tea and coffees, all of which could be taken away and eaten in your room if you wanted. The hotel itself was amazing. Now, we would probably only stay in a hotel maybe two or three times a year, so are not experts or anything, but we know when we are enjoying something and we DEFINITELY enjoyed the Waldorf Astoria. We ate i the famous Bull and Bear restaurant (I enjoyed my surf and turf, the hubby HATED his oven roasted rib), drank in Sir Harry's bar ($9 beer, $12 vodka & coke, $22 cosmopolitan + tips), and walked EVERYWHERE (20mins in heels to times sq!). We even arrived to our room one night to find a bottle of champagne and choc dipped strawberries awaiting us. No, we definitely can't speak high enough of the Waldorf Astoria, LOVED IT!!!!!!!!!!

Apr 4 2009 	Unexpected luxury	The hotel overlooking needs refurbishing, the windows and corridors as well. The hotel located in an excellent place. It is very huge you can loose yourself easly. We didn't get the reserved room, but they offered free breakfast for us. A strange noise from the street had heard. The quality of the service was excellent and stay as well. We've been there only one night. I told the problem for the receptionist at check-out, she wrote it up, I hope they can do something.

Mar 31 2009 	Beautiful stay at a historic hotel.	We chose the Waldorf Astoria for a two-night stay before a Caribbean cruise on the Queen Mary 2. We wanted to combine this modern cruising icon with the historic landmark of NY that the Waldorf is.The hotel is impressive and has this kind of old elegance, charm and finesse that it is difficult to find in modern hotels. It is well maintained, even if some places look tired. We particularly liked the rich wood hues in various walls and the balanced combination of spaciousness and restricted classical atmosphere in many public spaces. Our room was tastefully decorated, giving you a sense of intimacy, warmth and harmony.Service was very good and the staff was helpful and friendly. Actually we experienced this as soon as we arrived, when a kind young employee at the front desk (we remember him with gratitude) upgraded us to a beautiful junior suite at the 17th floor.We had dinner at the historic Bull and Bear Restaurant of the hotel, whose decor and ambience we enjoyed. The restaurant promotes itself for its awarded beefsteaks, and we found our own to be true to the advertisement.The location of the hotel is magnificent, at the centre of action of New York City. Everything was near, and when we needed to do some shopping all we had to do was to walk a bit, simultaneously enjoying the atmosphere of the city. Right outside of the hotel we also found the two-decker buses that we extensively used to explore the city. Overall it was a most memorable stay. Decor, room, service, staff, location were great. We would return to the Waldorf Astoria in a heartbeat.

Mar 30 2009 	Beautiful hotel but rooms disappointing	I have just returned from this hotel and overall the hotel was stunning inside but our deluxe room was dreadfull, it was small and with no heating working outside i could of been staying anywhere in the world as all i could see was 3 brick wall and a generater !!! I imediately complained and was told that there were no other rooms available which was an absolute joke eventually after sleeping in our robes we were moved the next day to a slightly better room. The location is great and we have Brad and Angelina staying there but some how think there room would be a bit nicer than ours!!!

Mar 28 2009 	You have to go to Chamber Magic Show	Even though I have lived on the east coast all my life, I have never visited NYC. We bought tickets to Steve Cohen's Chamber Magic Show after seeing him on CBS Sunday Morning. The show takes place in the Waldorf Towers, so we decided to treat ourselves and spend the weekend at the Waldorf. The show was absolutely amazing! Mr. Cohen provides an up close personal magical experience. The Waldorf provides the luxury that is expected from such a posh hotel We were able to visit most of Manhattan and then return to our comfortable room to relax. It was a weekend treat that was well worth the experience. It wasnt budget friendly but it was certainly worth the cost.

Mar 27 2009 	great location - threadbare rooms - grand dame is ready for an overahaul	The Waldorf is ideally located - easy access to everything. The staff is incredibly helpful (great concierge!) - but the room we had was pitiful, way overdue for an update. Paper thin walls - with a neighbor who slammed the door at least a dozen times a night between midnight and 2am - the lingering smell of smoke (nasty!) - no glazing on the windows so even on the 19th floor you felt like you were in the midst of mid-town traffic. All the more annoying since I had called the hotel and specifically requested a renovated room (to avoid all of the above). Management was not particularly helpful when I pointed out on my confirmation that I had made the request, their answer was to give my daughter a stuffed bear. A lovely gesture - but a quieter room without the acrid smell of smoke would have been better. My husband is a fan of the Peninsula - I fully understand why. If you want a reasonably priced room and are willing to take your chances with a room which may (or may not!!) be renovated then the Waldorf is just fine. But in a city with so many great hotels - I'd try elsewhere the next time.

Mar 24 2009 	Peacock Alley Fiasco	Our family were in New York for a birthday celebration, as a thank you I booked Sunday lunch in Peacock Alley for 12.30pm. Booking was made by telephone from Ireland, the receptionist gave his name (I will not embarrass him). When we arrived, despite the fact that there were innumerable empty tables we were told that there was no record of our reservation but a table would be found if we cared to wait. We waited and were ignored for 20 minutes, then gave out and went looking for an alternative, a wasted morning and a big disappointment as I had previously eaten there and was anxious to share the experience with my family.

Mar 22 2009 	Fabulous Stay at the Legendary Waldorf=Astoria	This was the second time my 9 year old daughter and I stayed at the Waldorf=Astoria. It is our yearly "Girls Weekend in NYC". The lobby is beautiful...Art Deco all around. Don't forget to look up at the ceiling and check out the golden clock by reception. If you go to the website you can also download an I-Pod walking tour of the hotel. Fabulous!We arrived early. Although our room was not yet ready, we were able to check in and have our luggage stored until we came back from a Times Square sight seeing walk and some lunch. After our return, we picked up our key and our luggage was taken to our room. We had a corner king (room 1113) on the eleventh floor. Note: After 6:00 pm you need to use your card in the elevator to go to your room. Our room was recently renovated. I had asked for a renovated room because the room we had last year, although very nice and large, was in need of sprucing up. This year, our room had tones of Gold with red, green and beige. The accents were dark wood and brass with beautiful fabric wall paper. There was plenty of closet space. The room included a long desk, comfy large upholstered chair, marble bath with tub/shower and plenty of towels, Lg. Phillips flat screen TV, I-Pod dock/radio/alarm clock with presets, 2 phones, and a comfy king bed with enough pillows for both of us ...I'm a pillow person. The bath had very nice amenities including cotton balls and tips, glycerine soap, lotion, shampoo, conditioner. There were heavy drapes at the window with both sheers and pull shades.The views from our two windows were fabulous. There was a great view through the far window of St. Bartholomews church and it's dome, as well as, down Park Avenue. The view from the front window was slightly obscured by the building but Park Avenue was still visible.The only thing I can say that isn't complementary is that our room had uneven floor boards under the carpet on one side of the bed. That's it. And truly, hardly worth mentioning. Nothing more than that. Everything else was great.In the morning, my daughter and I ordered up a small pot of coffee and small pot of hot chocolate. This is where you either like room service or not. I knew what the total cost would be before I ordered. But for those of you who may find this excessive I will explain. Each pot is $8.00...not too bad for a 3 cup pot in NYC. However, there is a $5.25 surcharge per person for your order. There were two of us, so, our coffee and chocolate came to $26.50 plus the $2 tip. If this is too much for you, there is a Starbucks downstairs at street level by the Park Avenue entrance (revolving doors) to your left, before you go up the stairs to the Terrace lobby. Or, you can take coffee downstairs in Peacock Alley or at the Terrace. Overall, everyone we interacted with at the Waldorf, from the doorman to the concierge to the reception desk to the waiter who brought up our beverages in the morning was very professional, courteous and helpful. They made my daughter feel as if she were a princess in a castle. The location can't be beat. This hotel is located on the East side of Midtown Manhattan. Close to Radio City, MOMA, Rockefeller Center, Top of the Rock, American Girl Place, Build a Bear and within a 10 minute walk of the Empire State Building and Times Square. A thirty minute walk will take you down to the Central Park Zoo. A little less time will take you to the park's playground, horse/carriage rides and FAO Schwartz (my daughter loved the floor piano -- think Tom Hanks in BIG). There are so many things to do at the park. On the East Side of the park, a little further down from the Zoo, is the petting zoo and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. On the West Side of the park (you will need to take a cab or walk for a bit) is the Museum of Natural History. Don't forget the Tavern on the Green, the castle and all the fabulous concerts and outdoor performances in the summer.We will definately stay here again next year, and hopfully for years to come, on our "girls weekend" in NYC. WE CAN'T WAIT!

Mar 22 2009 	Wonderful 25th Wedding Anniversary Celebration	My husband and I celebrated our 25th Wedding Anniversary in Febuary at the Waldorf. After reading a few negative comments we were a bit apprehensive about what to expect. We shouldn't have worried. The staff were very friendly and couldn't have been more helpful. We had asked for an upgrade and received a room on the 27th floor with a corner view of Lexington and Park Avenues with an amazing view of the Chyrsler Building.We never ate in the hotel as it was too expensive, but found an excellent cafe around the corner for breakfast called Cafe Europe. All in all brilliant.One top tip, try and get tickets for the Rose Centre, sound and vision show in the Planetarium.

Mar 22 2009 	Doesn't live up to the name	I was very excited to spend my birthday in the City and stay at the renowned, Waldor. Well, to keep this brief, I would have been more impressed and gotten better value for my money staying at the Holiday Inn. First off, check-in was confusing and took too long. The elevators malfunctioned (had to go down to go back up). And worst of all the room, was not what we was expect. I get the appeal of old charm, but our room was just OLD and had a weird, musty smell. The tub backed up and we had to space showers so that the water could drain completely. To make matters worse, I was over charged...We compensated for our accomadations by spending absolutely no time there, we returned late and left as soon as we awoke..

Mar 21 2009 	A little dusty but great location for the price	We were very excited to stay at the famed Waldorf on our trip to NYC but were definitely a little disappointed by the experience. The hotel had a very "convention/tourist" feel rather than the old world elegance we were expecting and the hotel as a whole was pretty dusty and tired feeling. Our room was a decent size for an NYC hotel but our view of the flat rooftop left a lot to be desired. The room was pretty clean though and the location to the 5th Avenue shops and Broadway can't be beat. Room service costs (for breakfast) were absolutely outrageous, even by NYC standards which was annoying.

Mar 20 2009 	Service much improved	I've stayed here a few times over the years, and always thought their service was pretty dismal. It would appear that someone has decided to remedy this. Was also pleased with a relatively large room -- stayed in the front of the hotel this time rather than towards the back. Rooms are clean and beds are comfy. My room only had a shower -- no big deal for me but I think a larger person would have difficulty fitting in the rather small space. If you like more space in which to shower in, suggest that you ask specifically for a bathtub.

Mar 19 2009 	Best avoided unless you are a VIP	The Waldorf obviously is a landmark hotel and its reputation is well deserved in most respects. Unfortunately, I find that the level of service and quality of room drops significantly if you lack celebrity status or your name is not prefaced by something like "Senator" or "Ambassador." On recent trip, I was made to wait 2 hours beyond regular check-in time for my room after having registered early (but they were more than happy to hold my bag ... thanks for that). Then, I was told that I was "upgraded" to a SUPERIOR Room. Wow (thanks again). What I found was that my SUPERIOR Room was so small that I had to turn sideways in order to squeeze past certain spots, and the bed needed to be moved in order to unfold an ironing board. Calls to Guest Services were met with ambivalence. Simply not acceptable for a hotel of such stature. There is a W Hotel and a Doubletree directly across the street, likely better values for a stay in Mid-town.

Mar 12 2009 	fantastic locationfriendly staffmost comfortable bed in the world	Arrived in new york for the first time in august and checked into the waldorf for not a lot more than no name hotels charge in poor locations.The staff are very friendly and eager to please.Our room wasnt ready on arrival so they gave us a free upgrade with a view of lexington avenue and a voucher to get some free drinks at the bar.We had to wait about an hour so we had a look around the hotels ballrooms and shops.The room was very nice as we had expected and the beds were the most comfortable I have ever slept on.The maids came every day and did an excellent job.Unfortunately I didnt know til we got home that youre meant to leave a few dollars tip on pillow every day .Its a good idea to have a roll of dollar bills ready for tips to the staff who appreciate even for a buck.The location is perfect and I felt safe walking around surrounding area at midnight .I would highly recommend this hotel to everyone and hope to go back again one day.

Mar 11 2009 	Loved every minute of it	I had wanted to stay at the Waldorf since I was little. Further to this, we booked a 4 night stay this March for my 40th.Before I booked I read every single review on this site and made a note of what I did and did not want. I made additional requests for a high floor, refurbished room with a nice view.We got there quite early due to a morning flight and were given some vouchers for drinks. A gentleman was summoned to take our bags to the room. I got over excited about the tipping and gave him $20. 5 minutes later he rang our door bell (yes door bell) and asked us to follow him to the 18th floor for a private tour of the ballroom and other grand meeting rooms. This was fab, a real treat. The rooms are amazing.Our room had a seperate parlour and bedroom and an enourmous marble bathroom with seperate bath and shower. It was a really cosy room which my husband said was like a 'little flat' all of our own. We were on the 19th floor and had fantastic views from 4 windows of Lexington Avenue and Manhattan. It snowed while we were there an it was amazing to see from our room.We paid $279 per night for the room. Including 1 room service breakfast, a room service dinner, a shoe shine (had to try it) and 4 budweisers ($50.50 but on ice with their own table!), our whole bill came to about $1500.Allot of money but when you look at the quality and size of the room, the level of service and the location, then compare it to the prices of other 'posh' NYC hotels, it isn't half bad.I loved the whole experience. Please don't even bother staying here if your main priority is a wide screen telly and wifi. Do stay however if you fancy being sent back in time to a more elegant and classy era.Another tip. Mar 10 2009 	great place to stay	My wife always wanted to stay in Waldorf Astoria. It lived it's expectations!! marvelous place!!we will be back!

Mar 9 2009 	Excellent Service	We have stayed at the Waldorf several times over the past years and have always enjoyed our stay - this time we returned to the Waldorf after a couple years absence and were impressed by the increased level of service and efficiency - all given by genuinely friendly, competent personnel. All members of the staff: the doorman, valet, bellhop, check-in person, room service, maintenance, waiters at both Bull & Bear and Peacock Alley made us feel like we were the most important people staying at the hotel and I observed that this level of service seemed to be the norm.Although the Waldorf was fully booked, we never had to wait or ask for anything - check-in went very smoothly - we were escorted to our room and the luggage arrived immediately, as soon as we stepped outside we were asked if we needed a taxi and it was promptly hailed, as soon as we arrived to one of the hotel's restaurants we were immediately greeted and shown to our table, the server came to our table instantly and continued to provide excellent service, each call to guest services for a request had someone at our room within minutes - even getting our car at the end of our stay - Biden was arriving as we were leaving so the cars were being delayed but the staff was wonderful and very responsive to the guests - we relaxed in a lounge area of the hotel and when we returned to get our car, it was waiting with a couple people helping to load the luggage, open car doors, etc. - and, it was extremely busy at this time.Again, all the staff were genuinely warm, friendly and extremely efficient. Everything seemed to go perfectly, we did not have to "think" it was so seemless. The Waldorf is an older, historic property and there are some things about the Waldorf that probably would be helpful to know:- During all my stays, there has never been a coffee maker in the room, I have speculated on reasons - building construct and codes, etc., but have never found out for certain. However, we called room service and asked if they would deliver a hot pot and a variety of tea bags for our stay - we paid a very minimal charge and these items were delivered promptly.- Rooms appear to be continually renovated. Also, there is a great variety of room types and the floorplans on each floor vary. I always note that I would like a renovated room when making a reservation and repeat the request upon check-in. I have always received wonderful rooms. Each room appears uniquely decorated and this time we stayed in a beautiful one-bedroom suite that definitely had an elegant, warm, "home" feeling rather than a cookie-cutter hotel room feel.- As with any hotel, there may be maintenance issues, but the staff responds immediately and expertly if you mention it. We had one of the heaters in the living room giving off cold air, no heat. We called guest services, a maintenance person arrived within 5 mins, explained that a new part was needed but rather than have us wait, he called housekeeping for an electric heater. This arrived in 5 mins - a brand new, quiet, tower style heater. Then, when we returned from our activities there was a message from the manager to check that everything was ok and to please call if we need anything else.- Bathroom amenities, etc. - if you need anything else by way of bathroom amenities, a phone call to guest services has it delivered promptly.- Turn down service - the hotel services directory notes that you should call if you would like turn down service, we called the first day to request it and it was provided consistently throughout our stay.- It has been my experience that management at the Waldorf responds to comments or issues immediately and does their best to ensure that things are resolved during a stay. We had an excellent stay at the Waldorf and, if it were possible to transport the Waldorf staff to every hotel I stay at, I would.

Third night I received the salad but without parmesan cheese slivers, and the whole wheat toast. Fourth night I received the same thing as the third night but was charged $8.00 for the whole grain toast.Overall: When you travel all the time consistency is key. Just didn't feel that here. If you want to stay here once, go ahead and roll the dice. If you want to be sure of service, you might need to look elsewhere. Plus side: The check-in staff was great. Feb 17 2009 	Beautiful hotel issues with service	My wife and I stayed at the Waldorf-Astoria for two nights in late January 2009. We made our reservation through American Express for a room listed as 1 King Bed Concierge Level. The Waldorf had always been a hotel I wished to stay in so I was excited about the visit.The hotel is truly magnificent. Staying there really takes one back to a time when a visit to a hotel was an EVENT, not something we do simply as a necessity. I was taken thinking of how my parents or grandparents would have felt as a guest there, and how much the hotel has changed in the past century, but how little (overall) the Waldorf had managed to retain the grand charm of days long past. If for no other reason than connecting with history, staying in the Waldorf is an experience one must do at some point in their life.The room we were given was in the Waldorf Towers and we were very pleased with the room overall. The size was exceptionally large for a New York hotel room. In addition to the main bedroom, there was an entry foyer, a kitchenette area, a dressing area, and a very large bathroom. The fixtures were a nice blend of old and modern, from the trio of closets to the multi-jetted shower. The condition of the room was excellent and all the linens and amenities were of superior levels. The view was a decent view down Park Avenue but nothing postcard worthy.The Concierge Level lounge provided a very nice continental breakfast each morning in a private room. The quality of the food and the selection were excellent, even if you had only a moment to grab a coffee to go. The staff in this area did a nice job of helping with most all requests. The area is small though, so dont be shocked if you have to wait a few moments for a table.The main amenities of the hotel are all superior. The fitness facility is very modern and well thought out, even providing guests with fitness gear in case you have left yours at home. The concierge is most helpful, providing good information and reviews on local restaurants. The shops and business center are well done and very convenient. And the location of the hotel is hard to beat.My main complaint with the hotel is one of attitude towards guests who are younger than, say, 50 or 60 years. Although they were always polite, the staff seemed to be uncomfortable dealing with my wife and I (both in our 30s but looking much more like two people in their 20s). From the front desk to the bell attendants, there seemed to be this underlying sentiment of are you sure you are old enough to be staying here? whenever we dealt with staff members. Given that we are polite, courteous and professional people, it caught us very off guard. Overall, this is a fine hotel and well worth a visit. I would recommend it to anyone, especially those over the age of 40.

Feb 6 2009 	W-A better than many reviews	I was rather nervous about staying at the famous Waldorf-Astoria after reading a number of negative reviews on various web sites. Frankly, this is an old, prestigious hotel, and I wanted to experience the art deco building and style.Check-In: More clerks than guests, so I walked right up at about 4pm. Nice attitude.Room: For NY, this was a LARGE room. Big King bed, huge desk, flat screen TV, mini-bar, two large windows (alas, overlooking a rooftop of another section of the hotel, but you can't have everything - if I looked sideways, I could see the street). Furniture was traditional style, and very fine. No wear and tear. Bathroom was good sized, black and white marble, exquisite fixtures in art deco style.Amenities: everything worked well, including the heat controls, and the maid did the room early each morning. Just fine. Newspaper every morning.General: Elevators are on key-card after 6pm for security, and they were FAST. Lobby is fantastic. The entire hotel is beautiful and kept up well. There were employees everywhere asking to help. The concierge was helpful, printed my boarding pass for the return flight without charge. Room service was expensive, so I left it out. No coffee maker, but I suppose that was an economy measure. Starbucks is in the hotel. Lower lobby. So, why bother?All-in-all, it was a very delightful stay. Room was great, checkout was swift. Internet in the lobby is free; in the room it is a charge. No problem sitting in the lobby accessing the net. Others did it too. Enjoyed seeing Cole Porter's piano in the Cocktail Lounge. And, I felt like a rich Master of the Universe, for only 120,000 points. The room is certainly worth the money - the location is great, the service is excellent, and the art deco furnishings and architecture are fabulous. A landmark it is. They had pictures of famous guests everywhere, but I was never able to figure out why Hermione Gingold was relegated to the Men's Room.

Jan 27 2009	loved this amazing hotel	we have just arrived back from our 5 day break at the waldorf astoria&after reading alot of the reviews on how unhappy peaple were with their rooms,i was a bit concerned!When we arrived,straight away our bags were taken care of by the doormen,while we checked ourselves in.The hotel is huge&very elegant.We arrived at 2pm and were given our room keys almost immediatley.We just booked the standard king room and we were pleasantly surprised by how beautiful it was.Very spacious,huge bed,desk,fab mirrored wardrobes,very beautiful marble bathroom with huge shower,bathrobes,hairdryer,minibar ipod station and immaculatley clean!we had a huge window with a view of park avenue.We were very pleased.It was my husbands 40th birthday and had a very exclusive box of waldorf chocolates& white rose left in our room which i thought was a lovely surprise.Hotel bars & restaurants are very expensive.Didnt eat at hotel so cannot comment on the food.There are alot of business and money peaple stay at this hotel but all the same we felt very comfortable around them,When we went to plaza hotel for a look around we felt very uncomfortable and out of our league.The waldorf is very central 2 everything,it is in a great midtown position.Would definately recommend this hotel to anyone considering it.I give this hotel 10/10

Jan 24 2009 	A complete and utter disappointment	In early August 2008, having arrived at La Guardia from LA X, the last thing you'd want to do is arrive in a stuffy indoor car park and wait there for about half an hour whilst a member of staff gives you the look of death for not tipping him!
