Jan 8 2009	Lied To!	On Oct 23rd 2008 I booked a 2 room Concierge level suite at a very good negotiated rate of $399+taxes.I was concerned when the E mail confirmation said "King Bed Concierge Level"I phoned and questioned this and I was told,"Don't worry Sir that's only the way it prints out,your reservation is for a suite as discussed".On the7th of Jan I recieved an E mail offering me cut price upgrades and when I investigated found that the suite was an upgrade being offered to me.I phoned the Waldorf and spoke to them without rancour as they'd obviously made a mistake.No mistake,they wanted an extra $150 per night.I pointed out that the $399 rate was actually above their rate for a king bed concierge level available on the internet but they wouldn't budge.I've cancelled and have achieved a very good deal at the Sofitel which I will report on later.

Jan 7 2009 	A classic beauty	The main entry reflects elegance of a time gone by.We are Hilton Diamond members and used a Hilton Award to celebrate a special anniversary. Our room was a newly renovated corner room on a lower floor. The heating system worked perfectly. The room had a large boudoir adjacent to the well sized bedroom. The bathroom was a marble studded gem. The location of the Waldorf is perfect for touring NYC. The theater district, MOMA and 5th Ave shopping are located close enough for a walk or a quick cab ride.Oscars, a wonderful breakfast place on the lower floor of the hotel, is no longer a perks for Diamond or Gold members. The Starbucks is the new breakfast benefit. Starbucks is located at the base of the hotel. It is very good, but you have to bring the food into the hotel if you want to sit down to have breakfast.Sir Harry's bar is a cozy place to go for drinks. You can order champagne by the glass. The Diamond desk has a staffing problem. This is the second time this year we have had excessive waits to get registered. If someone at the Diamond desk has a problem the staff does not alert the hotel management that additional help is needed to take care of Diamond members. Once we did get to our beautiful room we were pleased. The house keeping staff does a beautiful job of keeping it clean. They were exceptionally friendly and courteous.

Jan 7 2009 	Better to visit than stay	My husband booked a surprise three night stay in NYC at the Waldorf for the pair of us. The hotel is breathtaking upon entrance and definitely worth a look around as it is beautiful with regards to bars/restaurants/lobby etc etc. However the rooms were disappointing. Whilst I appreciate the hotel is old, the room we were given was very small and 'faded' even though we had paid to upgrade. In addition we were right next to the service area which was very noisy at 5.30am! We requested a move but having arrived Xmas night were told the hotel was full and would be offered a better room the next day at 3pm. We returned to move our things at this time and were disappointed to find our room not ready so had to hang around until it was, which was a bit annoying as we only returned to the hotel to move things and thought we could freshen up and have a rest but c ould not do this as we were 'in limbo' between rooms. We were then given a better room and yes it was in a nicer part of the building ie quieter and yes bigger in size but pretty much the same in the way of 'tiredness' of the room if that makes sense! Overall I loved New York and this did not spoil our stay but certainly wouldn't pay the money my husband did to stay there again when there are cheaper hotels with much better accommodation in New York from what I have seen/heard .(This was my fifth trip to NYC) Make the time to visit the Waldorf and even have a drink in Harry's bar (albeit very expensive I had the best Apple Martini I have ever had!!) its worth a trip but treat it more as a museum to visit rather than somewhere to choose to stay.

Jan 2 2009 	A retrospective of 5 stays	In the last decade my wife and I have stayed at the Waldorf=Astoria 5 sepatate times, each during Christmas week. We have experienced accomodation categories from an executive room in the Towers to a king one-bedroom suite in the main hotel. Much to my surprise, we have never been recognized as repeat clients when checking in. In some other hotels we have frequented, the better rooms are routinely given to returning clients. This has not been our experience at the Waldorf. Overall, we have never had an unacceptable experience (by our standards). Our one stay in the Towers is remembered mostly for the rude and unhelpful Towers staff. Our room expereinces in the main hotel have been hit-and-miss with both postives and negatives. In terms of the rooms alone, our best experience was being assigned a corner suite on a high floor. This suite was very spacious and the basic decor was classic. Yet, some of the furniture was broken and (in the bedroom) the backs were literally falling off both nightstands. The wall paper in the parlor was waterstained and bubbled around a window. I mention this case specifically because this is very typical of our 5 Waldorf expereinces--a mix of postiives and negatives that some will find acceptable (or at least tolerable) and others will judge totally unacceptable.This past year (2008) we had a Lexington Ave side king- suite--significantly smaller than the corner mentioned above but overall better appointed and in better condition. A few oddities with the bathroom plumbing and a large entertainment console that did not fit well in the parlor. Quite noisy at times due to Lex Ave emergency vehicles and garbage trucks. That mix again.The queen Astor suites in the Lexington Ave side of the hotel were redecorated a few years ago and overall I would expect these suites to be in better condition than others. Early on we had a mini-suite with an excellent bed but otherwise in need of furniture replacement--topped off by 2 bathrooms and a great view of the St. Barts dome across 50th street. Always a mixed experience.Over the years we have found the reception and housekeeping staffs to be polite and willing to help when asked. As I am a native New Yorker, we have never used the concierge staff. At present, it appears that occupancy is down (hotel was significantly less busy that in previous years)and staff reductions have already occurred. A problem in the making--not sure.So why then have we returned on numerous occassions? The main reason is that we have had mostly good times at the Waldorf, in large part because we have been able to enjoy the positives and put the negatives aside. In many ways this is a great classic hotel. In terms of cost, the suites have been nicely priced in late Dec. (relative to many other hotels). As others have frequently mentioned, the public spaces are magnificent. I started this review with a bit of a negative tone because I think that one should be aware of the Waldorf experience. Given that, I have rated the hotel above average overall as this is how we judge our collective experience with this hotel. As this forum indicates, many others have a different view. I have no reason to think that the general situation sketched out above will change for the bettter or for the worse. If you like modern and impeccably appointed hotels look elsewhere. If you are comfortable with history, classic decor, and flexible on many little details you may well enjoy a stay at the Waldorf. I believe that no two rooms/suites are the same, so you are in part dependent on the luck of the draw as far as accomodations are concerned. Will we return?--haven't decided yet.h

Jan 1 2009 	unforgettable holiday	we stayed at the Waldorf for Christmas, what a great expierence. I did have some concerns after reading some of the negative comments from other travelers, who had stayed at the Waldorf. All I can say is I don't see how any one can stay in this Historic Hotel with has such an elegant appeal to it, and not be happy. Our room was ready on arrival and it was spotless, it was much larger than I was expecting and the bed was very comfortable. The maids came in daily and did an excellent job. The concierge staff were so helpful and nothing was too much trouble. We had a room on the 17th floor as we had requested a smoking room, not much of a view but we weren't expecting one, its New York. The people of the city were very helpful, we even had our photo taken on a policemans Harley Davidson. We did not eat in the hotel as there are so many Delis that serve excellent food at a fraction of the cost, I can highly recomend Scottys Diner on Lexington Avenue, wonderful food with a great service. We decided to spend our money in Maceys. What a shop so easy to get lost. Iceskating at the Rockafella Center looked rather small so we went to Central Park, the rink was much bigger and less busy. A helpful tip, if you want to go to the Empire State building get there early, we went straight up at 9.a.m, by 10a.m. the queue was going round the block. I would recomend this beautiful hotel to all of my friends and I could not find fault with a single thing.

Dec 31 2008	Great Time In NY 	1st time in NY and booked at The Waldorf. Staff were excellent. The porters were very helpful and friendly, the cocktail bar man advised us a couple of places to eat ('I eat there with my family') and we were not disappointed. Our stay was great, the hotel is beautiful and has kept its old charm. Its not the cheapest but what a nice place to stay and the area was very business like and not overly populated with tourists (us). Remember any room you book in manhattan will be small unless you are paying a fortune so don't expect huge rooms, but again the time you spend in there is asleep anyway. The hotel was great and I would stay again and recommend. It was our first visit to NY and the hotel and its staff made us very welcome.

Dec 29 2008 	Not what you would expect	When you first walk in the lobby is fabulous. The room, however, was a disappointment. Understanding the age of the hotel I expected small rooms (ours was one of the few with a King bed) but the room had none of the amenities you would expect for $389 per night. No robes, a small tv, no thermostat to control temp (we had to open the window frequently to keep the temperature from being uncomfortably hot). Decor was also a dissapointment. the bar was nice, and Sonny was a great bartender. Sandy (waitress) on the other had consistently complained about her job in front of customers, and always had a scowl on her face. Getting change for cab fare was next to impossible as the line for guest services was frequently quite long (10 minutes).Concierge service was unimaginative to say the least. they couldn't recommend restaurants new the Waldorf open past 10pm on two requests. (City that never sleeps?)The Sunday brunch was ok (but at $95 per person you would expect more) and the Bull and Bear turned out an acceptable steak, but pale in comparison to Del Friscos just down the street.All in all, we won't stay at the Waldorf again.

Dec 28 2008	As sad state of affairs	Unbelievably awful and depressing. Used to be a grand dame of hotels in NY, now is like any crappy Hilton. We had to wait 40 minutes behind ropes to register, las vegas style because there was a mob scene and the hotel decided to have 4 desks open. The lobby had been converted to a crappy las vegas style buffet, so the mob had to stand beside the steam trays and wilting roast beefs. The hotel seems to service hoards of tourists and is about pushing people in and out. The room was not as pictured/described at all. The "one bedroom suite" was a cramped, shoddy, depressing room that looked out at a brick wall. The bathtub drain didn't work, the temp controller was broken so the room was insufferably hot. There is no free wireless, like there is in any mcdonalds or red roof inn. It is a crowded, touristy, depressing hellhole with outrageous prices. Sad, this used to be a gorgeous and lovely hotel. Whomever ruined this hotel should be ashamed of themselves.

Dec 22 2008 	Like staying at Grandma's - but she doesn't love you any more.	I travel to NY for business a good bit. I was spending a quick weekend for pre-xmas NY enjoyment and wanted to use some Hilton points. I saw I could book the fabled Waldorf Astoria - why not? I knew it was a bit of a gamble but figured the location was right, plus I didn't require much, and when else would I get to check it out?It went fine. It was what we needed. The location was indeed very good. The room was good enough. If I had paid $ I would have been very disappointed. It was like a best western I guess.. except I think those have had to keep up with the 1990s at a minimum. I can't think of much to compare it to. Old school vegas, maybe. Think freemont street. Frozen in time. Everything is a bit musty and dank. If they built it today and used that styling you might call it retro and give it a good laugh. When it is actual items from the 60s, however, they are a bit grimy and dirty. The rooms are full of carpet and oldness. There is a massive draft through the poorly sealed 1954 window. The temperature controls are pretty shoddy. Think motel 6. There are 600 uniformed employees to watch you as you walk around the hallways... there are large chandeliers... these things are all true - note them if they are what you are into. The mini bar doesn't autodetect what you take. If you are really lucky they will give you some COUPONS for free tiny bottles of water from the mini bar. They will instruct you to place these COUPONS in the minifridge in lieu of the water.. really... 1984-style. It is a riot. The showerhead literally has a font from a beatles album on it. Neat... but.. not very good for showering.The business center literally has FLOPPY DISKS for sale. I kid you not. I heard them tell someone they could lend him a charger for his laptop - $50/day. Funny stuff. Wifi? You gotta be kidding... nothing close. Lucky you have power. 2-prong power. No ground plug. I can't believe they had mag cards now that I think of it - I would have expected a bunch of skeleton keys handed out at the front desk. Kiosk checkin? HAHAHAHA. No way. Oh it gets better... We get a PERK.. free breakfast! After the checkin person mentioned 2 restaurants that would honor this, they backtracked in apparent embarrassment when the printed vouched stipulated the 'breakfast' was at.. STARBUCKS. Yup... one cookie and a coffee. Out of control with oldschool old-fashioned cheapness that seems ignorant of all the real hotels with customer service dotting the city.Oh yeah... went for a run. Wanted a hot tub. Called around and inquired about having one at the gym... no.. maybe the spa?... no... nowhere. No hot tub in the entire palace. Ok.In sum, this is without a doubt the worst hotel I've stayed at in years - and certainly in New York. It should definitely be demolished and replaced with something useful. It still exists for the same reasons as racism and The Varsity restaurant in Atlanta - sometimes people value 'tradition' over any actual quality/benefit.Don't stay here.

Dec 15 2008 	Best hotel in New York!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!	Myself and my husband were due to go to New York 4th Dec 2008 for 5 nights we had booked a hotel through expedia a bog standard 2 star property however upon arrival I found that my darling husband had secretly changed our hotel to the Waldorf to my absolute delight!!!! Bless him, it was a surprise xmas gift as he knows I have always wanted to stay there as I thinks its so new york!!! The hotel is amazing so luxurious and gorgeous and our room was lovely. The hotel is always busy and full with people and there is always something going on such as an awards ceremony or a wedding etc so very posh!!! The hotel is in such a great location and we found it easy enough to get everywhere from there. Very very very busy in New York in december never seen anything like it shopping was just a complete nightmare as you had to que to get in everywere so maybe I wouldnt reccommend dec as too busy but then on the other hand you wouldnt see all the fabulous xmas decorations and lights which we just unbelievable! all in all a brilliant hotel and we thought why the hell not as to us we probably wouldnt visit new york again so we wanted it to be special!

Dec 11 2008 	Great place for three-generation New York vacation	We took a three-generation July 4th trip to NYC, and just had to stay at the Waldorf because it is SO New York, and also because it was the only hotel my father would stay at, except the Plaza and they were closed for renovation. The oldsters where thrilled with the hotel, accommodations, food, service. The teens and pre-teens found endless wonders daily in and around the hotel. And those of us in the middle were happily just a few blocks from Bloomingdale's. All of our rooms were really large and seemed brand new in a New York old-money kind of way, which was unexpected but great. From the doormen in front who would get you a limo or cab in a blink, to the glorious, glorious lobby bouquet, to the stiffly-press bellman, to the front-desk staff that seemed to belong at the UN as much as at a hotel front desk... it was perfect New York. I was a little concerned about staying right in the middle of midtown on a trip like that, but it was a great location, with all the flavor and comfort that we wanted.

Dec 10 2008	Park Avenue's Historic Hotel	I had not stayed at the Waldorf-Astoria since 2002 so I was interested to see if anything had changed at the hotel. The service at the hotel is excellent and the breakfasts' that I ate at the restaurant "Oscar's" were very good as well. Check-in was swift. The only complaint was that the first night I was supposed to have a suite and my room was located near an elevator shaft and I heard it making a noise all night. This room was on the 22nd floor. I was moved to another room after I let the staff know about the noise which was much quieter- however, it was not a suite. I would recommend using the Lexington Street exit to hail a cab from between 5 PM-6:30 PM as the cab lines on Park Avenue are way too long. I missed a dinner reservation because of it.

Dec 10 2008	Really enjoyed our stay	Stayed 5 nights at the Waldorf Astoria in November.Upgraded to a King suite at check in, which was great. No negatives to our stay.Room was cleaned to a high standard.Breakfast in the towers lounget was of the continental variety, would only pay for this if you really want the convenience.Spent most of the time out of the hotel although made use of Harry's Bar early evenings and for a quick drink before bed, great ambience, good service

Dec 2 2008 	Relive a golden era	Ya gotta love grand old New York! We arrived by cab on the Park Ave side. The hotel was quite busy so we toted our own luggage up a short flight of stairs into the enormous lobby. It was as if we entered a long lost era. The lobby features those high ceilings and big chandeliers you rarely find in contemporary buildings.Checkin was very quick.. the front desk team very friendly. Took our own bags to the room. Booked through corporate travel, it was your basic room. The decor is a bit dated but very plush. A king bed that slept well. A big flat screen tv. Furniture in good condition. Nice, very clean and well appointed marble bathroom with a shower, no bathtub. Again, I had booked a basic room.. so I give the Waldorf a big thumbs up that I wasn't in some dark dank closet but instead in a well appointed space. We had drinks in the lobby bar. Very pricey (16 each) but well made. Came with good bar snacks. The bar was not clubby as you'd might expect in an old grande dame hotel though. A bit disappointing.Checked out via the service on the television. The bellhop had us wait inside (in the warmth) until our car arrived. Overall a pleasant experience. Better than many of the newer boutigue hotels with tiny rooms and darkened hallways. I would go stay here again if my business or visit keeps me on the east side of NYC.

Nov 27 2008 	Wonderful hotel experience	Myself and my girlfriend stayed here the week of 19th November. we arrived at the hotel at about 245pm, to have our bags helpfully taken from the taxi, in the underground entrance off lexington avenue. We went to the grand lobby and were checked straight in to our deluxe room. The staff during our whole hotewl stay were very good, from the doormen to the reception staff, concierge desk, travel desk and the cleaning people were all very nicve and helpful.Our bags were delivered to our deluxe room promptly. The room itself was fantastic, it definetley was a bit bigger than i was expecting. The bed was a huge and super comfortable kingsize bed, really good. The room was quite big that we had three large windows facing the bed, but the room was in no way cold, in fact we even turned the heating off at night. We also had two large separate built in wardrobes. The bathroom was all marble and the shower was good. The wireless signal in the room was not the strongest, but for all the length of time i was using it for, i just used the free service in the lobby.The hotel location itself is fantastic. The nearest subway entrance is only about 150yards away, fith avenue shopping only a five minute walk away and times square is about 15 minute walk or a quick ride on the subway.Is the hotel brand new and shiny...no. But it has a charm and charisma and everything was spotlessly cleana and in working order while i stayed there. I would definitely stay here again for a New York holiday.

Nov 26 2008	Upgraded!	I wanted to say that I too was on the Cunnard booking and the organisation from Cunnard was not good but also add that I feel we were really well treated by the Hotel staff and how we enjoyed our stay in this majestic old style hotel. The hotel had said the rooms would not be avaialble until 3pm, we knew this prior to arrival so we went sight seeing. On return after 3pm I went straight to reception desk and we booked straight in. I know that other Cunnard guests waited in a reception room for a long time but I feel this is because the information they got from the tour guides was not good. We had asked our travel agent to arrange two rooms together and as this was not available we got upgraded to a junior suite. This was wonderful large room which had recently been decorated with a huge really comfy bed. The other room we saw was also excellent. It appears that your experience of this hotel depends on the standard of the room allocated, if unhappy ask to be moved!We found really helpful staff who went out of their way to help throughout the Hotel.The Cunnard group was over 300 people so the check in was not going to be easy, all I can say is how well we wre looked after. It is a great hotel, close to the action.

Nov 25 2008 	After the QM2 crossing	We were booked here via Cunard after a transatlantic crossing on the QM2. Hotel was a disaster at the start. We arrived early (not sure who to blame) at 11.45 but our tickets said rooms ready for 3pm. Luggage taken off coach and put on pavement outside hotel.We were put in a very hot room and given coffee and advised that as we were a large party - 300 - our rooms may take a time to be allocated.Sensing a long wait my husband and I left the hotel and began our sightseeing trip.We arrived back at the hotel at 4pm to see little change. Loads of our party getting very agitated as few rooms had been allocated and that our luggage was still outside on the pavement! There was nothing to drink despite requests for water. A representative from the hotel said that rooms would be released as soon as possible.5pm came and went with the production of 3 jugs of iced water and paper cups but no rooms being released.Despite being told to wait for our keys/rooms to be allocated I joined a short queue in the main reception of the hotel. I checked in as normal and was given my room key and advised my luggage was in my room!!!Quite obviously the hotel was not able to cope with the Cunard guests and showed it was utterly unprepared.Next morning we received a letter from management apologising for the delays and we were given a credit to our room account of 50 dollars. This did not even cover the cost of a buffet breakfast for two.Our room was draughty, the sash windows were not clean and the whole room had an air of faded charm.The reception/lobby of the hotel is magnificent and is a magnate for all tourists to New York and is not to be missed, but there is no way I would stay here again.Some of the blame for the problem can be laid at the feet of Cunard and this is also being addressed.

Nov 24 2008 	Dreadful welcome at the door but everything else fab	Dreadful welcome. Our taxi pulled up, no help from the taxi driver to get our luggage out. The doorman saw us and barked "It's too early to check in!" and promptly ignored us with no help for luggage / doors etc. It was 2 30 pm ! However everything else was fab. The diamond desk sorted out a double bedded room with a separate dressing area for 4 girls. Jackie and Mary were very welcoming and helpful, giving us info on shoppping and other trips. They assisted with obtaining a late checkout as well. Lovely ladies.The public areas were spotless and full of wonderful Art Deco touches.The wedding flowers in the foyer were fabulous ( though we overheard security say on the Saturday night that the wedding guests were fighting!) and we loved reading the history of the hotel from the displays. The staff were smiley, approachable and all took a pride in their job. The doormen at the luggage collection point were a complete contrast to their front door colleagues. They sorted our luggage, smiled and chatted and found an extra large taxi. Excellent.Our room was spotlessly clean and large enough for 4 adults. Plenty of hot water and the beds and bedding were super comfortable.The hotel was in an excellent spot for sightseeing and we would certainly stay there agin

Nov 17 2008 	Good Stay but wouldn't come back...	Booked the Waldorf Astoria for weekend of November 17th for a Ladies weekend in NY. Was hoping for these lovely large rooms I'd seen written about so many times on the reviews but alas...it was not to be. The room was one of the smallest I'd ever stayed in..tight for 3 women. The bathroom was just like any other hotel bathroom except also maybe smaller. Nothing about the inside of the room made you think you were in anything other than a large dime a dozen chain hotel. Of course the lobby and public spaces were very nice but is it worth the huge upcharge...no.There is no wireless internet except in the lobby and the wired internet is pricey. There was also a shooting in the hotel stores while we were there. A crazy man tried to rob the Cellini jewelry store and he shot the security guard, a retired NYPD officer... sad and crazy! All interactions with staff were pleasant but again, nothing to brag about.The Sunday brunch was quite a shock. It is set up in the lobby and looks very nice although not much more elegant or posh than a local resteraunt in my town. The cost was $95 per person... Ouch!

Nov 10 2008 	Charming and Full of Character	Myself and three girlfriends were all sharing one room but hey - we were staying at the Waldorf! The room was large with two generous sized and very comfortable beds. We had a separate dressing room with wall to wall mirrored wardrobes, with double doors leading to a large bathroom complete with huge mirror and marble washstand. After reading several reviews where people were disappointed with their rooms - we were thrilled with ours. The staff were all extremely friendly and helpful, the service couldn't be faulted. Rooms were clean and tidy, there's a turn down service so don't leave stuff on your beds when you go out in the evening. Towels were changed twice a day, even when we'd left them out to dry. One down side for us English ladies was that there are no tea-making facilities but we had brought our own travel kettle and tea-bags after being fore-warned by other reviews. Take the time to have a look at the exhibition of old photos and memorabilia in the lobby and visit the Ballroom and Starlight Bar - fabulous art decco decor. Apparently there's a guided tour of the hotel but only on Thursdays so we missed that. We had one rather decadent night drinking champagne in the piano bar where we were spoilt rotten by the most lovely waiter who brought us complimentory savoury nibbles, then dainty cakes, then chocolate desserts in champagne glasses - with the third bottle of champers also being "on the house" we had a lovely memorable evening - hic!

Nov 9 2008 	Of course it was great but...	First of all, this is THE W-A, so it is an amazing (and amazingly historic) hotel. The room was HUGE, especially for being in the heart of Manhattan. We had an OK-sized bathroom, a nice sized living room, a bedroom w/ King and a walk-in closet. BAM!!!The service was great and any staff we came across were helpful.BUT....there were some things I was not crazy about, like the bathroom door was big and swung open w/in an inch of the toilet - NOT convenient. And the hotel, as historic as it is, is also OLD...the dark hallways w/ old carpet reminded me of "The Shining," no kidding. But all in all it was a great stay for a weekend. Truly awesome to have stayed in 1 of America's most historic and luxurious hotels.

Nov 7 2008 	Beatiful Elegant a fantastic stay.	The Waldorf Astoria hotel was beautiful and elegantStayed in Manhattan for three days whilst visiting friends in New Jersey .Family of four (two girls 14 & 10). The lobby areas are a must see even if your not staying there. The staff where friendly and so helpful. We had a good look round the ballroom was unbelievable.Our room had two double beds although not large it was very comfortable.The location was great short walk to the Rockefeller top of the rock is a must.It was well worth paying the extra to experience staying at the Waldorf.

Nov 6 2008 	Living on it's past	This is the second time we've stayed at the Waldorf, the first time we were upgraded to a fantastic suite, this time we were given the smallest hotel room I've ever seen, for three of us! We asked to move and the room we were given was certainly larger but with peeling wallpaper, ripped cushions on the furniture and a very unusual smell. We had originally booked for four nights but checked out the next day and went to the London Hotel on 54th and 7th which was a breath of fresh air.The Waldorf has great history and a rare presence, but if you need quality accommodation at a this price you can do a lot better. There is no wireless internet in the room and the wired service is expensive.

Nov 4 2008 	Great service old-world charm	My husband and I stayed at the Waldorf during the NYC marathon since we found a great rate ($275/night) by booking nearly a year in advance on the hotel's website.We loved the attentive service, and especially appreciated the free upgrade to a larger King room. The quality of the service and the history put this hotel in the 5-star category. However, we've stayed in hotels with nicer rooms in 4-star hotels.We recommend the Bear & the Bull bar for a nightcap. The bartenders were hilarious & very attentive. Be prepared to spend $30-40 for two drinks (unless you are drinking the $6 pints of beer).We would definitely stay at the Waldorf if we found another great rate, but there's no way we would pay the going rate of $700/night.

Nov 1 2008 	Overpriced and over-hyped	The hotel staff were really good, the location is excellent BUT the hotel itself is faded glory, the rooms we were in (and we were poart of a large ocnference) were in serious need of redecoration and upgrade, if I had paid $100 per night it might just have been acceptable, for $600 it most certainly was not.I would go out of my way not to stay there again

Oct 26 2008 	Classic charm but . . .	Stayed here on business in mid October 2008. I had stayed here a couple of years ago and found it to be a little dreary for its price range. This time my room seemed to have been recently renovated, bringing it more in line with what I expected from its reputation and price range (low $400s per night before taxes). Several things about the hotel bugged me. First, it is a bit of a maze with some elevators not going to all floors. If you have meetings in the hotel this can be frustrating. Probably not a big deal - part of the charm for some. Second, the wallpaper in the bathroom was peeling off and the sink was chipped. Not what I would expect at all at this price range. Third, there was no hot water one morning when I went to take a shower. Definitely not what I would expect. Last, the price of cocktails in the bar was astounding. Two basic cocktails, although excellent, set me back $40, which even for Manhattan seems beyond the pale. Positives were: great location, classic charm in the lobby and public areas, fast bell hop service coming and going, friendly concierge helped with reservations without a pause even a couple of days before we checked in, personal wake up call from a real human being, and nice and quiet rooms, at least on the upper floors.

Oct 25 2008 	Wonderfull old world nyc glamour	I have stayed at the Waldorf Astoria now on 3 occasions....i love the location of this hotel....Park Avenue.Great location for 5th Avenue shopping...although close to all other areas you will deff visit.Hotel rooms are of stardard size for NY....most rooms not very large if you book std rooms.Hotel has a very 'Old World Glamour ' feel with still with all original features from when hotel was first built.I have saw many celebs at this hotel,and watched first hand a hollywood movie being filmed in the lobby!!!

Oct 23 2008 	Did exactly what it said on the tin	Waldorf Astoria. A classic piece of NYC. Had to be done really, as (for now) it was my only visit to NYNY. I am so glad i stayed here. Yes, its not your trendy boutique hotel in the village, but it is a piece of history, and its like living, in a piece of history. Great service from all, had a refrigerator delivered to the room FOC - great for keeping beers in ! - wonderful service from front of house, great bar - who could resist having a manhattan in manhattan !! - just a great place to spend a long weekend. i would recommend it. room was fine, a litlle dated, but what do you expect. everything clean and working order. had great alarm clock with ipod docking station. stole all of the toiletries and stationery, well, you have to don't you !!go there once, for the experience, you won't be disappointed - we weren't !

Oct 23 2008 	Time Warp in a positive way	After a couple of stays in this NYC classic Im very pleased with service and also with rooms provided. Oct 19 2008	Stunning hotel but can find better for the price.	This is a stunning hotel and a piece of NYC history. At $500 a night though i found the grand hyatt to have nicer, larger rooms and the service to be better. The Grand Hyatt usually falls between $350-450 a night.

Oct 19 2008 	Pleasantly Surprised	We stayed at the Waldorf for 4 days last week and, after reading several negative reviews, I have to say that we were pleasantly surprised. I should note that we used our Hilton Honors points to book the room, so it was basically free-- but it was also the lowest category of room that they had available. It was a large (by NYC standards) room with decent furnishings, a nice bathroom, and a great, comfy bed. We've stayed in several other historic/landmark hotels, and I have to say that this one seemed much more cookie-cutter than the others. But, we noticed no musty smells or signs of shabbiness that were reported by some other reviewers. We were notified, after we checked in, that the water system needed maintenance and there would be no water in the guest rooms from midnight until 5 am the next day! This was no problem for us, but I can see how it could have been a major problem for others. Our room had a terrible view of a lower rooftop with utility equipment, but it turned out to be a blessing because we were away from the city traffic noise. The walls are a bit thin, so you tend to hear what's going on in other rooms (honeymooners, please keep this in mind). The hotel staff was pleasant, helpful, and professional. The Waldorf's location is great-- in mid-town, two blocks from Rockefeller Center, with two subway stops nearby on Lexington Ave. There's a lot going on at this hotel... it seemed that every evening there were people milling around the lobby in black-tie attire. You really feel like you're in the center of all the action. Very New York.

Oct 14 2008 	A trip back in time	We celebrated our 10th anniversary at the Waldorf recently booking through the Hilton Honors customer service due to a complex itinerary. First, the lobby, bar area and Bull and Bear restaurant were lovely and did not disappoint. We were upgraded to a suite (two rooms + wet bar room, bath and vanity area) due to my gold status. In this era, when it seems nothing is free, the Waldorf management really came through with a surprise gift of a full size champaign and chocolate dipped strawberries waiting in our room to acknowledge our anniversary. That really meant a lot. Make no mistake, however. The other reviews are on to something. The room just seems to lack pizzazz and/or doesn't seem to convey $500/nt value somehow. Some of that may be that a dollar doesn't go very far in NYC. I stopped to consider what I would ask them to do differently. Unfortunately, the reality may be that staying true to the hotel's history and art deco style may mean living with what feels to some extent like staying in your grandma's living room. If they updated decor to the luxury standards we've come to expect, would it be just another hotel vs. a trip back in time?

Oct 13 2008 	Waldorf fine but shabby in places	I was looking forward to my one night stay at the Waldorf this past weekend. I have to say there were highpoints and low points. The lobby is wonderful. Angel at reception was patient and kind when checking me in early. But my room - 1060 - was not the best. The bed was great and comfy, but the wallpaper was separating and had a few problems. The white curtains were dirty, and the cable tv seemed to be having problems, too, as most of the stations were a little snowy.The service was, however, impeccable from the room service to the maid who turned down my bed to the Bull & Bear and to the guest service managers who handled my complaints about the wall paper, etc. (I hope the room got looked at after I left). I was given free breakfast at Oscar's and $75 off my room price. Yes, things are pricier at the Waldorf ($95 for Sunday brunch) I treated myself to a Waldorf Salad (appetizer size) and a glass of the house champagne which came to $34.00. Room Service for onion soup and hot chocolate was about the same. I enjoyed people watching - no dowagers in tiaras -but several rather formal events were taking place that night at the hotel. Surprised by the lack of doormen at the front to assist with cabs, etc., but on the whole, a pleasant experience. Would I stay again? If I got a good rate again - and I would make sure that I didn't get room 1060.

Oct 4 2008	Does not live up to the reputation	We spent a week here for our honeymoon. We found the experience somewhat lacking. We went straight to check in after a 10 hour flight. The staff were apprehensive about assisting us until, after they served several people before us, they discovered we were staying in a suite and their entire attitude changed. I found that approach mercernary at best. Our room was extremely large, however the bathroom was very small and not terribly moden. The whole hotel gave us the impression that it must have been something in its time but some modernising is needed here. We were on the 27th floor and we still found street noise a problem, however we soon learnt that this is a new york thing and therefore hardly the fault of the hotel. The lifts were not working properly for 2 days while we were there and as we were so high up, taking the stairs was dreadful, especially after walking around the whole of manhattan during the day. Our new york experience was somewhat disappointing all round. We found it a soulless, money hungry city.

Sep 29 2008 	Where's Waldorf?	I broke down and spent the extra $115 per night to take my wife to the Waldorf-Astoria, instead of a cheaper NYC hotel after reading a bad review about that other hotel on TripAdvisor concering bed bugs. The Main Lobby and floor of the Waldorf is opulent, but the room I was in was significantly less so. The room I stayed in was nothing too special, and lacked features you would expect in a high class hotel. There was no flat screen television, no t.v in the bathroom, the queen sized bed was too small, and the lighting was poor. Don't get me wrong, it was a nice hotel room. But, I expected great and was disappointed. There always seemed to be a bustle in the main lobby comprised of well dressed foreignors and corporate types. The best thing about this hotel is its lobby and location. The hotel is situated in easy walking distance to mid-town sites and is surrounded by impressive buildings. As NYC mid-town hotels are un-godly expensive, the Waldorf was actually a fairly good bargain. My room, unfortunately, was near the elevator shafts, so I keep hearing the swoosh of elevator cables all night while I was trying to sleep. That's my fault for trusting the reception staff to pick my room, because I went with the cheaper option of having my room selected for me upon arrival.

Sep 26 2008 	Great stay	We began our honeymoon in New York, at the Waldorf Astoria and it was really great! There was a bottle of champagne with strawberries waiting for us and the room (a deluxe one with queen bed) was very spacious and clean. The hotel is huge and very charming. The position is very comfortable. The staff was very king and helped us when we had some troubles with our luggage. In a word: marvellous! I hope I'll able to visit it again sooner or later!

Sep 23 2008 	Great Hotel	We were recently very lucky to spend one night in the Waldorf, thanks to my sister & brother-in-law booking us in with their Hilton points. We had a great king size superior room on corner of hotel - more like a suite as it had separate dressing room. I liked the old decor and charm, the room was very comfortable and by far the most luxurious we've ever stayed in. It was also the largest. There were so many cupboards and wardrobes - our meagre overnight bag looked very lost! The housekeeper was very attentive with regards to making sure we were happy with everything in our room.We used the Starbucks for snack on arrival and the Bull & Bear for cocktails before going out in the evening. We had emailed the hotel a few days in advance re menus as my husband has special dietery requirements but unfortunately they didn't bother to reply - so we didn't eat there.We also found that the hot water supply in the room wasn't that great.Neverthless, we did enjoy our overnight stay there and thought it was very grand hotel.

Sep 20 2008 	Historic and unique but aging	I stayed at the Waldorf and found it charming and authentic, but it does show its age. The Waldorf service is top notch, with lots of extremely helpful staff at the ready at all times. Great food, location, and fitness center as well. Starbucks in the lobby - yay! The accommodations are not necessarily as deluxe as you might expect at this price point (more than $700/night) - the bathroom in my suite was tiny, with only a pedestal sink and a shower/tub combo. I could not open the shampoo bottle to save my life, and outlets were hard to find. On the upside, though, the towels, sheets and robes are fabulous, I loved the alarm clock with the iPod docking station, and the view of the Chrysler building out my window was priceless. On the whole it is a treat to stay there, but don't expect flat screen TVs, jetted tubs or updated fixtures. The place has character!

Sep 16 2008 	Fantastic	We stayed at the Waldorf back in 2004 when we got married and it was truly wonderful. Very glamorous, admittedly a faded glamour but this only added to the charm. The hotel really enhanced our New York experience and the staff were very kind to us, upgrading us to a room with fantastic views of the Chrysler building and sending strawberries dipped in chocolate and a bottle of Champagne up to our room on our wedding night. Sep 13 2008 	Historic Hotel	We stayed in a small double bed room on the 14th floor and even though we had a bad view from our window, our room was comfortable, clean and elegantly decorated. The only small problem was it seemed as though we would occassionally hear a banging and scraping noise coming from the rooms above.The staff was very helpful and eager to please.I would also suggest eating breakfast around the corner since it is Very expensive eating there.

Sep 10 2008 	A piece of NY history!	This hotel is pure New York history, I have always wanted to stay here and being a huge movie fan I was fascinated by this hotel! The hotel has displays about its heritage which are very interesting and just walking around with all the old money clientele is an experience in itself!The location is great for getting to 5th Avenue and to all the NY tourist attractions via the subway which is very cheap and convenient or via the open top bus tour which I highly recommend as it stops outside, is really good value and lots of fun plus you hop on and off at any attraction you want!Also go to Central Park for a full day, there is a lot to see and do and its bigger than you think!The hotel staff were very friendly and we were given free champagne as we were on our honeymoon! The Bull and Bear do the best steak I have ever eaten and I recommend going to Gordon Ramseys restaurant at The London also. New York is amazing!

Sep 8 2008 	Loved it!	The Waldorf was not cheap but it was worth it. The hotel is as grand as I had imagined it to be. We stayed in a basic room (no upgrade) but it was still fantastic. The room was a comfortable size, the black out drapes were great, the marble bathroom was lovely. All in all, it was the perfect luxury hotel experience. I have never enjoyed a hotel stay more, I didn't want to leave the room!

Sep 7 2008 	Corner Suite	I've stayed at the Waldorf=Astoria four or five times over the past two years. As a Hilton Diamond VIP, this is my preferred Hilton full-service property in NYC. The separate check-in lounge for Diamonds, just to the left of the looooooong registration desk, is a nice touch.The Waldorf is truly an historic gem, rich with period details. I booked a one bedroom suite for $529 and received an upgrade to corner suite 13-A (yes, they have a 13th floor). A nice room with non-working fireplace in the living room, crystal sconces, small but nice marble bath, and a very comfortable bedroom with walk-in closet, suite 13-A overlooks St. Bart's.Room service was prompt and very cordial. The housekeeping staff were pleasant and attentive. Bathroom amenities were on a par with the Four Seasons.Peacock Alley is a great spot for lunch or cocktails. Kenny's gives an upscale men's haircut in a private salon, for a price (about $125). Avoid the Bull & Bear - if you want a steak, go out on the town.If you love historic hotels, you won't be disappointed at the Waldorf.

Sep 3 2008 	Just like the movies	The Waldorf Astoria is everything you'd expect from a 5 star New York City Hotel. Absolute luxury and first class service.Personally speaking, the location is a little too tourist friendly but I can't fault the hotel. The service was fantastic.

Sep 3 2008 	Wowie Waldorf	I used Trip Advisor to review a number of hotels prior to booking for my stay in NYC. I just wanted to enjoy the stay

Aug 29 2008 	Out of this World!!!	I stayed at this hotel last year and I chose it because it was my first time in New York and after hearing about the Waldorf and seeing it in so many movies I just had to see it for myself!I was not disappointed!!My friends and I hired a Limo to take us to the hotel as we thought we may as well as it really didnt cost that much (about 30 each for a return trip for 3 of us) the limo pulled into the underground car park of the waldorf and we were greated by a staff member who immediately loaded our luggage on to a trolley and guided us to the reception desk to check in, this was very quick!!He then showed us to our hotel room (2 double bed deluxe room). The room was beautiful!!!! very spacious we had a corner room and had a view of park ave, you really feel in the heart of the city! The room looked so nice i was afraid to touch anything and was very warm and inviting compared to some hotel rooms now that feel quite impersonal and clinical! The bathroom was very clean, great shower (nothing worse that a shower that has no power in it) and overall a great standard!!I also found the staff to be fantastic! I went to the shop within the waldorf to buy a sewing kit as I found I had a hole in my jumper the hotel staff offered to have it fixed FOR FREE!! Overall the staff were so helpful!! Ive never been to a hotel where i've felt so well looked after! from beginning to end this hotel is truely an experience and yes it can be expensive but if you can afford it or can save really hard like I did haha its well worth it! We ordered room service on our last morning which was so much fun just to have done it i think it was $25 each and all silver service i would deffinately do it just to treat yourself!The staff were perfect! The room was perfect! The door man was so friendly i loved staying there just because it was so nice talking to him in the morning, the staff are a credit to this hotel.I really hope I can stay here again, i give this hotel 11 out of 10!I think if anyone has found fault with this hotel they are very very very hard to please!!

Aug 27 2008 	Fantastic stay at the Waldorf	We have just returned from staying at the Waldorf Astoria and had a wonderful time. We were apprehensive after reading some of the recent reviews but every fear was unfounded. On arrival at the hotel, we had to enter via the car park which was disappointing, but the doormen don't like airport shuttle buses parked outside the front entrance.We found our way to the lobby with our cases and checked in within five minutes. The staff were friendly and asked if we needed help with our luggage but we declined, knowing that it might not arrive quickly.When we entered our room we were very impressed with the size and the decor was traditional and well maintained. We had e-mailed a few days previously to ask for the best room possible at our rate and also stated that it was our anniversary, so arrived to find a bottle of champagne and a plate of chocolate covered strawberries with a note wishing us a pleasant stay.The airconditioning was effective, the room was clean, and the maids provided a turndown service each night. We were on the 27th floor and had good views towards the East River and Park Avenue.We did not intend to eat at the hotel knowing that the prices were high, so have no complaints about the cost. We did drink in Harry's bar and ,although quite expensive, I am sure that we could have found other hotels nearby with the same prices.The hotel itself was beautiful, and if you take the time to walk around and explore, you can imagine what it must have been like in its heyday. The grand ballroom and silver corridor were especially magnificent.The location of the hotel is great as you are within easy walking distance of most of the main attractions but do not have to put up with the constant hustle and bustle of somewhere like Times SquareWe had no problems buying food nearby and ate in places varying from the cheap Viennese deli on Lexington towards the Chrysler building, to the Oyster bar in Grand Central Station, and the View restaurant 48 floor up in the Marriott Marquis hotel in Times Square.We also would recommend taking the Gray Line bus tours from the 49th street side of the hotel. We had 72 hour passes and these included all routes and tickets to the Empire State Building and the Statue of Liberty. There are street vendors everywhere but we bought ours at the hotel ticket desk. We experienced prompt attention and good service with no queues.We went to the Statue of Liberty via the bus and although it took some time to get there, the tour was very interesting. The queue to the boat was long but moved very quickly and we only waited half an hour. We did not get off the boat but you can disembark at Liberty Island and Ellis Island if you wish.We went to the Empire State building when it opened at 0830hrs as recommended by the hotel staff, and walked straight through with no waiting and no crowding on the viewing platform. Later in the day queues form outside and around the building.Returning to the hotel after a busy day was always a pleasure and the sheer opulence of walking through the lobby and not being in a brand new 'chain' hotel with no history was lovely.Staying at the Waldorf Astoria does not have to be that expensive and to be in such beautiful surroundings only enhanced our stay in New York.The staff were always friendly, helpful and easy to approach.We hope to return to New York and stay in the Waldorf Astoria again.

Aug 22 2008	A Grand Dame	In today's world of Holiday Inn's, Courtyards, etc. it's always a pleasure and a treat to take a step back in time and bask in the glory of a time gone by.After reading some of the posts, it made me wonder if I was the only one to appreciate this landmark hotel. I took in all the glitz and glamor the hotel could offer. Our hallway was adorned with photos of those celebrities caught in the moment of being in the Ballroom, at dinner, and the likes. I wish I had more time to stroll the other hallways and gaze upon moments preserved forever. My daughter and I were in the city for one night, to attend a cooking demonstration at the Astor Center on E4th St. We were able to take the subway, just around the corner from the hotel, and be in the SOHO District in 10 minutes, and I think it only cost $4 for the round trip. We took the train into the city, so we didn't have to deal with driving/parking, because it is a nightmare!We were upgraded to a suite, offered a choice of continental breakfast or 2 cocktails at any of the 4 bars at the hotel and 2 bottles of water --being an Hilton Honors member does have it's priveldges :)Our 2 room suite was huge...a small entryway, large 'coat' closet, fireplace in the living room area, another huge (7x5ft) walk in closet in the sleeping area. I felt extremely spoiled having the room we had..we were on the 9th floor of a 26 floor hotel. They do have a club level. Water pressure and temperature were just fine. 2 tv's, mini-bar (always outrageous prices with mini-bars, but they are fun to see what's in them!) We were at the end of the hallway so I never heard any noise...but being in the city is loud..constant traffic, horns, sirens, but that is all part of what makes NYC the best city in the world! NYC is expensive, so be prepared...We had drinks at the Peacock bar and just watched the world go by. Our drinks were complimented by 2 little dishes of marinated olives and espresso dusted almonds...thank you Nick and Michael for your attentiveness, you're great mixologists! Even at 10pm there were people, lots of people checking in, checking out, the front desk was always busy when we walked by, and we were there on a Monday. I loved hearing the clock chime. There is so much history in the hotel--enjoy it while you can, and if you can, be grateful that you were able to....

Aug 19 2008 	Don't Waste Your Money	I have been to NYC on many occasions. I have stayed at some WONDERFUL places like the Carlyle, Ritz Carlton and Affinia Dumont. On this trip, we didn't want to spend that much money on accomodations as it was only for one night. However, I was traveling with someone who really wanted to stay at the Waldorf. We found some very reasonable rates online (around $350). We drive into the parking area for Valet. When you first drive in, it seems very nice. We waited about 15 minutes just to pull the car up and get the bags out. No one helped us with our bags. This is not a big deal, as we are certainly capable of carrying our own bags, but I certainly expected better service from The Waldorf.We finally get inside and found it a bit hard to find where to find the lobby. Not a big concern.We get to the lobby, which is indeed very nice, but certainly an older hotel. We then found a large row of registration desks. We found an even longer line to check in. Standing on line with our bags for about 10 minutes or so. Again, not what I would come to expect of a hotel. I have received better service at the Marriott.There are a large array of people staying at the hotel. We get to our room and it is a good size for a superior room. The hotel, it's obvious is older and the renovations don't appear to have helped. Upon going to the restroom, I walk out and notice that I am actually walking downhill from the bathroom to the main room. There is a slope in the floor in our room.The bathroom and the bedroom were spacious. The bathroom had been renovated, but it seemed more like a 'face-lift'. The sheets on the bed were ok and the towels in the bathroom were good as well.Getting a cab from the Park Street entrance was a nightmare. The front door men seemed really lazy and there was always a line of people waiting for a cab. Not to mention the bike riders constantly asking if you want a ride. It's NY, so it's ok. The staff would try and move them to the side, but they always seemed to be in the way of cabs and cars. It was easier to walk a block down and flag a cab myself.The restaurant took a very long time to get seated for breakfast, which was odd considering there were only 4 people eating at the time. The food was ok, the bloody mary was terrible and overall WAY too expensive. Would have been MUCH better to hit a deli.Location is ok, but there are many other great and reasonably priced hotels in the area that would be worth your time. Don't waste your time staying here.

Aug 18 2008	Old elegance in need if some renewing	When you enter the Waldorf-Astoria, you are greeted by the lobby's obvious opulence and beauty (though if you arrived by car, you will first notice the complete disorganization of the parking in the driveway which runs through the middle of the building - there is luggage everywhere.. it looked like when American Airlines' baggage system broke down).As you roam the halls and arrive at your room, you'll notice that things aren't exactly as elegant as they once were. This seems to be a pattern at the older, more historic hotels. They rely a bit too much on their historical value, but don't seem to be reinvesting any of their hefty price tag on updating or upkeep. There are lots of walls that have been patched over (and not patched well), our room had holes in the wall where a headboard had previously been drilled or a painting previously sat, peeling wallpaper, a curtain hook that was coming off the wall, and other signs of age. Everything was otherwise clean. The bathroom was probably the part of the room in the best condition, though the shower head was starting to rust, and the shower faucet had references to a button that needed to be depressed but there was now only a hole. I was also surprised that our room had an old CRT television.. I'd expect flat screens at a hotel of this caliber at this point in time.I would also say that while this isn't really important to me, I was surprised at the level of service. I don't think I saw a single door man, and staff seems to be mostly in the lobby area only. Overall, no major problems or complaints - the hotel just doesn't live up to its name, reputation or price tag.

Aug 13 2008	Really disappointing	This is a grand old hotel, and the lobby and public spaces don't disappoint. Our room, however, did. Cramped, dark, with no place to sit comfortably and relax (except on the bed or at the desk), with a view of some sort of shaft. In order to tell if the sky was blue or gray, we had to crane our necks up from the corner of the window. The concierge staff was helpful if you could get to them; there were always a lot of people waiting in line at their desks and at the front desk. The cleaning staff was friendly and did a good job.If the hotel cost less, one would take these inconveniences in stride, but when paying so much, one expects more. For less money, I think I would in future book a nicer room at, for instance, the Helmsley on Central Park South. Better location and you wouldn't feel depressed every time you returned from touring.P.S. When, in answer to a question about my stay, I indicated my disappointment while checking out a friendly person at the desk gave me her name and said she would see I got a nice room next time I came. I probably won't take her up on it.

Aug 12 2008 	Not Great. For that price there are so many other hotels to choose from.	We just returned from a trip to New York City. Aug 8 2008 	Loved the Waldorf Astoria New York City	We have just returned from stay at the Waldorf Astoria. The hotel is magnificent and we have never experienced such incredible service before. This is absolutely the best hotel we have ever stayed in on any vacation. The entire staff went out of their way to help us with any need. Every one was helpful and friendly. The door man remembered my 7 year old son and called him by name every time that we entered the hotel. We will return to this hotel on our next visit to New York.

Aug 8 2008 	Do not stay during a heat wave	Overall the hotel is clean. Our room seems to have been updated based on other review. The bath room and room are a bit on the small side but this is NYC. They are big for NYC. I have stayed at other hotels in the city with smaller rooms. The room was cleaned every day and even had a turn down service.My issue with the Waldorf was that nothing seemed to run smoothly. Maybe my expectations were too high. We checked in at 11 am and were told our room was not available. This was no big deal and expected. We were asked to give them a cell phone number and they would call. We were also told not to stand in line when we returned since all we needed to do is big up keys. I should also mention that we were using Hilton Points to stay at the hotel and were in the city for a wedding. We left the hotel and went to entertain ourselves in the city. At 4:30, we decided we should head back since we had to be at the wedding rehearsal at 7pm. It was over 100 degrees in the city that weekend and needed to shower before the event. When we arrived at the hotel we went were we told to go at 11 am. A woman working for the hotel came over and said we needed to stand in the check in line. After explaining our situation she said we still need to stand in the line; which had over 10 people in it. Oh, I have forgotten to mention I am Hilton Gold. After a 20 minute wait, we got to someone to help us. We were told that we had been upgraded to a nicer room but it still wasnt available at 5:30pm. At which point, I told her I had to be somewhere at 7pm and needed to shower ASAP. She left to go speak to a peer. 15 minutes later we were given a room key. We were told it was just a normal room and to make it up to us they would give us drinks at one of the hotel bars. At this point, I was more worried about making the rehearsal. We were told our bags would be sent up.After 30 more minutes our bags finally arrived. The room was extremely hot. The bell boy told us they dont keep the AC on in the rooms. He showed us how to work it and left. We were in the room for only 45 minutes before we left as well. The room was as hot as when we got into it.When we got home at 2am the room had not cooled down at all. However, since it was so late and we were exhausted we decided not to worry about it.The next day we went to the front desk and they said they didnt have any other rooms at that time but could move us later in the day around 6pm. The wedding was at 5pm and that was not going to work. They said they would send maintenance up to the room and see what was wrong. That night it didnt feel any cooler. The next day we noticed the entire hotel was warm. In the long run I do not think there was anything wrong with the AC. I believe the Waldorf is an old hotel with an old AC system that can not handle a 100 degree heat wave.On our last day we checked out and stored our bags at the hotel. When we came back to get them at 4pm, it took over 45 minutes to get them. The bell boy even expected us to tip him. FOR WHAT! Thankfully, our car service understood and we still made our flight with plenty of time.Some other issues were that neither our tub nor sink drained properly. Additionally, the mini bar smelled like something had died in it. The smell was terrible. Thankfully, we only opened it once to get our Hilton Gold Gift-bottle water. I did mention this to the maid in the halls. She said she would clean it. I do not know if it was done since I didnt want to risk opening it again. PEWWW!!!We also had a few drinks with friends at Sir Harrys in the Waldorf. The service was terrible. We hit it at a lull so I would expect some slowness but we both had to ask for our bill and then also walk it up to someone to get it run after waiting 20 minutes for her to pick it back up.Unfortunately, my experience didnt get any better once I got home. My bill was $0 since I was using Hilton points for my stay. The Hilton website confirms. However, once I got my credit card statement I had 3 charges on my statement from the Waldorf. One for $16.10; one for $8.70 and one for $1578.00. I have been on the phone with the Waldorf and they plan to credit my card back for all the charges. It is just a hassle to deal with in the first place.I am glad that I got to experience the Waldorf. If I was paying for the hotel, I would go somewhere else. There are plenty of hotels in NYC that do a better job and have better service. The name isnt worth what they are charging and for what you get. Once you get out of the lobby the rooms are the same as any other Hilton, DoubleTree, or Marriott. There is nothing special in the rooms themselves.

Aug 7 2008	Never again	We arrived at 6PM with a reservation for an executive king.When we attempted to check in, we were offered a room with a defective TV but they offered us free movie. When we arrived we found it was an ordinary room. We called down and asked if the room we reserved was not available, why had we been downgraded instead of upgraded.We told them we were furious for being lied to at the reception, downgraded without a discount and unsatisfied, We were tired of arguing and accepted their offer after a half hour of haggling of $100 per night and a bottle of champagne.Our luggage took 45 minutes to arrive. Aug 6 2008 	Nice hotel	This hotel is not modern, its a classic piece of New York's history. The lobby is beautiful, the staff are great and the rooms are nice. All the staff that we encountered in our 5 day trip were pleasant, seemed to enjoy their jobs and were very nice and patient. I'd stay here again in a heartbeat. Our room was very clean, very comfortable. The walls are a little thin so you can hear the odd tv or person but it is to be expected in such an old hotel. The cleaning staff were great, offering privacy when needed and the turn down service was very nice.We stayed there just to experience it and it was worth it.

Aug 5 2008 	Classy hotel infrastructure old rooms	I spent a night at the hotel with my girldriend.When you see the historical building and even more when you enter in the hotel you are absolutely stunned!Fantastic lampadar and lobby with a historical watch in the middle of the lobby.When you pass the elevators you start getting aware of the age of the hotel. The elevators are old and slow, the corridors or nothing special and the rooms have nice beds and desk but not all rooms are newly refurnished. The air conditioning is still very old and smelly.The view from the 7th floor was nice with a view of the Rockefeller center. Nothing special compared to other hotels like Hilton Times Square.Worth a visit but happy to have spent there only one night just for the historical importance of the building.

Aug 4 2008	Enjoyed the Waldorf...Just Know What You Are Getting	Spent a week at the Waldorf Astoria and had a great time. Reviews are split on opposite ends, so I will try to enlighten anyone considering this hotel.First of all, you pay a hefty premium at the WA because it is historic, has a famous lobby, etc. The rooms are large and the hotel displays old world class. Also, a friendly maid was always in the hall if you needed anything. The hotel is kept very clean despite its age. Hotel service was always friendly, but, due to the size of this hotel and its many occupants, you often had to wait a while to get a cab, talk to the concierge, etc.As for the drawbacks, there was some cracking paint above the shower in the bathroom, but nothing major. Don't expect a flat-screen t.v, swimming pool, vending machines, free internet or gym facilities at the WA. I did feel the hotel "nickle and dimed" its guests somewhat considering the premium paid for the hotel (i.e. - $10/day for internet and $15/day to work out in their gym). As for location, there is a subway stop across the street and you can easily get to 5th Avenue and Madison Avenue shopping in a few minutes. However, it is pretty good hike (15 minutes at least) to Times Square/Broadway by foot or about a $10 cab ride. If you are going to visit those areas daily, consider a closer hotel. It does have a Starbucks in the lobby, but there is also one every 50 yards in Midtown (including across the street at 50th and Lexington), so no big deal.Bottom line, I am glad I stayed here just to say I did, but would stay closer to either Times Square or Central Park next time because I spent most of my time there and didn't eat in any of the hotel restaurants (Midtown has great restaurants every 30 feet, try them). Since you know you are paying a premium for this hotel, just know that the premium is in return for a stay in a historic hotel that people recognize for its class. If you want more modern amenities closer to the 'around the clock' action in Manhattan, you can spend much less elsewhere.

Aug 2 2008 	Does not deliver	We wanted to stay here to soak up the ambience and history. We have stayed in historical properties before so we knew the rooms would be small and possible a bit dated. What we did not expect was a smelly, poorly furnished, boiling hot room with dirt everywhere. We were totally shocked. The room had a beat up old air conditioner that did not not work the two of the three days we were there. It was filthy. The bathroom was horrid with some sort of drywall bits and other dirt in every nook and cranny. The bathroom ventalation system looked to be about 30 years old (and never cleaned). It made a tremendous noise but seemed to move no air.We called the front desk about the problems. They repeatedly apologized and then did nothing. We asked for a new room to no avail. This was the rare occassion when we dreaded our return from a day of shopping and sight seeing.Just to top it off, we had a view of the top of the roof between two wings which was a bloody mess! I took a picture (which is on another computer so I may get around to uploading it along with the shot the air conditioner I also took) it was so funny/sad. It looked like what you see driving down a back alley in a poorer neighborhood.The public areas are great. They were everything we expected. The food was, sadly, very poor. The drinks were great. The staff were very good too.Having just come from the Michelangelo (at $100 a night cheaper and a much, much better room), this was a real let down. Never again...all the nice places in the hotel are public and you can enjoy it without being subjected to the rooms!

Jul 31 2008 	Waldorf Times	Recently spend 3 nights at the Waldorf and we would compliment the hotel on a very good central location. Public areas were traditional and well maintained. Our guest room although quite big, was a little tired in style and presentation which was disappointing given the hotel's historical standing in the city.
