If we had only stayed on a Saturday and Sunday, our nightly rates would have been a good bit less.????Hotel expensive to dine it.Lots of good eateries nearby at a fraction of the cost.......also, down town open top tourist bus stops right outside the hotel.......worthwhile to get your bearings.

Jul 31 2008 	Disappointing	I was realy looking forward to visiting the Waldorf Astoria, but was very disappointed. The rooms we were given were poky and in need of a change of decor, the bathroom was tiny and there was a very odd smell in the room. Our outlook was on to another wing of the hotel, so we often looked out to see other people staring at us from their rooms.Windows could not be opened, so the stale smell stayed the whole week.One night I threw the heavy top cover off as I was so hot and found what looked like blood on the inside, I told the chambermaid the next day, and even though there was a clean one put on the bed that night, there was no word of apology.As I went with my son, we requested rooms close together, he ended up down the corridor and round the corner, his room also had a funny smell and was just as poky as mine.I had expected more from this hotel, having read so much about it.I would definately NOT return as there are many more modern, and cleaner hotels to choose from in New York.The only good thing I can say about it was it was nicely situated, breakfast was chaotic, and staff very poor.Love New York, hate the Waldorf.

Jul 29 2008 	Loved Waldorf Astoria	Stayed here nov 07 was a bit unsure after reading the reviews on this site but have to say it was a wounderful stay.Had mini suit was newly refurbished view was out the back of the hotel but wasn't in the room often only to sleep so wasn't that bothered.It was thanksgiving weekend so was very very bussy, would stay there again.

Jul 29 2008 	Better than what we expected but not 100% amazed.	Took a long weekend to stay here with husband, who is a Diamond HH member (we paid for the hotel, so this wasn't a reward stay).Upon arrival, I was expecting a grander entrance to the hotel, instead it was a small revolving door, and a couple of heavy push doors that would not fit a wide suitcase through, and a 50m walk to the lobby. This is not necessarily a criticism, just that I was expecting the lobby/reception area to be visible upon entrance. In saying that, everything was very grand, and there was a beautful bouquet of flowers, probably the largest I have ever seen, on display in the lobby area.The room was very large for NYC, some may call the rooms dated, but I would say that the Waldorf is trying to keep the decor looking grand and classical as opposed to the minimalist style. I thought it was quite nice. There are modern touches like flatscreen TVs, and the radio which accepts ipods.The bathroom was clean and tidy, everything was marble effect. Toiletries felt like good quality.The main cons:Breakfast $25Gym $15/day - unless you use the Guilane spa. I was extremely dissapointed that not even Diamond HH members could use the gym facilities!!Pros:cleanswanky - people will awe when you say you're staying at the Waldorf!great location - steps away from Madonson/5th ave, but also great neighbourhood/local eateries and bars if you take a stroll down 3rd.extremely comfortable bed & pillows.If you're looking for a weekend packed full of activities, and hardly anytime in the bedroom, then the waldorf is probably not worth it, but otherwise its worth a visit on the weekend when rates are lower.

Jul 25 2008 	Waldorf doesn't live up to reputation	My wife and I stayed four nights for business as a part of a large group. Excellent midtown location with the subway immediately across the street to the left on the Lexington entrance. Very good Redstone Pizza, Duane Read Pharmacy, and a liquor store are three blocks to the right down Lexington. Morrell Wine Bar is a great place to people watch the Rockefeller crowds a few blocks away.The Waldorf lobby, common meeting areas, and restaurants still convey a grand old school appeal. The peeling paint in the bedroom bathroom and the non flat screen TV's should be improved. Service was hit or miss when the staff could or could not manage the crowds. The front desk manager was excellent at handling a stressful checkin, while an undertasked bartender at the Bull and Bear was lazy and unattentive. This is a BIG hotel, and there are so many good hotels in the area. I wouldn't stay here unless the price was right or my company was paying again.

Jul 24 2008 	Nice hotel but GREAT location	Stayed in the Waldorf in July 2008 for one week with my mum and sister as a shopping trip and chance to meet with family who live in NYC.On arrival our luggage was taken care of quickly and we were taken to reception rahter than just being directed. Check in didnt go according to plan as when we booked we booked two interconnecting rooms (these were promised by travel agent) On check in there were no interconnecting rooms left although it worked out in the end as the single room was offered on the 17th floor (smoking rooms only) which one of our party wanted.Rooms were big - our room had two double beds, walk in wardrobe (great for the shopping bags) although it did have a small bathroom. We experienced problems with the shower.. you have to run it for over 15 mins before any hot water. My sister complained once and was given breakfast vouchers (which we didnt use) but the water was never fixed properly. Housekeeping okay - turndown service didnt happen every night and when you wanted towels changed they hung up your used ones again so we called down a few times for fresh towels. The room has a/c which you cant turn down lower than 63. Rooms look like they could do with a facelift but hey how long are you spending in your room.We used the Theatre and Tours desk within the hotel to book a show (Chorus Line) Richard on the desk was very helpful and got us great seats. The Concerige desk was again very helpful especially when it came to plotting all the shops we wanted to go on a map! No problems getting a taxi outside the hotel.. although for those who have not been to NYC before like me.. their taxi drivers always ask for a full address of where you are going!!!Theres a Starbucks in the ground floor of hotel which is pricey compared to the starbucks out and about but ideal very first thing in the morning.Hotel has all different types of guests... we saw wedding parties, business persons and tourists.. the hotel does say it has a dress code for lobby areas but we wore shorts etc and noone said anything.The best thing with this hotel is the location. A pleasant 15min walk to Times Square/Tiffanys/Bloomingdales/Grand Central Station its perfect.We wanted to have a late checkout as our flight wasnt till late at night.. when we called down to first ask we were told 75 dollars per hour so we werent going to bother. On the day we were going home we called again and were told first hour free then 35 dollars per hour so another warning... always check again! We also had mini bar charges on final account which we had not used so again check your bill before you leave.All in all a lovely hotel with its amazing lobby and history but personally I prefer a more modern hotel and if I was returning I would find one but ensure it be close to the waldorf as location was great.

Jul 20 2008 	Over-rated	Gorgeous lobby then it goes downhill. For the price paid, there are much nicer hotels in the vicinity - the rooms are very old fashioned - and I dont mean quaint! We had trouble getting hot water via the shower - tip - let the tap run for at least 15 minutes then turn to shower mode. There is a on-site Starbucks but the prices are quite hefty - tip - loads of Starbucks outside and charges are much cheaper. The staff are very helpful but on checking out, noticed we had all been charged for using the mini bar (we couldnt even open ours!) - not a problem though, the charges were immediately taken off. Remember to check your bill before leaving. There is a dress code in certain parts of the hotel but we had no problems wearing shorts and tshirts as were many others, bearing in mind this hotel is also hugely used weddings, business conferences,etc. All in all a fantastic stay in New York but would definetely stay in a more contemporary hotel.

Jul 19 2008	rob and vivs 40th birthday in the waldorf	stayed in the waldorf astoria in march with my girlfriend for our 40th birthday what a hotel. the staff were so helpful what you would expect from a top class hotel .the room was really nice and the bed was so comftable with those triple folded down sheets never slept in a bed like it.if you go out the lexington entrance the are plenty of places for breckfast .a good tip if you suffer from astma you can e mail them and they will supply astma sheets . unless your going to drink out of the mini bar leave the stuff inside alone because as soon as you lift something out it registers on your bill . you can book in online from the buisness suite in the lobby for free for your return flight home the staff are more than helpful.if you want to see a broadway show go to the booking office of the theatre the day before or on the day you can get seats at half price we did at the winter garden went to watch mama mia the seats where 3 rows from the front and the show was fantastic.. if you go to macys shopping as for a discount card in the shop visitors get a 11% discount .have a go at the helicopter flight you will enjoy it we did and a good tip if your going to visit ground zero or liberty island its all in the same area so worth planning we did the helicopter flight then went to ground zero, . all of the starbucks have wi fi so just buy a drink and surf away on your laptop.just a last thing we felt safe all the time in new york night and day even on the subway and we are going back

Jul 19 2008 	Fantastic!	This hotel has the most beautiful lobby of any otel Ive ever stayed in and although my room, paid for with Hilton Reward points collected over 7 years of almost constant business travelling, was tiny and overlooked the service area of the hotel, who cares? Its a great place to base a stay in NYC if you can afford it (which I normally cant!). The beds were incredibly comfortable and the staff, except for one depressingly surly breakfast waiter were great.

Jul 19 2008	This place is a dump	This place is totally resting on its laurels. Our room was large, which was about the only good point. The carpet was filthy. There were no slippers so I had to request them. They probably haven't done a thorough renovation of the room since 1970. There were layers and layers of paint on the bathroom door, closet doors, and on moulding, whch also had a nice big piece of blue painters tape stuck to it. The furnishings were tired - there was a hole in one of the lampshades. The bed itself was nice as were the sheets, but the decorative pillows and stuff were practically threadbare. The marble/granite was nice in the bathroom, but you could tell the tub had been refinished about a 50 times. There were a few layers peelng off around the drain. Can't complain about the price since we used Hilton points to stay here but if I were paying anything close to the rack rate, I'd be very annoyed. No way would I stay here again - there are so many nice hotels in NY why waste it on a has been?

Jul 18 2008 	Loved it!	Having read the reviews, I must admit I was a bit apprehensive about staying here with my family, particularly given the comments on the condition of some of the rooms from many previous visitors. However, from the second we arrived until the very second we left the Waldorf, the service was excellent. It was my son's 15th birthday whilst we were in NY and I wanted to make it a special occasion. I had e-mailed the Waldorf a few days in advance explaining this and requested a nice room with a view. We were not disappointed. We had a large room (there were 4 of us) with a separate dressing room and bathroom facilities all in very good condition with an excellent view over Park Ave. The Waldorf even sent my son a personal card, some fine bottled water and exclusive chocolates for his birthday. The hotel is something special and people who plan to stay here must remember it is not a modern hotel, This is quite simply its appeal. The reception areas are stunning and the scent from the wonderful flower arrangements is simply lovely. The staff were always extremely helpful and curteous and made you feel very welcome. This is a truly special hotel which offers character and a bit of history which undoubtedly is its charm. I would have no hesit ation in recommending this hotel to anyone.

Jul 12 2008	Loved the Waldorf	After reading all the negative reviews about the waldorf I was hesitant to stay. We used points for our first trip there in October 2007 and were delighted with our room, service, tour desk... everything. We returned in May and our room was outrageously large for NY - with huge closet, large bathroom with seperate shower and bath, and a seperate sitting area. I love the classic elegance of the hotel and I must say we loved the Waldorf.

Jul 11 2008 	There are better options.....	Converted Hilton points for my stay so did not pay. Room was very small. By the time we removed decorative pillows and bedspread walking aroudn the room was severely limited. Bathroom very nice. Air conditioner was marginal at best. If it had been warmer outside the A/C would not have been sufficient. Public spaces are gorgeous. For a nearly 80 yr old building it was very well conditioned. Service was fine. I have stayed at the Hilton NY (Ave of Americas) and for the same # of points could have stayed there and had a better room and a better location. It's a great tourist spot but there are better rooms and locations for the money in NYC.

Jul 10 2008 	Pleased with the Waldorf-Astoria	Be booked at the Waldorf-Astoria since this is such a well known and famous hotel, but we were not very certain after reading some of these mixed reviews. We decided to book an "executive room" (or whatever they call it) to make sure not to end up in one of the smaller rooms. When arriving we were sent to the "VIP" check in because all receptionists were busy. We were seated in this kind of office got a very helpful and nice check in from the lady behind the desk. The room was not ready (as we arrived a bit early), but they would call us when the room was ready. The bell boy took our luggage and we went out to get something to eat. The only bad thing is that the stairs leading from the Park Avenue entrance is quite difficult when you have a lot of luggage. The public rooms are all simply gorgeous and grand like other reviewers tell. No need to repeat the story. After one hour they called and the room was ready. Our room were on the 15th floor with an amazing view of Park Avenue and the church next door. The room were very spacious! Not only for a New York hotel room but in general. The hallways and all public areas are all spacious at this hotel. They were probably not so space efficient in the old days. Large and clean marble bathroom. No peeling paint or dirty ventilation shafts. Very comfortable bed. Clean. Walk-in-closet with iron and iron board. Nice furnishing allthough they could have put in an extra lounge chair or something. The room was not new and not in perfect shape, but it was "nicely worn" and quite acceptable. I think some floors are renovated later than our floor but we were pleased with our room. Very old kind of style, but this is not a trendy boutique hotel. Not over the top luxurious but comfortabel and good size. I think that people have to have in mind that this is a very old hotel and not modern and completely up to date as new hotels would be. However this is much of the charm. If they gutted the entire hotel to make it all trendy and fancy it would not be the same. It would probably end up as a "Las Vegas old style hotel."The bar next to the lobby and the elevators is a very nice place for drinks. Wonderful and helpful staff. The people working in the bar is of "the old school" and have maybe been working there for their entire lives. The bar in the Park Avenue lobby with live piano music is nice for late cocktails before going out to dine. We ordered room service one day we were to tired to go out, and it didn't take long for the food to arrive. Very efficient. Good service and good food. The last morning of our stay we came home at 6am after some really hard clubbing. We were drunk and probably a bit shabby. They let us keep the room for 3 extra hours without any charge. Very nice of them or we would be completely destroyed the last day in NY.The check out was quick. We had to stay some hours in New York because our plane left quite late. The bell boy came to our room to pick up our luggage and placed it in storage. When we were leaving for JFK we went to the taxi "drive though" inside the hotel, gave them our reciept and the bell boy put the luggage in the taxi. Very efficient and smooth service. The Waldorf-Astoria was everything we expected. Maybe we were put back by reading some reviews and didn't have too much expectations, but compared to other 4/5 star hotels in New York the Waldorf-Astoria is one of the better places we have stayed. Maybe it's advisable to spend the few extra dollars to upgrade from the standard rooms. This will probably make sure you don't end up in a "staff room" or in the smaller rooms. The con is that this hotel is really huge, and even though the service is good and smooth it's only on the surface. There is no personal service at this huge place, but the service we got was good, efficient and met our expectations. We didn't encounter any service problems. The second con is that the lobby doesn't have much sitting space except from in the resturants. There are two huge lobbyes, but very few places to just sit down and wait. The public areas seem to attract tourists not staying there, and this makes the public areas sometimes a bit crowded. Maybe that's the reason why there are so few sitting areas. Would we stay at the Waldorf-Astoria again? Yes. Next time in NYC we will most probably end up at the W-A again.

Jul 4 2008 	Nice Hotel but worth the money	Well this place is a great location. Close enought to shopping and restaruants but not right next to you so you don't have that much foot traffic around. So given the other reviews, I must have really lucked out. Also beware that when you are quoted the price for the room there are also about 15% additional for various taxes.So it was a nice hotel in a great location but but not worth the additional money.

Jul 1 2008 	Superb	Stayed in The Waldorf Astoria at the end of May 2008 & was rather nervous given that it has more than its fair share of bad reviews, however the whole experience was excellent.Arrived well before the specified check in time but had no problems checking in - there was no queue & we were in our room within 10 minutes of arriving. Luggage turned up 5 minutes later. Reception staff & porters were all very friendly & not at all snooty.we paid for a standard room - Our room was on 27th floor & had a double aspect view up Park Ave towards the park & East towards the river. Room was very spacious, well decorated & furnished & clean. Aircon worked well & unobtrusively. My stay coincided with my birthday & I was sent a complimentary bottle of champagne & chocolate covered strawberries on the day - a nice touch.We also found the concierge service in the lobby very useful for advice on getting around & booking tours etc.My only gripes would be the high cost of room service (We didn't use it there are plenty of reasonable restaurants & delis within 2 minutes walk) & the high cost of the laundry service.overall, highly recommended & well worth the money to stay in a piece of NY history.

Jun 27 2008 	Old World...New perspective	No problems at all here. The hotel is extravagant and quite beautiful. I would stay here again in a NY minute.I loved the historic touches and detail that the hotel provides. It's a side of the Big Apple that I have never seen before. Well worth it.

Jun 26 2008 	A Beautiful Piece of history	We were guests at a wedding in the city & the bride & groom chose the Waldorf as their host hotel. We live on Long Island but hadn't stayed at the Waldorf for more than 20 years (we usually stay at the NY Hilton, which we love). I had remembered the Waldorf as having an opulent lobby & tiny, musty rooms. We were pleasantly surprised! Our family had 3 rooms & each one was more than adequate. Jun 20 2008 	An utter disappointment!	On a recent trip to New York City with friends we decided to indulge in what we thought would be the ultimate splurge and stay at the renowned Waldorf Astoria. We were very excited and after a long day of travelling we were looking forward to settling into a luxurious and comfortable room. The carpet was worn and filthy, even coming up from the floor and away from the walls, The walls had stains and marks all over them, the tiny minibar fridge that sat like a box on the floor (not even in a proper wardrobe) had leaked water all over the carpet and our view was over what appeared to be an air shaft. The furnishings are dated beyond belief. The beds need new linens, comforters, pillow shams everthing. It all looks as thought it has been used since the day the hotel opened. Absolutely dreadful.The bathroom was small, the sink was cracked and the shower had to run for about 20 minutes before we could get any warm water. The toilet barely flushed.I really could not come to terms with the amount of money we spent on this room. We were speechless. We did now have a nice Park Ave view, a large dressing room as well as a few lounge chairs to sit in however there was just not getting past the fact that the rooms are in dire need of an update. To think of how much we spent versus how much satisfaction we got from our stay makes me ill. A visit to the lobby will suffice if you feel the need to see what all the buzz is about. Beyond the lobby, the hotel is a huge disappointment.Just as an aside, after paying through the nose for the room, the Waldorf then has the audacity to want to charge you $30 if you wish to access the internet from your laptop in the room. Ridiculous. Our last night in the New York area was spent at the Sheraton Newark Airport hotel so that we could be near the airport to catch an early flight. The room cost $140, the internet connection was free and the accomodations were clean, modern and extremely comfortable. I realise Newark airport is not Manhattan however it just goes to show that all you are paying for at the Waldorf is a name and the faded memory of a once 5 star hotel.I would NEVER recommend a stay at the Waldorf , your hard earned money can be spent elsewhere and you will be much happier.

Jun 19 2008 	luxurious position	We spent 4 nights in New York before going down to the Caribbean. Booking one year in a dvance the Waldorf came up cheaper than many below its standard..... Jun 16 2008 	Pros and Cons	I wondered, why the reviews posted here differ so much in rating the hotelrooms and staff. I even supposed some of the (overly positive) reviews being feigned. So, I was a little apprehensive, also because two friends joined us there for over night stays due to my suggestion of this hotel.To begin with, there are many aspects I liked about this hotel. Above all, it is classic and old fashioned and I do like that. The price (329 USD) was good compared to other high class hotels in that mid town location.On arrival, the super shuttle from JFK let us off at the motor entrance. He told us, that a concergie would take care of us. Odd enough, we saw at least six employees waiting and NO one took notice of us and our luggage. So we chose of the side entrances and took our way towards reception.On check-in, waiting time was short and the employee booked us in efficiently and politely. He (probably) upgraded us into a corner room (11th floor in a wing towards 50th street) and took care that our friends arriving two days later would get an adjacent room.The room had a good size, an old closet in the entrance area, a perfect bed, a bath-room with a big shower and a window. There were no curtains at that window, only a blind, which we had to pull down when using the toilet. We reported this to the reception desk, the employee listened carefully, but curtains never appeared throughout the stay. The view was not over impressive but not bad either. It was memorial day with obviously less traffic, no noise disturbed during the night. The air condition was an individual device and a little noisy.House keeping was good, only turn down service was inconsistent (no turn down at all on third night).Some of the lifts did not work properly. Once we got stuck in a lift and had to push the alarm. Good luck, the problem was resolved quickly.We had vouchers for continental breakfast at Oscar's (due to my gold status). The seating procedure proved to be a little fight in order to get a table where we prefered to sit. The buffet was unimpressive and did not keep up with a hotel of high reputation.The Bull and Bear restaurnt's steaks were of huge size, but charred on the surface. One of the steaks (party of four) had a penetrating taste of charcoal. The waiter told us, that this is the typical style they prepare steaks, but he will take that one off the bill. The seating was slightly uncomfortable, because the table was a bit too small for four persons. All tables were on the small side.The last night I detected, that the water on the bath room floor did not stem from our using the shower but was dripping from the ceiling. We reported this in person to the receptionist, who offered us a room change (not for the very last night, too much trouble). She offered us free breakfast (we had the vouchers). So we obtained four vouchers for free drinks at Sir Henry's Bar. I must say, we enjoyed our drinks there greatly. Returning into the room late, I found a message from the receptionist in charge who was concerned about the leakage from the ceilling in our bath room. She offered a room change without moving our luggage and asked me to call back. Well, I was tired (it was late), I did not want to be further away from our friends staying in the neighbour room (we wanted to check out togehter next day, continuing our journey), and I thought it was too much trouble for the very last night. Eventually the leaking stopped since they fixed it in the room above us. - Nevertheless I rose this issue at check out the next day and eventually got 100 USD off the overall bill.The departure was smooth. Our luggage was collected and deposited at the motor entrance. The employee there got us a taxi for four people. That worked well and fast.To cut a long story short: I liked the hotel but it does not live up to its reputation. And that is a pity. Staying here, was a good and fairly nice experience, but it could have been better. Reading other reviews I guess, staying at the Waldorf Towers makes a complete difference. But that is like another (high priced) hotel. They should work towards a more consistent appearance in terms of rooms, maintenance and service.

May 31 2008 	The worst nice hotel in the world	I am a Hilton Diamond member so I try to stay at Hilton Hotels. When I got to the room neither the TV nor the Air Conditioner worked. I called about both. They fixed the TV but didn't do anything about the A/C. (The TV here is a old tube not like the sexy flat screen a the "lesser" Hilton a few blocks away). I called again about the A/C the next morning and they said they'd fix it .. but nothing again. The morning of my last night there, I called again. When I got in from my meetings at the end of the day, they had installed a crappy window unit air conditioner in the room. May 30 2008 	Top class hotel!!	We have just returned from a stay at the waldorf astoria and want to say what a wonderful time we have had. May 24 2008 	Love the Waldorf	We loved the Astoria - all our experience with the staff was of the highest standard from check-in to check-out time. Concierge were great and always helpful.Would definitely stay here again - not only for the grandeur of the hotel but also the location.

May 23 2008 	World Class... but worth the price?	My wife and I stayed at the Waldorf=Astoria in April. My parents stayed their about 25 years agoand I had always wanted to stay their. We're from Las Vegas and we've stayed in many luxury hotels all over the country. This Hotel was exceptional, especially when you consider the history of the building.We need to get one thing straight. The Waldorf=Astoria is OLD. If you're expecting everything to look shiny and new, you'll be disappointed. If, however, you are willing to accept the fact that you're in a well kept piece of American history, and not the Disney/Vegas-based hotel/resort, you'll be in good shape.The hotels does have its pros and cons.To be honest, I probably wouldn't stay at the Waldorf again on my own dime. The place is full of history and really lets you peek into what the "old guard" must have marveled at in it's day. The entire hotel drips with history and old world charm that makes it very obvious as to why its considered the "Gand-dame" of hotels. But for a regular guy like me who wants to squeeze as much luxury as i can get for my dollar, it may seem like a waste of money.Though my wife and I agree that the service and staff were all phenominal. We just couldn't bring ourselves to spend $8.50 for a glass of Sprite and $14 for an Amstel light at the bar. The $95 per person Sunday Brunch buffet had us very puzzled, as we've both been to some of the greatest buffets in the country and never paid more than $30 per.If you're a business traveler and have a decent expense account, the Waldorf may be for you as the hotel seems to be really concentrating on large meeting and conferences, which with corperate sponsorship, would make more sense for some of the prices.The area itself is just about perfect if you want to be close to the action, but not RIGHT IN THE MIDDLE of it.A ten minute walk will get you to Times Square, which in my opinion is just an unkempt Disney-type property. Every piece of wall is covered with some sort of advertisement designed to catch your eye, and there are thousands of ads trying to out-do eachother to get you attention, so all together you look at everything and focus on nothing. Though it is quite the spectacle, Times Square epitomizes that universal image of NYC; almost overwhelming.Before you get to Times Square from the hotel you'll run in to Rockefeller Center. Top of the Rock is a must do. Beware of the creepy security guard at the top who REALLY seems to like to take pictures of couples kissing with the view of the city in the background.My wife and I couldn't stop laughing because he kept moaning "yeah, yeah, kiss her again". Friendly guy though!Walk over a few blocks to the east of the hotel and there are several privately owned restaurants that won't hurt your wallet.We really liked Ristoranta Lazagna. Great specials and amazing Lazagna, especially for the price.We also enjoyed the Grayline Hop-on/off bus tours.If you walk into this the the mind set that you're going to get to see the city from a bit better view than what you would in a cab, you'll appreciate it a bit more. Don't expect much more aside from that.What more advice can I give you? Don't be afraid to eat off the street carts. Try the gyro guy a block west of Rockefeller Center. Try Ray's Pizza on 7th Ave btwn 53rd and 54th st. and have a slice.Try the original Grimaldi's Pizza in Brooklyn. Friendly staff and great pizza.Don't be afraid of the subway, It's very easy to learn the system, and most people will gladly help you find your way around.Try everything!!! It's New York City!!Last last bit of advice is to take comfortable shoes. In NYC you never realize how much you've walked until the end of the day. If you like to explore as we did, your feet will thank you if you leave the dress shoes in your suitcase and wear those walking shoes.

May 22 2008 	This is how it is - Fantastic!	I stayed here for a girls trip in 2007 and loved it so much went back this year, little did we know the hotel could only be better than before! And no it didnt cost the earth at all, for 5 nights we paid less than 600 between us which for this hotel is amazing!On arrival we were dropped off at the underground section, somthing we hadn't had in 2007, we were met by a 'welcomer' to the hotel who greated us, had our bags taken to our room, walked us throught the hotel and checked us in while we sat and relaxed on the sofas. He came with us to the room, and after saying we would like a bigger one, just because our room in 2007 was slightly larger, he made a call and we were moved to a large suit and had strawberrys and bubbly arrive at our room as a welcome gift. Anything we wanted he looked after us. All other staff were amazing. My friend and i love the old world style of the hotel, the fact that all the furnature is not new and Ikea looking is what i want from the hotel, the grandure of it all makes you feel special,ALL the staff are amazing and the beds better than any i have ever slept in! We never dress up in the day and never feel out of place at all, never looked down on and only given respect by ALL the staff!On leaving the hotel in Jan we did have a slight issue, only minor with regards to our luggage as we left, i recieved an email from the hotel asking for my opinions on the hotel and detailed my minor issue. Within 3 days i had the director of the hotel on the phone to me in the UK to discuss the matter and express his regret...and this was only a tiny issue i raised!! He knew i was returning to the hotel in Feb and on my arrival, to my suprise, met me to further appologise, upgraded my room and when i checked out left a note to say on my next visit i would get another upgrade and a free night, so if you dont like something in the hotel tell them and they will do everything they can to make it better for you!! Oh and the welcomer from my visit in january spotted me in the hotel and welcomed me back, sent more bubbly to the room and gave us any info or help we needed....all the customers he would see but he remembered me and greated me by name! All staff from the door staff to housekeeping were fantastic and would do anything for you.I would not stay anywhere else in New York. If you are going to New York please give this hotel a chance it will do nothing but make your trip more special.

I know I am late in writing this, but as I have not received anyreply from the hotel in over a year after writing to them several times via email and completing their feedback form several times, I want to write about our experience. Hopefully they have renovated by now. This was supposed to have been a wonderful experience for our 30th wedding anniversary in the great Waldorf Astoria. We had saved up to go to New York for ages. We arrived jetlagged after more than 24 hours flying,late at night to a tiny room that greeted us with a massive stain on the carpet that had seen better days. The paint was peeling and the bathroom had make up all over the door and basin. I used the toilet and it got blocked, very blocked, so we called reception who said they would get a plumber. By this time, we were beside ourselves with tiredness. We asked if we could have another room to go to sleep and were told no as it should not be long. The room was like a sauna all night and we slept in by 30 minutes(having slept about 2 hours in all) so we missed the buffet breakfast that we had paid for months before. They said all they could offer us was coffee and sweet pastries. It was such a waste of money, hard earned money. I have stayed in better hotels here for 1/4 of the price. The most disappointing thing when I look back is that there were no apologies of any sort. Not even a simple reply to the numerous emails..... We love New York, but never again will we stay at the Waldorf Astoria.

May 12 2008 	Loved the whole experience!	We stayed at the Waldorf for 4 nights in April, 2008. I had reviewed the comments on this site, and was skeptical but, we decided to go for it. We are so glad we did! It was absolutely everything we could hope. We had a two room suite which was better than what I expected. The rooms were very well decorated, with a large and updated bathroom. The lobby of course is exceptional, and it was great to just walk through it each day. We found the staff to be very professional and friendly. I can't quite understand comments from others about snobby attitudes. We experienced none of that , and found the opposite to be quite true. We ate lunch the first day at Oscar's waiting for our room to be ready (it was extremely busy that day) and at at the Bull and the Bear twice, because we enjoyed it so much the first time. We found the service in the restaurants beyond reproach. They even helped us not to over-order! Of coure, that type of attitude encouraged us to return on our last night, so the restaurant lost nothing in terms of money. On our last night, we had a window table and sat for hours enjoying the ambience. We certainly can't afford to stay there often, but, on our next trip to New York, we will definitely return to the Waldorf. We loved New York, can't wait to return, and the Waldorf helped make our stay all that it was.

May 7 2008 	Thank God for Travel Points!	We spent 4 nights at the Waldorf Astoria (WA) in a suite on the 9th floor. We were using travel miles that had accumulated over 9 months time. This was my third trip to NYC, and we loved the WA's location. The lobby and its expanding hallways are magnificantly furnished. The entire place had that "old money" feel. Our checkin was quick, but we didn't have our confirmation page with us. We were told to provide it before we left or we would be charged $910 a day. We were not required to have bell service with our bags. We were given 4 free passes for a drink/Bull and Bear or for a breakfast/Oscar's. We took the drink tickets and headed down to the Bull and Bear. Our wine was $14 a glass. The three of us had dinner for a grand total of $333. Two of us had the filet for $50 each. It was terrific, but it could have been a smaller cut for less money. The lobster soup was first a dollop of lobster served in a bowl with garnish. The server then came back and poured the bisque into the bowl. Fabulous! We tried the waldorf salad, but it was basically a partial red and green apple slivered for $17? My friend had just had a birthday, so she picked up the tab as her celebration. One of us is a smoker so we were going down the elevator a lot at night to smoke at the ground level parking entrance. We wound up making friends with the valet staff. There is also a private entrance down there for upscale clientele. One night we saw Donatella Versace and her daughter, Allegra. Room Service: We didn't want to pay $8 for a small pot of coffee (3 cups) delivered to the room...plus a 15% gratuity and a $5.25 service charge. Instead we headed across the street/outside on 50th Street to Starbucks. $2.11 for a Grande/including tax. Later on we found out there was a Starbucks in WA, but their prices were higher. Suite: There were beautiful tapestry pillows and bed runners on the beds. The first time we returned to our room after being out all day, we found our beds turned down with the music playing at the IPOD station. We enjoyed the scented body lotion left for our use in the bathroom. The bathroom lacked a fan for ventilation. We kept joking about the price of what the WA charged for any kind of laundry service. $9 to wash a pair of panties?In the end, all we had to pay for was our internet service. It was well worth the visit.

May 6 2008 	Friendly Waldorf	We have just returned from a 4 night stay which was booked as a surprise for my birthday. I found about the trip 2 days before we went, came straight on here to check it out and was apprehensive to say the least, after some of the reviews!Get the not so good out of the way first - our taxi was directed round the side, and no-one gave us directions to reception so we stumbled around for a while. One evening in the bar the barman looked a bit sniffy at our 15% tip on 2 drinks. And my parents had a problem with their room.Good bits - Fabulous lobby - very grand and beautiful. Every member of staff we had contact with was extremely friendly, polite and professional. We got some great advice on where to eat, and excellent help with everything we asked - cancelling a restaurant booking we had made elsewhere, directions, booking return flight seats - nothing was too much trouble!Our room was spacious, and we had a corner room, so 1 window that overlooked other room windows, and the other with a view down Park Avenue. Big TV, great radio / clock, and a really comfortable bed. There was a room service note to say they would change the sheets every 3 days unless we asked them to change more often, but they changed the linens every day anyway. Our bathroom was small, but looked like an original bathroom, which we thought was nice - it was small, but fine for 2 people. Good turndown service - bedside lights are turned on, and the radio is left on low so its almost like youre returning home. Maybe if I were to be picky I could say that the decor was a bit faded, but if we wanted sparkle and modern we would have stayed at the W or the Hyatt.MY parents twin room was large with a gorgeous bathroom, but they did have a problem, and when they spoke to reception they were immediately moved to a suite which was beautiful. Their problem was handled swiftly and professionally - perfect!We didnt find the hotel, the other guests,or the staff stuffy or snobby in the least. There were functions going on every day, and we just marvelled at the management that this took. It was lovely to see people all dressed up in their finery, and yet we didnt feel out of place at all. Some of the reviews had said you would be out of place if you werent dressed up in designer clothes at all times, but I dont see that - I saw people in jeans and trainers, flip flops, and shorts and t shirts just back from running, and no-one batted an eye. Some of the retaurants have a dress code, but thats to be expected, isn't it?!There is a starbucks just to the left of the main doors that opens at 6.30. If you are from the UK, and youre awake before then and need your coffee fix faster, go right out the main doors, turn right at the end and there is another Starbucks 50 yards down which opens earlier!Take a trip up to see the ballroom and the Starlight room - both are amazing!!

May 6 2008 	Starbucks paper cups and snobby staff	What a beautiful Art Deco lobby! ... it seems to be one of the NYC top sights. Get a coffee from Starbucks located next to thePark Avenue entrance and sit down comfortably in the lobby and enjoy.Afterwards leave the paper cup somewhere, on the stairs for example.The staff is so snobby they won't even notice You (unless You are mentioned on the world's billionaires list), so no problem! ...and You have been able to enjoy the best W=A has to offer - for a reasonable price!There is no reason why You should stay at this hotel:as already mentioned the staff is snobbish and uninterested in serving a guest (however not at the bar!)During my five days stay at the hotelI didn't receive a single smile from a staff member.The rooms are very outdated and depressing. The overall room standard was surprisingly low - even at the higher room category (superior).A very modest turn down service occured every second evening.Bathroom toiletteries (mixed!) where changed once during my stay.In the bar, Sir Henry's, You can expect to find all a tired travelingsalesman needs after a long day (however even here the standard was surprisingly low!) ...and of course a good selection of liquors, as well.In brief: once You leave the lobby (although with those paper cups) there are no signs of a world known luxury hotel anywhere- at least not below the Waldorf Towers floors.

May 5 2008 	Classic hotel but no 5-star	I very much looked forward to staying at the W=A given that I had heard that they had refurbished the hotel. The common areas, including the ballrooms have been cleaned up to reflect the original style (classic modern architecture) and, while not my style, they did a nice job. The rooms, however seemed to have been overlooked. Wallpaper seams were exposed in the room and bathrooms. Basic fixtures did not get replaced (i.e., toilet paper holder or smoke alarms that have a kahaki color that comes from plastic getting old) so they looked like a bad Motel 6. And, much of the furniture had clearly not been addressed (e.g., dings and scratches in the wood, backings coming off of the armoires, etc.). The staff was friendly and the food was great, so it is a good place to visit....especially from a historical perspective. But if you are looking for a 5-star hotel, suggest staying somewhere else.

May 5 2008 	Glad I stayed will I will try somewhere else next time.	I really am glad I stayed, but next time I will stay in a newer hotel.Check in was easy and quick all the staff we came across were very friendly. I went to New York with my mum, sister, 2 children and husband. I stayed in a king size room which was bigger than the 2 x double bedroom. The beds were very comfortable.No kettle in the room but if you phone down for one they will bring one up for you, but no tea, coffee, milk or sugar you need to bring your own!! We had no view out side our window.Shampoo, conditioner, soap and body lotion and a hair dryer 2 x bath robes and towels are provided. The rooms do need redecorating, but it is what it is, a very old, well know hotel which every one should stay at! The lobby is very impressive and grand ,old money springs to mind. There are a lot of business and very well dressed people in the hotel I wish I had taken my nice clothes instead of causal sight seeing ones. The hotel is very well located 2 blocks from rockafella centre. we did not eat at the hotel, but at the restaurant in the Raddison hotel down the road.

May 4 2008 	Great Hotel	3rd May 2008We have just returned from a week at the Waldrof Astoria, New York.What a fabulous place, without doubt it must be one of the best hotels of its kind in the world. Not a glass and modern minimalistic boring place, but one steeped in history and grandier that you don't find in many places today.When we arrived we were greeted with a very warm welcome from the receptionist, who didn't take long to go through all the details of the booking. Our room was a bit small for a weeks stay, but no problem ,we returned to reception to ask for a bigger room and although they couldn't do anything that day told us that after 3pm the following day they would have a superior room for us to view.After viewing the room we were very pleased indeed and took it straight away.We found all the hotel staff more than happy to answer any questions we asked,The room was cleaned every day and the bedding changed every other day, and turned back every evening. Yes you do find that the hotel is very busy with business people, but thats one of the things you have to put up with as these people and there companies are the ones that are probably keeping this hotel going.No, we didn't find them intimatating as we also saw how pleased some of the were to be in such a lovely hotel, and they to were taking photographs of the lobby and asking passing guests to take a photo of them in the hotel.Please except it as a pleasant experience as we did. How is wish we could go backAnn DaviesSwansea

May 1 2008 	Classic New York Experience	My husband and I had always wanted to stay in NYC around the holidays so we cashed in some Hilton Honors points and stayed at the Waldorf. The building and lobby are beautiful and dramatic. The location can't be beat for all the mid-town touristy sites. However, the room decor could use some updating but was very richly decorated. We also didn't care much for the clientele - the Waldorf is not necessarily for those who want the best, it's for those who want everyone to know they spent the most. Though we are fairly well off for our age, I felt out of place for not wearing a full-length mink coat or a 10 carat Harry Winston diamond. The staff was also snobbish towards us for not being a member of the New York elite. Apr 30 2008 	Dissapointed	Arrived after a long weary flight to find a long line waiting the check-in, which seemed to take an age. It's a fine old establishment, but the service level needs review as I found out one evening trying to get a drink at the lobby bar, Sir Henry's, when the bar man informed me that he was extremely busy and asked if I wanted him to "split himself in 3" to get served. Apr 29 2008 	Great Location Aging rooms	We stayed in Room 905 for one night 4/26/08. We received a free upgrade to a king room for $299 a night, but our room was not available until after 4pm. Not a huge problem, b/c we left our suitcases with porters and went sightseeing---until the next morning when housekeeping banged on our room door at 8:30am--how is it that the room is not ready until 4pm, but housekeeping starts before 9am?Room service arrived promptly and the portions were adequate.The bed was super comfortable and was turned down. We had a king bed, chair with ottoman, flat screen TV, walk in closet, desk and chair. All in all, it was the largest hotel room we have ever had in NYC. The decor is aging, the carpet was worn around the edges and the draperies were 1960s granny style.All service personnel are polite, welcoming, helpful and sincere. There was a Denzel Washington movie filming at the hotel, which meant that the Park Ave entrance was closed periodically, which made it difficult to hail cabs. The Starbucks is convenient, but a venti nonfat latte cost over $6, almost double the normal fee.We would probably stay at the Waldorf again due to the size of the room and the location, and would expect superior service but a dated room.

Apr 26 2008 	visit but don't stay	secod time to the waldorf first time twenty years ago wish i had left it at that. reception looked very grand with all the christmas decorations up. staff lovely and very helpfull then we got to our suite reality set in, like visiting your grannys house that she has'nt decorated since the early seventies not grand antiques just plain cheap and nasty. great location and fab to tell people your staying at the waldorf but expect to be underwhelmed and you will not be dissapointed

Apr 20 2008	5 Star Rip Off	I booked with a friend for a very special trip (significant birthday) and took one of their experience packages, which was the most truthful thing about the stay, it was an experience. Draughty (the maintenance man came at 11pm and put gaffer tape around the windows to stop the draught). Two ancient TVs - why?? - tiny shower room in this suite for 4 (we were fortunately only two and no toiletries. Room not tidied or vaccuumed. Apr 17 2008 	Mixed feelings about the Waldorf	Okay, after reading a few reviews on here prior to going, I had mixed emotions about what we were going to expect at the Waldorf.I, myself, am a Travel Agent within the UK so I have been trained to always go somewhere with an open mind.The check-in was speedy and perfect however it did go a little down hill from there.The room we were given was 'dated' and not what I'd expect at such a famous and well recommended hotel.As we were there for 'tourist 5-days' we always felt out of place within the hotel as it was mainly full of buisness people carrying briefcases and chatting loudly on their mobile phones in posh Armarni suits. We were (more than once) looked at like we smelled of dirty poo, even though we were dressed quite smartly.The bad thing is, is that I've booked the Waldorf to stay in for my wedding in May and it was too late to cancel it and find somewhere different.Fair enough, the hotel was in a very good location and if it wasnt for the dated room with a crap view and the nasty stares from the other guests then the stay would of been great.The bonus you have within the hotel is it has a Starbucks inside which is a must for the 'City that never sleeps'.Anyone needed any further info or for recommendations on other hotels in NYC, please feel free to contact me.

Apr 17 2008	A good base in NYC	Considering what a huge hotel this is, service is remarkably efficient and personalized. Everything we needed or wanted was promptly provided. Our updated room had a nice view of St Barts. Other reviewers have talked about a lack of heat. This certainly was not our experience. Food and drink are not cheap, but considering this is a grand old hotel in New York what do you expect? All in all a good base from which to explore Manhattan

Apr 16 2008 	Not 5 Star!!	Just Came back from a long weekend trip to USA. On the way back from a hotel conference in Las Vegas, we stopped in New York for 4 nights. In Vegas I stayed in The Venetian, stayed in a suite, and it was great as well as the rest of the hotel.When arriving to Waldorf Astoria, they did not have the room that i had requested. BUT they offered to upgrade me to a junior suite for only 100 USD extra per nnight, and i accepted this. When seeing the room i was very disappointed, not really any bigger than any normal hotel room, and in need of refurbishment. As it was late, and i had a dinner appointment that night, i did not have time to waiste complaining to reception. The following morning i was woken up very early by building work outside. This was confirmed by reception....who amazingly admitted they knew this when they upgraded me to this room.I was given another STANDARD room, now on the other side of the hotel. Very small....and I had to call reception again later that day as the water was stuck in my bath!On departure day we checked out before 10 am as we were told. We were offered to store our luggage till we had to leave for JFK. When arriving back in the afternoon to pick up my luggage, I was told to wait outside on Park Avenue where Taxis would be found, and they would bring out my luggage. Well!!!....after waiting 20 minutes, i asked the doorman if he could find out what happened with my luggage, so he went in to find "investigate". As he never came back, after waiting another 15 minutes, i went in to the bell desk AND soon found out that nobody knew where my receip for luggage had gone missing!!!! and nobody came out to tell me....but instead i had to follow somebody down to the garage and luggage room to identify my luggage!!!Just to add to the story, my friend who also had attended the hotel conference in Vegas, also had to request a room change when we arrived to Waldorf Astoria.They might live on their name/brand, but not worth it!Lots of other great hotels in the area!!!E.S

Apr 16 2008 	Ummmm...not sure	So, where do I start. First off, everyone should have the experience of staying at the waldorf at least once in their life. The lobby is AMAZING. I felt like a ultra rich person as I checked in.Now the average news....everyone who's written on this website so far is correct. There are good things and there are bad things.I paid for a mini-suite and wound up in a handicapped room with absolutely NO VIEW. It was the view of the inner core of the hotel. YUCK. No sun coming thru at all. Then waking up one morning to workers inside this "core" yelling all morning.It was 75 degress and no air conditioning. The next day it was 50 and no heat. I called and they said that they have no heat/ac at this time of year so they'd send somebody up to open the windows. YIPPEE! (sarcasm)I called the next day to complain that my room was not a mini-suite as promised. No sitting area's, just 2 double beds. They said they would move me, but I said, I just want some money back. I was in no mood to move. They wouldn't do it since I didn't pay thru their website. Instead, I got offered an upgrade on my next visit.The pro's:1) beds are wonderful2) the room was clean3) It was quiet (for the most part)4) It was not in the middle of times square. And there is something to be said about that.5) Beautiful lobby - elegantThe con's:1) disappointed in the suite I paid for (not as indicated on their website)2) No heating or AC3) Took 1 hour to get my luggage4) I arrived at 1 and didn't get into my room until 3:30 after standing in line 3 times5) Having to take the back route to my room due to events happening in the lobby6) The shower too forever to heat up and since it was a handicapped room, I felt like I was taking a shower in a large closet.Location was pretty good.I went to the bull and bear to have the famous Waldorf salad and it was about 3/4 cup of salad with 4 walnuts. I had 1 glass of wine and the salad and my bill was $35.I think I would rather book an event there than stay there.

Apr 14 2008 	Fantastic Place - Will be going again.	We went on a five night stay to New York (First Time) we had no idea on what to expect. When we arrived underneath the hotel we where helped with the bags from a friendly porter, and directed to the lobby. The lobby itself was very very impressive! Booking in was a breeze with the amount of desks open and with smiling people standing behind them ,was a nice change from England with scowling people :)We had a room on the 13th floor the lifts are alot faster than in the UK i'm pretty sure, we got into the room to find the maid turning down the bed for us(nice touch). The room itself was very clean and tidy the bed was very very comfortable, the bathroom was spotlessly clean! Everywhere in the hotel was just impeccable, no matter where you looked there was cleaners busy!All the staff are excellent and very friendly, the concierge was excellent made our stay effortless as we'd ask for a good resturant and 5 minutes later it would be booked at whatever time we asked for.Location was very central so i couldnt have asked for more from the hotel and when I do go back to New York I know what hotel i'll be booking.New York is fantastic!

Apr 14 2008 	Waldorf Astoria - OK if you're a "Pretty Woman"?	Myself and my friend stayed from 9th to 13th April 2008. This was a special trip for our 30th and 60th birthdays so I wanted somewhere we could both enjoy.First impression was it was a great location. Out taxi pulled up at the grand entrance and was then asked to move to a different entrance not once but twice. So at the third attempt we were directed through the scaffolding at the side of the building (now affectionately known as the tradesmans' entrance!) and up to reception where we were advised room was not ready but hey took our mobile and said they would call when it was...no call but we did not mind as we took a great carriage ride around Central Park instead ($34 for 2 of us plus tip)Check in was smooth and girl was very pleasant. Our room (1609) was better than expected having read some reviews prior to departure. It was spacious enough for the 2 of us, although bathroom was a tad small although perfectly serviceable! Plenty of towels and 2 robes provided. Only negative was the shower took ages to get the hot water to come through (they did do some repairs one day so may have been fixing it then?)Using the tradesmans' entrance was to become a regular thing...on 3 separate occasions we were advised that we could not use the front entrance as there were events taking place and they obviously did not want us common folk getting in the way! This got a bit annoying after a while!!One night when it was late and raining we returned...wet and minus our umbrella! We were ignored by the doorman so he could run down the road to the aid of what could only be described as a "pretty woman" character! (incidentally already carrying her own umbrella!!!) It was a quite a picture which will not be forgotten quickly...next time I go I must wear at least Prada/Cartier to get any kind of attention and carry my Amex card of course!!Overall we had a great stay tho' . ideal location, comfortable room and we got a good deal via Greenbee!

Apr 12 2008 	The Wonderful Waldorf....	We stayed at the Hotel to enjoy the history of the Waldorf and it's old world charm. Found the room w/ a Queen bed to be on the small side with an outdated 26' TV set in a large armoire.The staff was very professional and helpful, especially the doormen hailing us a taxi and giving us city tips.Enjoyed dinner at the Bull and Bear restaurant, although overpriced and somewhat darkly lit.You must stay at the Waldorf at least once in this short life.Paul H. - Irvine, CA

Apr 9 2008 	Old Titanic	I stayed at the Waldorf in March for two nights. I had the opportunity to stay in several high end hotels and I can tell you that I was not impressed. I realized it's NYC and prices are higher but really folks, 20.00 for two eggs any style in the Peacock restaurant for breakfast? Twelve dollars for a bowl of oatmeal (not that we ordered that) Check out the menu on their website, your eyes will roll back in your head. Ok down to the nitty gritty, the room, 17th floor average size and just plain ugly old yellow and brown decor, with a huge armoure that takes up too much room and an old 27 inch regular TV. The beds were terribly uncomfortable, the bedding scratchy white hotel sheets with a 200 lb bed spread that looked like it belonged on one of the beds on the Titanic and flat pillows. The only modern device in the room was the alarm clock that allowed for an Ipod. I could not regulate the heat, it was very hot, the bathroom was really small and there was no exhaust fan. It took 2 minutes before the water came out of the faucet in the tub and then it took at least 8 minutes before any hot water came out. The curtains, again very Titanic and white sheers that looked so dingy I wondered if there had been a fire. The desk is way to small to do any work on. Don't ever book a room that is near the elevator because all you will hear all night is the sound of a 747 taking off down the runway. The website doesn't tell you that there is a Starbucks down stairs. And it does not tell you that it costs 50.00 a day to park your car and an additional 10.00 if you have an SUV. I paid 120.00 bucks for two days OUCH! The lobby is very "grand" and dark, again like an old ship. I will say that when I checked in I found the staff to be very friendly, including the bellmen, the doorman and any man or woman that worked there. Here's a cool fact that the man who checked me in told me when I had advised him that my father stayed there in 1950 for his honeymoon, he asked if he still had that bill? Then went on to tell me if he still had the bill and wanted to stay there, that the Waldorf would honor that price he paid in 1950. If you are going to have to stay in a hotel, don't you want to have the same amenities or even better amenties that you do at home? I suppose if you are a history buff, you might love it

Apr 6 2008 	Earplugs are provided!	My wife and I came to the Waldorf Astoria to attend a meeting of my old alma mater. We were given a room by the elevators which was not properly insulated for noise. Cars going up and down all night made it difficult for us to sleep. When we reported the incident, we were offered ear plugs!The following day, when we insisted that we would like to have a good night sleep, one of the managers, Mark, who had offered the plugs in the first place, suggested that we move to another room, but at twice the price! When we expressed dissatisfaction with this option, we were promised an alternative room, which would be ready in a matter of minutes. We left a cell phone number where we would be called. Five hours later, we had not been contacted. Before attending a show at the Waldorf Towers, we complained to Vivian, a kind person at the reception, who spoke to another manager, reassuring us that there would be a room available but that it would take a couple of hours to be cleaned. When we returned two hours later, as requested, we were asked to talk with yet another manager, Elena Oxford. She informed us, as kindly as she could, that there were no rooms available at that time. It was 11:00 PM then. We asked to be moved to another hotel. We were offered The San Carlos, a few blocks away. After several new phone interactions with Elena, who was always very professional and polite, we were shown yet another room at the Waldorf Astoria, but that now had constant noise from the street!By midnight, when we were ready to change hotels, we were offered another room, on a higher floor, and far from the elevators. At long last, we could get some quiet time. This was a perfect example of a lesson I received from one of my old tutors at university: when a place has a good reputation, I does not deserve it anymore!

Apr 5 2008 	Elegance and Service with a great location!	My husband took me to New York City to celebrate my 40th birthday. We spent two nights in the Waldorf-Astoria. This hotel embodies old word elegance and charm. I felt like I was in the middle of an old Hollywood movie from the moment I walked into the impressive lobby. This sprawling hotel is also quite luxurious with plush carpets and swag draperies. A bellman greeted our cab as we pulled up to the hotel and our luggage was whisked away by very efficient porters. At check in, we learned that our room probably wouldn't be ready until about 3:00 p.m. The front desk clerk took my husband's cell phone number and said that he would give us a personal call when our room was ready. After receiving the call that our room was ready, we took a ride in the elevator to the 15th floor where our room was located. I must admit, after reading some of the trip reviews posted here, I was a little nervous and scared that I would find mold in the bathroom, peeling wallpaper, or dirty furniture. Thank goodness I did not find any of these things. Instead, we walked down a private corridor to our room and were greeted with a very elegant and clean bedroom. The main room had a King sized bed, a plush chair, a desk and chair, nightstands and an armoire with a large flat screen T.V. on top. Off of the bedroom was a dressing room with another plush chair, a small table, two mirrored his and her wardrobe closets, and a vanity area with stool. The bathroom had French doors and was done in black and tan. There were lots of nice details such as silver waste baskets, a silver tissue holder, complimentary magazines relevant to the NYC area, and plush robes. The molding and light fixtures were very pretty and added character to the room.Shortly after settling into our room there was knock on the door. Because it was my birthday, the hotel sent up a birthday card and a silver tray complete with fresh fruit, a small loaf cake, and a large bottle of Spring water. It was services like this that made our stay so unforgettable.We ate in Peacock Alley and Oscar's while we were there. I ordered a steak in the Peacock Alley and was disappointed to find that it was full of fat and quite tough. The service in the restaurant was top notch and the waiter quickly noticed my distress. The manager came over and said that we would not be charged for my entree and would I like the chef to grill me another steak? They also provided my husband and I with complimentary flutes of champagne in honor of my birthday. My husband was very pleased with his meal and gave it a thumb's up. Since the service was so wonderful, the unfortunate steak incident was quickly forgotten.We had breakfast both mornings in Oscars. They offer a decent breakfast buffet which was complimentary to us since my husband in a Hilton Diamond member.The location of this hotel is very nice. Walk two blocks and you are right at Saks Fifth Avenue and across the street from Rockefeller Center. You are within walking distance of Central Park, great shopping on and off Fifth Avenue (including Bloomingdales), and Times Square. Cab service was very easy to catch from the front of the hotel. The hotel assists guests with finding a cab. The bellman always opened the door when the cab pulled back up to the hotel which gives you a nice "welcome home" feeling.One thing I did find strange was that the conditioner, soaps, and moisturizer were all from the same English brand but the shampoo was Neutrogena. They did not refill the soaps or shampoo between cleanings of the room.We did enjoy the turn down service each night because they also pulled down all the window shades and closed the curtains. We did not find the room to be too noisy considering that we were staying in such a central section of the city.

Apr 5 2008 	Famous hotel but a little dated	The Waldorf does live up to its reputation, although in parts, it is becoming rather dated.The staff were the friendliest and most helpful I have met in a hotel to date. On one occasion, we waited 10 minutes, then decided to take the stairs instead from the 9th floor.

Apr 3 2008 	Great stay at the Waldorf	We wanted a hotel for a seven-day New York experience and chose the Waldorf for its name,and despite seeing some indifferent reviews on this site.We need not have worried; the stay was great. Apr 3 2008 	Fabulous Waldorf	We stayed here for 3 nights over the last weekend in March and had a fantastic time. The photographs do not do justice to the real thing. It is old fashioned but absolutley fabulous. The service is second to none and the best my sister has experienced and she has stayed in other hotels in New York over a dozen times over the years. We paid a bit extra for a superior room but got a good discount. The room was very large with 2 king size beds and a walk in wardrobe and beautiful marble bathroom. You will be bowled over by the architecture and stunning flower displays. The rooms do not have tea and coffe making facilites but there is a Starbucks in the main entrance that we used.A good tip if you havent been to NYC before is to take advice from the concierge with regard to restaurants as some look decidely ropey from the outside but fantastic when you get in. We had great meals in Little Italy and China Town. We also booked Empire State building on the internet and got a far better deal than if we paid on the day (plus you can jump the queue) We went to BB Kings for brunch on Sunday with the Harlem Gospel singers and had a great time. This was also booked online as all the shows at BB Kings were sold out for the 4 days we were there. The pace in New York is frantic and all the people we met were friendly and helpful without exception. The key is to plan what you want to do but be flexible according to the weather. Tickets you buy online are not date and time specified which allows you to make the most of good weather and shop when bad weather! Best times to visit attractions seem to be early before 9am or after 6pm. We visited Top of the Rock at 11pm and it was deserted - fantastic!

Apr 2 2008 	Loved The W=A!!!	My husband and I went to New York last month for the very first time. Apr 2 2008	Nice but overpriced.	I didn't think the rooms were anything special. Classic old money New York. At the Waldorf's Bull and Bear Restaurant where one soda, one drink and dessert run $50 the staff is far too busy to provide your table with a table cloth or service of any kind.At the Waldorf you will be left to fight off black town cars sent over by the staff to take you to the airport. Mar 31 2008 	Perfect New York Hotel	After being surprised for with a Christmas present of a fully booked trip to New York, I was straight onto tripadvisor to check out the Waldorf but slightly worried after reading the reviews. Mar 28 2008	Shocking Hotel. Good Stay.	I stayed in a quadruple room (two double beds) on the 9th floor of the Waldorf for 6 nights in March. Check in was fast and courteous. The Receptionist wasn't overly friendly or interested in us but that suited us quite well as we just wanted to get to our room. We'd had a long and bumpy flight and been terrorised by the rudest little man I've ever met at immigration in JFK.Anyway. The room was a good size, very clean and comfortable. I had been worried by previous reviews mentioning the shabby decor but although it did look a little tired and dated in places the wonderful comfortable beds, walk in closet and fluffy towels made up for that. The bathroom was also slightly dated but the shower was great and the toiletries were replenished daily. There was a good hairdryer in the room and an iron with ironing board. The only things missing were tea and coffee making facilities. I know Americans don't drink much tea but this was an international hotel and I go a bit mad without my tea.The staff were helpful and polite and I did feel a little bit special despite it being such a large hotel. This was very welcome because outside of the hotel almost all the New Yorkers I met were very rude - something I found gobsmacking in a city where the world and his wife wants a tip for their "good" service.I only had two real problems with the hotel. Firstly, the lighting in the bathroom was somehow rigged to make you look like you'd been dead 4 weeks - or feel like you wish you'd been dead 4 weeks. I've never felt so ugly! Secondly, the entire hotel gives out electric shocks constantly and is filled with the sight of people leaping back from light switches and elevator doors. It did make us laugh at first but when you've had your 9th shock of the day and start debating with your friends who is going to draw the short straw and have to touch a door nob then it gets a little bit irritating. However, these are minor points and if you can get a good price via the internet then I recommend the Waldorf because of it's location, cleanliness and peace (the lobby is often very busy but once upstairs in our room we never heard a sound from another room or from outside). Building C. Location D. SuggestionsA. Certainly having good people on site is very important. Our experience was very good. The staff was willing to help in every area where we had a challenge. This includes day and night request. The doorman was quick to recruit us a taxi and to give walking directions. When the computer was removed from the Owners Lounge (now relocated to the welcome area) the desk was willing to let me use the machines downstairs to check emails. B. The building is very much our taste, modern and contemporary. The artist drawings are VERY much what it actually looks like. There are just two guest elevators and they stay busy and move slow. Even thought the lifts are small, my compliments on having floor buttons on each side of the door. The exercise room has a glass window over the street on the 2nd floor. My wife used a treadmill each morning; this area is a 10. It is a super view. Journey to the 25 floor to enjoy the outside terrace (see photos). My family sat up there an hour one night, with a cold beverage, to enjoy the night lights! It is an even better view than the exercise room. Please note that not all the guest rooms face the north (57th). On our floor only 803,804, 805, 806 and 807 had the premium view. Hey, I did not travel to the city to look out the window so our poor view was not a problem for me. A photo of our view is attached. A guest ice machine would be great even if on a few floors. I do not mind calling guest services for ice or even giving a tip, its the waiting that is a thorn. The large bathtub has no horizontal place to set your soap, shampoo, or wine. Please note that there is a large pharmacy next door with everything from Q-tips to beer so doesnt worry about forgetting anything. Better television set-up Ice Machines Bath tub basket Accessible computer to check emails Outside sidewalk cover for rainy days It would be helpful to have a mirror in the living are of the 1BDENJOY, we did!

Sep 18 2009 	Falls short in too many ways	Arrived on Sept. 16, for 2 nights, a studio room. When I asked about the availability of turndown service, it was clear that the clerk had no idea what that term means. I really wanted to like this hotel, but for now I will go back to staying at the Hilton Club at TheHilton,

Sep 1 2009 	Luxury made to feel like home! I'm not sure if you are allowed to go in there if your not an owner though. They had someone outside the door checking off who came in so don't be surprised if you get turned down. Aug 14 2009 	Beautiful property service uneven; very good/and not so hot	For a very detailed, accurate review of this property the first review dated July 5 does the hotel justice, with the exception of the last paragraph about the amazing happy hour including fine cuts of meat etc. We checked into two rooms last night, August 13, with high expectations.
