The location between Central Park and Midtown is close to the action without the hordes of tourists.I should point out I am a Hilton Gold member and travel extensively for work and play. When we checked in, we inquired about the happy hour that the previous reviewer had disclosed. The young lady who was checking us in replied quite haughtily; " that is for the "owners" of the hotel; not people checking in for a night." Not a good start.We then gave her our tax exempt forms and went up to our admittedly beautiful rooms.The next morning our bills under the door did not have the taxes removed. A quick stop at the front desk before breakfast from a wonderful young lady quickly took care of that problem.When we checked out, I noticed that my Hilton number was not on the receipt. The same young lady advised that since this is a vacation club property Hilton members do not get points. When I returned home tonight, I checked the Hilton website. The happy hour is not listed on the website, but there is no mention that we do not get our points.I telephoned Hilton customer service and they stated the clerk was wrong and we will be awarded Hilton points in two to five days. We shall see.I do want to point out that except for the young lady with the attitude who checked us in; everyone else went out of their way to be friendly and courteous. There was also plenty of staff on hand to attend to everyone's needs.The fitness room (not mentioned in the previous posts) is adequate with the standard Hilton Precor Fitness equipment and free weights.I would stay at this property again for it's amenities and location if they can work out the service bugs.Cheers.Marius

Jul 5 2009 	Enjoyed my stay at this beautiful luxury timeshare property	The location of this property is in the heart of midtown Manhattan and it's on the same block as Carnegie Hall. You couldn't find a more convenient location to both Central Park and the Theater District.I checked in the morning of Friday, July 3, which was opening day. The check-in experience was very quick with so many staff members working that day. The staff were all friendly and tried their best to accommodate any reasonable request. I requested and received a Studio Plus room on a high floor (the 20th - the top floor is the 26th). The elevator was fairly quick up to the 20th floor. Key card access is set up in each of the two elevators but is not working yet.When I opened the door, I smelled the odor of new leather from the stuffed chair in the corner. The next thing you notice is the handsome blonde all-wood floor and an awesome all Italian marble shower stall with a glass wall letting in lots of light from the floor-to-ceiling windows it faces. You can also slide an opaque door to cover the glass wall if you want privacy, but you might prefer not to do that to get the most natural light!The boutique toiletries are from Archive and include Green Tea & Willow soap and shampoo, Rosehips & Lavender body lotion, and Grapefruit and Neroli shower gel.There is a 37-inch LG high-def flat screen TV and a Yamaha surround sound projector plus a separate Pioneer DVD player. Full 800+ channel digital cable TV is provided through the Time Warner Cable system. The array of available channels is nearly unlimited. The only downside is mastering the use of three separate remote control devices. There is also free high-speed internet in the room using wired Ethernet access. Wi-fi access should also be available soon.The bed is comfortable albeit a bit firm for my personal taste. There are three designer lamps in the room, a 2-cup coffee maker, a mini-bar, and a separate refrigerator that you can fill with your own items.You will find a beautiful Owners Lounge on the second floor across from the fitness center. I won't comment on the fitness center because I did not use it. The lounge features ample seating both inside and on an adjacent outside terrace. There is no kitchen, so all food is catered by the nearby Redeye Grill. Continental breakfast is served from 6:30 AM - 10:00 AM seven days a week. They have fresh fruit, Greek-style strained yogurt with fruit or honey, bagels, croissants, pastries, cereal, cookies, cheese and crackers, bread, orange and grapefruit juice in addition to milk and various bottled water, juices, and drinks, coffee and tea, etc.Evening cocktail hour runs from 5:00 PM - 7:00 PM seven days a week. In addition to soft drinks, red and white wine, canned and bottled beers, and spirits, there are the usual cheeses and fresh fruit plus several hot tapas served from Redeye Grill, including Kobe beef pigs in a blanket, shrimp dumplings, mini quiches, meatballs in marinara sauce, and spring rolls. The food is delicious and a several cuts above the Hilton Club New York, probably because of the caterer used. The spirits are all top shelf (for example, Ketel One vodka and Tanqueray gin).I truly have enjoyed my experience here and highly recommend it to others.

Nov 10 2009 	Don't believe the hype.	I was excited about staying at the W before I actually got there. My experience differed, however, from that of those who give it favorable reviews. Oct 13 2009 	Wonderful everything..	Stayed here last weekend with my wife, it was the first time since our son was born 4 years ago that we got to spend a weekend away on our own. Oct 9 2009 	A Positive Experience for the Frequent Traveler	I have been travelling from LA to NYC since January, and Ive stayed in ten different hotels in Midtown (mostly Starwood and Marriott properties). There was a time when I had been moving from hotel to hotel after two or three stays because bad experiences that would eventually sour my interest in continuing my stays there. I had also been avoiding Times Square at all costs, but back in early April, I booked a room at the W-Times Square after some last minute travel plans left me no choice. Lucky for me, because I have returned to this hotel for my business travel ever since that first stay seven months ago.No hotel staff has been consistently friendlier or more accommodating than the folks at the W-Times Square. Im not sure how they manage to be so resilient with so much heavy traffic in and out of Blue Fin, high tourist volume, and my own brief glimpses into the frequent guest demands, but this teams got it in spades. In my experience, the door men are attentive and pleasant when hailing you a cab, or helping you out of one (thanks, Eric!). The front desk staff are pleasant and welcoming at check-in, and will go the extra step to explore options to best meet your preferences (thanks, Christopher, Ricardo and Pamela!). The staff who are on-hand to store, retrieve, or deliver your luggage to your room are quick and friendly, and I keenly appreciate the attentive housekeeping (and turn-down) services. No one hovers for tips, and Ive never experienced or seen a member of staff snubbing a solo or discrete guest in order to rush to the side of another guest who traveling with a mountain of designer luggage and is sporting predictably trendy gear. As a frequent traveler for business, efficiency, comfort and quiet are important to me. Many hotels in NYC are long overdue for refurbishment and they werent designed to accommodate the volume guests they have today (or their needs), so I really appreciate that the W-Times Square is fit for purpose. Small things add up, like the elevators being quick and functioning at all hours and the gym being equipped with plenty treadmills (and it is NOT located in the basement which is a huge plus). If I need something, the whatever whenever line is answered promptly at any hour I call. I was also pleasantly surprised to discover that once beyond the bustling lobby, the hotel is quiet and work-friendly. The rooms have plenty of outlets in sensible places and enough flat work space to spread out comfortably. When its time for a break, I enjoy having access to BBC America and an iPod docking station, and it also goes without saying that the beds in the Starwood properties are the best sleep in town when Im ready to call it a night. I have spent many, many nights at the W-Times Square and I have only had positive experiences to report, which keep this weary traveler fiercely loyal.

Sep 22 2009 	this is the most welcoming hotel in NYC	Over the course of the last 20 years, I have stayed in hundreds of hotels, but this is by far the most fantastic staff in any hotel I have visited anywhere (including some of the fanciest in the world). If you ask for it, they will try to accommodate you in any way they can. They are gracious, thoughtful and industrious. While I am a Platinum member of the Starwood Hotels and get particularly great treatment, I have never known any other hotel that bakes me chocolate chip cookies on arrival, makes sure I have the right number of pillows, hangers, electric outlets, water and lightning (their rooms can normally be a little too dark for me). The rooms are always comfortable (I often get upgraded to a suite if available): great beds and pillows, nice Bliss products and all the electronic amenities you need (like ipod decks, dvd players and good wireless and wired connections). While Times Square might not be everyone's first choice of location, it is easy to get anywhere in NY quickly and is certainly the most convenient place for theater, many restaurants, Central Park, a variety of museums and all public transportation. The restaurant downstairs (Blue Fin) is very good and the bar scene on the Lobby Floor is very lively. While the Four Seasons might be somewhat fancier, and the Ganesvoort a little trendier, the W Times Square will ensure you have a reliably great experience with all the luxury and hipness you need.

Jun 10 2009 	Leave the chaos outside enter into an oasis.	Ok my husband had just given up his corporate apartment in Murray Hill so he booked the W at Times Square just for something different. Murray Hill is more residential and worlds aways from this chaos so that is where I am coming from. As soon as we arrived at the W, we were greeted outside by very friendly staff. You enter and then go up the elevator to the reception area. In the same area is a bar with lounge music and lots of people. Ok so not really quiet, but honestly it was not annoying. The bed was super comfortable with ample pillows.Very cool and comfy I wish I had a bed like this at home. I really could have just taken my favorite books and spent the entire time in bed reading.There was an Ipod doc/stereo for your Ipod. How great is that! Lots of room for laptops and other electronic devices. I was most impressed with the W's security as my room key somehow stopped working. The room was in my husband's name and so security went up with me. I must say that I was very impressed that they were careful to make sure I was who I said I was. The security man they sent up with me was extremely professional and courteous. He did his job! When we checked out I saw the same officer and he remembered me by name. I actually would stay here again, yes someone who did not want to stay in Times Square.By the way the rate we got here was much better than the W at Union Square. May 29 2009	Amazing hotel blighted by a receptionist.	Having a mindset of never dwell on a problem, I would never usually complain. However, on this occasion I think I might issue a warning. After a full day and half a night of travelling to get to NY, bartering with a receptionist was near enough the last thing we wanted to do. How disappointing it was to arrive at the hotel at 10.30 in the evening (3.30 am London time) only to be told that our room, which my boyfriend paid extra for, had been given away to an overflow customer who had originally booked another hotel. Im not sure what warranted the priority of this other customer, apparently booking and paying for a room in advance does not ensure that you can actually stay in it. Instead we were told to stay in a downgraded room for the first night and that we would be moved to our proper room during the following day.However, this might have been an issue which I could have come to terms with if there was a degree of remorse shown by the receptionist and perhaps a refund of the difference, maybe even an upgraded room, sadly it was not to be. After suggesting that we were not particularly happy with these arrangements we were offered credit for the Blue Fin restaurant. This we declined as we were not certain that we would eat there. Next he offered us a complimentary drink each at the bar. After bumping this up to 4 complimentary drinks, we settled. Its just a shame we didnt get the apology.Some might think me prude, but when it comes to bathrooms, I might be inclined to favour comfort over style or at least a goodly amount of both. When contentment in the bathroom is forsaken for a glass wall, I would suggest that the design was perhaps not as well thought out as it could have been. I can see how some might see it as fun but mostly I found it off-putting. However, it is not this to discredit what otherwise was a good hotel. The doormen were friendly and attentive. They helped with our bags and called for a taxi for the return journey to the airport. The location and the view from our proper room was amazing. The bed was unbelievably comfortable and spacious and the room itself was clean and stylish.

If you have a small child, he will not be able to reach the sink, shower was great/hot.Security-I felt very safe-you need to use your room card to push any button to get above floor 7 (lobby). GYM-did not use, but took a look and am an exerciser-great modern equipment-lifting stuff and eliptical/treadmill kind of equipment. BAR/LIVINGROOM-saw many people hanging out, comfortably having a few-modern. FOOD-did not eat there as I could feed my whole family breakfast on the charge for just a yogurt and cereal. Went next door to get muffins and bananas at StarBucks.LOCATION-Remember this IS Times Square, if you want peace-go to the country (it is where we are from-no lights, people & tons of stars in the sky). We were on the 31st floor and had a side view of times square, on this Memorial Day weekend Saturday night it was loud but when the airconditioner was on, we could not hear anything and we were so tired nothing could stop us from sleeping. The morning noise was not a problem at all. We walked to and from Penn Station, Gershwin Theater, and Build A Bear. As a mom with two pretty teenagers in the "big city" I felt very comfortable and safe walking all around. I have been here a few times before, just take precautions as you would anywhere. I googled maps to help with locations and directions and managed just fine.

May 23 2009 	Brighter lighting in rooms please.	Just back from a stay at the W Times Square, loved the floral scents, the hip decor, the fun cocktails in the Living Room, the wonderful toiletries, the location. All in all, nearly perfect for our business meeting, especially when it came to relaxing after the meeting! Only one suggestion, more lights in the room, please. It is nearly impossible to get any work done with the dim lights provided. I had to raise the shades, just to read the hotel guide in the room. Business travelers who want to look at documents in their rooms should consider bringing along their own lights.

May 18 2009 	Bouncers on the door!!!	I was on a short break with my girlfriend. The hotel is in an amazing location although it took some careful dance moves to get from the taxi to the hotel entrance with our baggage. You then had to negotiate your way past the bouncers on the door, through the disco and the beautiful people and finally you made it to reception. Very nice staff who happily upgraded us from a Marvelous room to a Fantastic room. Apparently they are identical although one was on the 12th floor and one was on the 51st floor. The room was ultra modern and in my view the designers have tried too hard. Too large cases and no storage space at all. One small drawer and several fake drawers which were sealed shut. I did complain but apparently all the rooms are like this! Great design with no thought as to the eventual user. We had to complain about the cleanliness on more than one occasion however the staff were quick to help out and send someone up to sort the problems. Very noisy location and with the window open, well what would you expect for Time Square! First trip to New York and absolutely loved the place. Less enamored with the hotel though. After a busy day sight seeing etc, I needed a little tranquility on my return to the hotel and the W didn't offer this. Not a complaint, simply an observation.

May 14 2009 	Style over Substance - with great location.	I stayed with my heavily pregnant wife at the end of April. We booked with Amex so we got upgrade on arrival, stay 3 nights get 1 free, free breakfast,early check in, 4pm check out, a $85 credit for the blue fin restaurant/bar and a limo from JFK.When we got to hotel there were no door staff to help with bags or point us in right direction. We quickly found check in on the 7th floor. This was smooth and he told us how to get to our room on the 52nd floor. The room looked very good, great view but had absolutely no practicality. The size of the room was fine, but the wardrobe was tiny and there was just no draws to put anything. There was plenty of space where storage could have gone, but the room was too trendy for its own good. We phoned down to say we were not happy and very quickly the service manager arrived. She admitted that although the rooms had just been renovated, it had not been done particularly well and most people do complain about lack of storage. She said most rooms would be like this but she would upgrade us to a suite if we liked. We did.We had to go back to reception and get new rooms keys. When we found our new room the service manger arrived with a bag of gifts and a hand written note congratulating us on our future arrival. A nice touch.The suite was great, very large, 2 big wardrobes and 1.5 bathrooms. The main bathroom was tiny though. The living area toilet was big but had no where to hang a towel. Overall a good room but needed more lights. Far to dark at night time. In summing up the rooms they look great but they are not designed for someone to use them.The free breakfast had to be taken in the room and on the sixth day was starting to get boring.I used the gym most days and although it is small it has very modern equipment and was always quiet.Because we stayed 6 nights we had 2 $85 credits at the blue fin. We used one for a set menu meal which was very good and the other for Friday night cocktails which was better.I did have to remind them of the free nights on check out, but the staff as usual were very good. I did also take advantage of the free Internet in the lobby, no need to pay for it in your room, if you are just checking emails and i also had quite a few of the welcome drinks.I would recommend this hotel, but pack light and you don't really come to New York to stay in your room do you?

Apr 22 2009 	Cool and Trendy	We stayed one night in W Times Square for a family birthday and Broadway show with my two children and parents. Apr 12 2009	one of the best hotels i have ever stayed at	i am pretty young and love staying at the new and hip W hotels. Apr 9 2009 	Living Room Experience	The W Hotel experience was absolutely exceptional; however their external partners such as the Living Room were not as exceptional. Mar 31 2009 	For Location Excellent	This is now my 3rd stay @ W Times Square and apart for the renovated rooms pretty much everything remains the same. The location is excellent, central for most attractions and tourist sightseeing, The staff are friendly & helpful, The bar is still hip & makes a great place for cocktails. Stay here if you want a Times Square loction and be in the centre of the action. Don't stay here if you are on a Business Trip ? need to work in you room.

Mar 31 2009 	Right in the Middle of Times Square Expectations Met	If you are planning a trip to NYC, have some money to spend and want to stay in the Mecca of all tourist zones... the W Times Square is for you. This is a great hotel and has everything you'd expect in a W, although scaled down to a "Manhattan Size". You're not going to find huge rooms here (outside of the suites) but if you are in NYC and spending a lot of time in your hotel, you're not optimizing your trip.The fitness center is adequate and the staff and service is standard. This is not a "blow you away in awe" W like some of that brand can be, but compared to other Times Square options, this is definitely the hippest and trendiest chain I've stayed at. They're is nothing wrong with this place, however if you need peace and quiet, you might want to look elsewhere... there's always something going on if not in the hotel, then on the street.

Mar 29 2009 	Simply lovely...	I was in town for a conference and this hotel was picked by a colleague for its location and fair price. I was thrilled---always loving the W brand, this hotel did not disappoint. First walking in, the floral scent is lovely and inviting. I love the modern design, water features and fresh flowers everywhere... The reception area and bar have a cool, modern edge. The staff were very friendly and helpful (storing luggage and help at concierge--aka "whatever" desk).Our room was a good size for NYC (2 beds and it fit luggage!). It was modern and clean. Bed and linens were top rate. The bathroom was complete with tub, shower and fantastic Bliss products.Location is great for the tourist and Jatvis conference attendee. Yes, there is some traffic/siren noise, but common anywhere in NYC. Overall, I highly recommend!

Mar 27 2009 	great hotel wish i was there now	we travelled to the w with our two teenage sons for our sons 19th birthday First impressions the elevator area with waterfall was great.The checkin very fast and we were quickly in our 31st floor room great room, nice size ,comfy beds and very clean.The lobby bar is lovely candles everywhere and lovely smelling lillies,gets very busy and is a little exspensive.The hotel is situated ight on times square couldnt be better. All the staff were very helpful.We visited all the usual places empire state,central park ,greyline tour ,hms intrepid thats great but make sure you allow at least half a day.we also saw the nicks lakers game at madison square gardens the lads loved this.We used the theme resterants planet hollwood,hard rock cafe and espn zone thats great with kids.If your travelling to newyork a must is the purchase of a newyork city pass it saved us a fortune. When we return to newyork well definately stay at w i would recommend it to anyone.

Mar 20 2009 	Trendy modern and comfortable but dark and cave-like	If you are looking for a hip and trendy boutique-style hotel filled with trendy people smack dab in the middle of Times Square, then look no further. My room was comfortable and clean with a great bed. Times Square is a very noisy place to sleep, however, if you are not used to that level of noise (even on the 39th floor), and the flashing lights from the signs can be a bit much. This is probably a great hotel for a romantic or sightseeing trip, but don't expect to do any serious work in your room, as the lighting is strictly mood-oriented, and not made for working. I could also hear more details than I cared to from my next door neighbor's telephone conversation.

Mar 19 2009 	Overdesigned and too cool staff	Don't get me wrong - I like W Hotels and stay there quite frequently (Hong Kong, Seoul, Montreal etc.) but the W Times Square in New York has been one of those experiences you don't want to repeat.The first room we got has been so small that 2 persons couldn't unpack the suitecases, store the clothes, have breakfast... Further the bathroom has been so much overdesigned that they forgot to fit enough lamps. For my wife it has been impossible to do make-up, for me shaving has been a problem. So, since I've got a Platinum SPG card, I called and complained. The y promissed a bigger Suite for the next day, okay, fine. When returning from restaurant we saw that they forgot the "turn-down-service" (which you can expect at approx. US$ 400/night). We've been informed that the W isn't star rated and therefore we can't expect 5 star service. "Turn-down" they perform only on special request and automatically when you're Platinum SPG member (which I am - but still they forgot). The next day we were moved to a nice Suite. But again, the thing has been so much overdesigned that they forgot the light switches. So for switching on/off the light you have to go to each and every lamp to switch it on/off... And again, the light in the bathroom has been too little, everything too dark!Breakfast (in-room) has been included in our package, that's maybe why the croissants always had been from the previous day... But the juice (freshly squeezed) has been perfect!Another positive feature of the W is free-WiFi at the bar/lounge (which is quite crowded and noisy) - but who cares, it's free - while in the room you have to pay.The problem started the last (3rd) day. Again they forgot "turn-down-service" and in the morning they even didn't bring new shampoo... So I called and the lady insisted that they performed turn-down-service, that she had been present in person, that they exchanged towels and put chocolate. I informed her that neither there're fresh towels or shampoo nor chocolate. But she insisted. Anyway, after a while, she told me that we'll get shampoo in a moment. So I waited 15 minutes before I called again. She said "immediately" and I waited another 10 minutes, sitting on the sofa at the entrance door. Then I called again and she informed me that the person had been there, knocked - but I didn't open. I told her that I'm sitting by the door, no TV, no radio, no iPod, no drugs, asked her if she has a wrong room number. She confirmed the right number and told me she'll call back. 5 minutes later she called and told me that the shampoo is now standing in front of the door. I opened - and guess what - no shampoo. 5 minutes later really somebody came, knocked and gave me a shampoo... More than 30 minutes waiting, wasting, for shampoo!I think the problem is that at the W Times Square the staff wants to be sooo cool, too cool to perform service. Nothing is really serious -and that's a problem for business travelers.W at Court is fine, W Times Square a nightmare!

Mar 13 2009 	Couldn't get any better	As we arrived at the W Times Square Hotel we were greeted by an over head waterfall, which was stunning. You have to go in the lift to take you upto the reception area. When we arrived it was abount 7pm on a friday night and the reception/bar area was buzzing with people. The decor was very modern but cozy aswell. The staff at the reception were very friendly and helpful.As we got out of the lift to go to our room the corridors were decorated in gold, which loooked very luxurious.As we entered the room were very pleased at the size of the room (compared to the W on Lexington avenue), we had a very large window with a chaise lounge next to it were we took advantage of the spectacular view of times square and the hudson river. The bed was very comfortable and the bathroom was to a very high standard also.You could not have asked for a better location, we were right next to the tkts booth and everything else times square had to offer.When i go back to New York i wouldn't even think of staying anywhere else.

Mar 6 2009 	Style but a bit more substance needed	Yup, it looks great.(Very) Comfy bed, clean, clean, clean. Love the toiletries. Great (24 hour for those with jetlag early wakening) gym.2 minutes to Times Square subway and a panoply of subway lines to the rest of Manhattan. Handy indeed.And very close to the E line at 50th St straight out to the JFK airtrain if you want to avoid that big cab fare to the airport or touring umpteen hotels to pick up fellow passengers.That costs, and the costs are about average for the size of room we had in Times Square. You want cheap? You'll be walking a lot further.So, a great looking hotel in a brilliant location.BUTIf you want a bath (not just a shower) make sure you ask for a room with one when you book (and online booking may not tell you). After a long day in the snow and minus 5 a shower doesn't always do the job.And you'll be living out of your suitcase. One clothes drawer and one shelf in the cupboard. We travel pretty light, but 2 people for 5 days with very variable weather means SOME luggage. And there's nowhere to put it.Ignore the "table reserved" signs in the lobby bar. They all are, and it's just to keep interlopers at bay. Don't expect rapid service in the bar either. Overall: a good hotel, which is a little up itself, but if you want facilities and location it ticks all those boxes. I stayed in the Times Square Hilton 2 years ago and the W is better on many fronts. If I were staying in Times Square again I'd use the W.

Feb 27 2009 	Great location Great vibe	Great hotel! Love the Vibe, love the location. The only drawback was the tiny little rooms. My wife and I stayed at all of the W in New York over the years but this one is a ittle cramped for my style. The bar and lobby bar is great place to hang out and have drinks, a great launching pad for the night! There's nothing like checking in, leaving your bags with the bell hop and getting a much needed drink post travel drink in the lobby as they bring your bags to your room. The club was a nive place to hang out at the end of the night as well. All in all, if you want to be in the thick of time square and don't mind with the bright lights, the traffic noise from your small room, this is the best place to stay in the area. If you want the ammenities of the W, much larger room and a much quieter stay, try the W Tuscany, or the W Court. They are side by side near Grand Central and worth the price!

Feb 21 2009 	Wonderful and Hip - Will be back	We stayed for 2 nights on our way back to Australia. The W Hotel is in a great location fronting Times Square. The refurbished room was really nice and spacious for a New York hotel. All staff were friendly and helpful and dressed in funky uniform. The hotel is hip and cool, we loved the bar off the reception area - the ambience was hip, relaxing and comfortable. We will definitely be back when we next visit New York.

This was an issue since our son ( age 22 ) was with us. The staff was great, I left my favorite pair of sandals and when we called after our cruise they sent them home to us. I was so happy.

Jan 21 2009	Whatever Whenever says enough	What a perfect way to spend our anniversary. This was our second stay here and remember exactly why we returned and why would not stay anywhere else in NY ever. The hotel is first class in everyway. Very modern in every way. Awesome flat screen and a bed that will make you never want to get out. We were really taken care of. Any request I had they went about and beyond to accommodate it. The service was amazing. Jan 13 2009 	5 strikes and your are out!	Within 24 hours, five strikes against this property which in the future, I will certainly avoid and suggest you do the same. For the hustle and bustle that is Times Square NY, the hotel property itself was very pleasant, clean, and modern. There were a few issues that I have yet to get over, even though three weeks have passed since our stay. W Hotel touts itself as a trendy, and dare I say sexy, contemporary resort. For me it was far from that. The purpose of my stay was a romantic pre-Christmas stay with my girlfriend prior to the family fun and chaos that Christmas brings. Upon arrival we checked in to the hotel and went to our room. The room was clean, trendy, and simple. We booked with our Starwood Preferred Guest (SPG) points and paid an extra amount of points for an upgraded room. For an upgraded room, it was not worth the investment. (Not the first strike, but worth noting) We asked for a better view room to overlook Times Square which was available but they wanted $50 more for the night to move 4 rooms over. The hotel was rather empty and as a SPG who paid an upgrade points already, I would have hoped they would upgrade for no fee. Not the case so we declined. (Strike 1)After a hectic morning of travel, we just needed to take a rest before we hit the town and fell asleep immediately. Within 40 minutes or so of falling asleep, we were woken up by a loud knock on the door. Upon answering, we met a gentleman asking to change lighbulbs. Yes, woken up about an hour after checking in to change lightbulbs! For a hotel that claims to focus on comfort and the guest, this was not a good start. (Strike 2)We then went to the concierge for advice on broadway plays. Although polite and friendly he was not well informed. In fact, he mis-informed us about the showtimes for the play we wanted to see and we missed the deadline for the reduced price tickets and had to skip dinner to make the earlier showtime. A high end trendy hotel with a misinformed concierge? (Strike three)Then, after a wonderful night on the town, late into the evening, we had a wonderful nights sleep in a very comfortable bed. Then, it got worse. We were eager to sleep in and enjoy the serenity of the pleasant room and cozy bed, however, at about 8:30 am there was another knock on the door to wake us up (again). Half asleep I went to the door and found the staff member chose to wake us up and let us know there was a newspaper at the foot of the door. Waking guests up at 8:30am to tell you about a newspaper....Absurd! (Strike 4)The fifth and final strike was the worst. It was about 10am that same day. There was a brief knock at the door and then immediately the door flung wide open. This time, a staff member, who never waited for us to answer the door, rudely and ignorantly barged in the room and interrupted "an intimate moment" between me and my girlfriend. Extremely embarassing. We still have no idea why he just barged in the room. We remain shocked, embarassed, and angered by the experience. My girlfriend was extremely embarassed and ran to the bathroom crying. I did call the manager immediately and she was very polite and apologized. My SPG points were also refunded. Three weeks have passed and I am still disappointed in the stay, the staff, and the embarassing experience and this is why I chose to write this review. 5 strikes in one 24 hour period for a property of this caliber is simply unacceptable. This hotels claim of being trendy and sexy is true but the staff is poorly trained and inexperienced which can lead to missing a broadway play , scalping expensive tickets, missing dinner plans, and a crying girlfriend in the bathroom the day before Christmas. My recommendation is to consider the few other major hotels (i.e., Mariott or Double Tree) within a block of the W in Times Square and avoid this property until the staff can be suitably trained on guest relations.

Jan 7 2009 	Excellent night stay	I stayed at the W Times Square for one night on December 17, 2008 and was very happy with the experience. Valet was easy at the entrance on 47th St. (It is $65 (large car/suv) per 24 hours no in/out).Check - in was very quick and we were upgraded to a suite with Times Square views. It had two bathrooms, a wet bar, pull out couch and separate king size bedroom. The mattress was very comfortable as was the room overall. It had dual climate control zones and two enormous LCD tvs. We called housekeeping twice for pillows, etc. and they were brought up in minutes. Our room was on the 20th floor and did not have any problem with road noise - honking cars, etc. So many other reviews mentioned this, but it was not an issue for us. Also, in the lobby there was not loud music playing and it actually had a calm vibe to it during the day. When we returned late that night there were definitely people at the lobby lounge/bar but it still seemed pretty low key. We had an excellent breakfast in the hotel restaurant. The pumpkin ginger pancakes and smoked salmon platter were both great. All of the hotel employees that we encountered were pleasant and helpful - from the valet attendant, to housekeeping, to check-in, to restaurant staff (especially at the restaurant - it was very busy when we came in for breakfast (it was filled primarily with what looked like local businessmen and a few hotel guests), but the restaurant manager (seeing we were hotel guests) was very attentive and made space for us after a few minutes wait)As we were leaving we did notice that they have something called the Acura Experience or something like that. It's hotel sponsored program that provides free rides around the city in an Acura SUV, I think. We definitely would have made use of this if we had known of it. Also, at check in the hotel receptionist knew the pull-out couch would be used, but this must not have been communicated to housekeeping because the pull-out was not set up at turn-down. We had to call for extra blankets and pillows. I know this is minor, but it's so nice when these things are remembered by staff and I'm pleasantly surprised. The rooms were pretty dim and the opaque wall/divider between the bathrooms was a little odd, but other than that I have no complaints. I would definitely return to this property and recommend it strongly.

Jul 14 2008 	Urban cool but looking tired round the edges	Located right in the centre of Manhattan off of Times Square, The W clearly positions itself as the epitome of cool. Certainly, your welcome experience bears this out - the beautiful water feature as you enter, the stunning lounge area on the 7th floor and the genuine easy going and friendly welcome from the staff (who are, of course, way better dressed than you are.)Beyond the lobby, others have noted that the decor veers toward the dark and the industrial. The corridors in particular are like peculiar black holes; mildly off-putting, but the general calming effect does make some sense - and it's unlikely you'll spend much more than a few seconds in those areas as you're passing through.First impressions of the room itself were positive - if you can get over the fact that the room itself was disappointingly small for the price, but overall, the 'cool' vibe carries through - flatscreen HDTV, glass desk, views over Time Square, mood lighting and so on. The bathroom is well appointed with a great shower and refreshingly, a good set of toiletries, including a decent face wash to clear off all that New York grime. The bed was simply one of the best I've had in a hotel - and it needs to be, with the hustle and bustle of Times Square outside doing their best to keep you awake.Alas, after a short while of being in the room you begin to notice that the shine and gloss wears thin quite rapidly and it's clearly evident that the rooms are in dire need of a major facelift. Wallpaper peels from the corners of walls, dust is collecting on the skirting board, the air vents haven't been cleaned in months. The taps in the bathroom are dull and tarnished; the sink has cracks from years of use. The lamps are yellowing, the cover of your complimentary 'soothing' CD looks like it was found at the bottom of the bargain bin of the Virgin Megastore across the street.In a low key hotel at a cheaper price, you'd probably let these things pass - but in a premium hotel at a very premium rate, the lack of attention to detail was unforgivable. Clearly, the rest of clientle - a mix of fashionistas, media types and "Sex in the City" wannabes - seemed happy enough, but then again, they probably weren't fretting about who was footing the bill.
Jul 12 2008 	W Rocks!	Perfect W experience! Great location, helpful staff, great room!

Jun 29 2008	One of the hotel features: overbooking	This review will be very short. We were 2 couples and decided to spend a weekend at the W for a birthday event. We get there to check in and the receptionist tell us to come back later because the rooms were not ready yet. We called before coming back and we were told the rooms were clean and the keys were ready.As soon as we got there, they finally tell us they had a computer problem and that all the rooms suddenly happened to be all taken. What a service.

Jun 28 2008 	Stay Away!	The room is one of the smallest I have ever seen. They make the Microtel seem spacious. It's hard to pull off the modern contemporary look when the property is so dated. It has that 70's style of "contemporary". The location is unbeatable. The price is outrageous even by New York standards. The only thing positive I can say is that the Blue Fin restarant was great. Excellent food and great service at reasonable prices.

Jun 25 2008 	Nothing special	We stayed at this hotel in June 2008 for a birthday treat for my 21 year old daughter and 16 year old son. Picked the hotel for the location, right on Times Square and thought my daugter might like the modern space age theme. Booked two rooms intercommunicating. Booked 'spendid rooms' for a treat, on arrival at reception was offered two rooms on the newly renovated 15th floor, so were first guests to stay in them. My son and daughter were highly impressed with the ultra modern decor but for myself and partner we were quite disappointed. The corridors and lift areas have gun-metal grey walls, ceilings and carpets which to begin with looked quite smart but by the 3rd day we felt we were staying in a prison block. The rooms were a reasonable standard hotel size and as previous reviews have stated, the beds were very comfortable. Again the 'grey' theme was repeated throughout the rooms. It felt like the hotel has tried to make it hip and fashionable but failed to make it comfortable. Although the twin room had a very small bath, the king-bed room only had a shower which was a little disappointing. A note on the bathroom, the entire walls are made of glass, and although frosted you can see people inside, therefore absolutely no privacy, which for a couple can just about get by, but for my daughter sharing with her brother was a big no-no. Lots of the room decor and with the hotel in general, has been decorated for show, and has not taken into consideration any practicalities.Another mention is that all 3 mornings we were awoken at 7.30am by loud drilling, so guess the floor is still being worked on, so avoid rooms on the 15th for the next few weeks.A note on the staff, again we felt that everyone was image consicious and not really doing any proper customer service. The consiege was the most UNHELPFUL we had ever come across and we have stayed in New York many times.In all, my daughter loved this hotel which was what the trip was all about, for myself wouldn't stay here again, much prefer the more comfortable Sofitel a couple of blocks away.

Jun 22 2008 	One of the best hotels in Midtown	I was booked in this hotel by Starwood Corporate after my original stay at the Sheraton Manhattan at Times Square went all wrong (see my post there for full details.)Having stayed at many W hotels in the past, this one ranks up with one of the best. The suite I was in was absolutely beautiful. It had a very large bedroom, 2 full bathrooms, living room, two large screen tvs, multiple sound systems... the works. The best part of this room is that it is the only room with a full balcony. It has an amazing view, and is perfect for anyone looking to entertain up to two dozen people comfortably. You are separated from all the other rooms, so you can be sure your partying will not disturb any of your neighbors. Also the balcony comes in handy for those who smoke, as all the rooms are non-smoking.The club in the basement of the hotel is okay, tho never drew a very big crowd. There is a great bar in the main lobby area of the W (3rd floor), and a great place to unwind. The restaurant has some great food (sushi blend), but expect to pay the usual NYC fares. The room service is on par with the restaurant, and can satisfy almost any need at anytime. This goes along with the W's motto: Whatever, Whenever. I would recommend this hotel to anyone who is looking to stay in Times Square.

Jun 16 2008 	Needs a facelift	I am originally a New Yorker, so going back and seeing how Times Square has changed in 30 years is great and I Love N.Y. The past few years we stay at the W-Times Square-used to stay at the Paramount now the W. When it opened;WOW.!! This year it just started to seeem like it needed a bit of work. The carpet had small stains, the rooms hadn't changed in at least 3 years, and the bar that we love (BLue Fin ) which has a great corner view jutting out onto Times Square and all enclosed in glass needs to replace the chipped glass chair stools. Honestly I love this hotel, I go every year but would hope Management recognizes it's time for a facelift.

Jun 15 2008 	W Times Square is GREAT!	The main purpose for my trip to NYC was to see "Grease" at the Brooks Atkinson theater, with Taylor Hicks in the role of Teen Angel. After weighing the options (closeness to the theater being foremost), I chose W Times Square. And I am so glad I did! The theater and the hotel are in the same block.This is a very hip place to stay, located in Midtown and the Theater District. Though the hotel and most of the nice eateries around it are pricey, it was worth it.Also, it is convenient for sightseeing via the hop-off/hop-on double-decker bus tours - there's a stop right around the corner from the hotel, by the Roxy Deli (the size of those sandwiches!).The W staff was fantastic. My room was quite comfy. As I mentioned, it's a "hip" hotel - mostly a young crowd, so the "living room" (the lobby) was a bit noisy -- but all of NYC is noisy!I really enjoyed my stay, and I look forward to going back.

Jun 4 2008	W 4 me!	Have just returned from a long weekend at this hotel, and what a fab time we had. The hotel is situated right in the hub of Times Square. Thought the noise would have been a problem but as we were on the 25th floor and facing one of the side streets, this was unfounded. The room was a twin room with two double beds and an ensuite bathroom. It was a fair size for two people and I could have lived with it longer, if I had the chance!! Fresh towels were provided daily and the bar was stocked well, if a tad expensive. The bliss products in the bathroom were replenished daily and were brilliant. The staff were excellent, friendly and courteous at all times. The bar was a bit expensive although very chic so we preferred the bars out on the square and surrounding areas. Only ever ate breakfast in the hotel and it was okay, plenty of it. We would return to this hotel again as we loved it, the location and the big comfortable beds.......

May 29 2008 	Great Hotel	I've just recently come back from a 3 night stay in New York. I took the trip with my wife as a birthday present.I visited New York about 7 years ago and always vowed to go back. The recent bank holiday seemed like the perfect excuse. The first thing i noticed when booking the trip was how expensive the hotels had become in New York. Most hotels seemed to be around the 200 a night mark. I looked at a few 'cheaper' hotels and they were still around 150, so i thought, go on treat yourself, book a nice hotel. So after much deliberation i booked the W hotel in Times Square.After reading a couple of reviews i was a little appehensive. I was led to believe that the hotel was pitch black with techno music booming out until your ears bled ! This was not the case.When you arrive at the hotel the first thing that will strike you is how close you are to the centre of Times Square. You are literally bang smack in the middle. There are several bars outside the hotel, as well as deli's and other eateries. The hotel is also a short walk from the Times Square Subway stop.You enter the hotel in the basement and have to take a short lift to the 7th floor. The 7th floor being the reception / living area of the hotel. As you enter the basement the word ambient springs to mind. Dashes of purple light and ceiling mounted water features. A nice little touch with regard to entering the basement is that the hotel employ security during the evening to make sure that only hotel guests can enter.The reception area of the hotel is something else. I totally understand that it will not be everyones come of tea but i personally thought it was fantastic. It's very dimly lit and the tradition of purple light and ambient colours are reproduced. Music seemed to play 24 hours a day whilst we were there. The best genre to describe it would be ambient beach music. I personally quite liked it. And it wasn't as loud as some reviewers have suggested.There is a bar in the reception area and several seating options. The atmosphere was laid back and friendly. The bar staff are excellent.Also within the same room is the concierge. I generally don't bother the concierge as they are normally quite unapproachable. Not so in this hotel. As you walk to the desk you are greeted with a plaque that says 'Whatever'. This pretty much sums up their attitude. And over the course of our stay i bombarded them with pretty much whatever came to mind. Each time they obliged. From producing a plaster for my wifes foot, booking dinner reservations to booking a helicopter trip. They were fantastic.The lifts to the rooms are split into 2 sections. One for the lower rooms and one for the higher floor rooms. We were given a room on the 48th floor. Wow, the room was great. I had read stories that the rooms are small and unpractical. Totally untrue. The shower is a walk in affair and their plenty of room in the bathroom. The bed was fantastic as were the nice touches that surrounded it. You will also get a plasma tv, alarm/radio and several other hotel standards. One thing i must mention are the bliss bathroom products. Easily the best quality hotel bathroom produce i have come across. I am still using the body butter now, but thats another story !In summary, the hotel is great. The staff were generally quite young but incredibly friendly and approachable. The location is great and is pretty much bang in the centre of town.I enjoyed the bar in the hotel but did not use the Whisky bar which is lcoated underneath the hotel. However, i was told that if you produced your hotel card on the door you would receive some form of VIP treatment. Also, i did not use the Blue fin restaurant but did hear good reviews whilst in the hotel.One great recomendation i received from the concierge is worth a mention. A breakfast eatery called the brooklyn diner which is nearby. If you want authentic New York complete with waffles, pancakes etc.. Thats your placeTotally won over by this placeLyndon

May 25 2008 	chi chi hotel with a great location	I am a little old for this brand of hotels but have stayed at this w a few times recently. GREAT LOCATION! GREAT FOOD! You take the elevator up to reception which is a few floors up from the ground. Check in is usually pretty crowded. The on site places to eat are some of the best in area which is packed with hotels because of the theatre district as well as midtown location. Rooms are on the small side but very well designed and comfortable. The hallways are too dark for my taste but it seems to be part of what w defines as cool. Not a lot of benefits for business travelers but the hotel clearly targets young professionals with its bar scene. they have dvd's for borrowing as well as a diverse and tasty room service menu. All in all a nice and comfortable place

May 19 2008	It's Alright	I only live a few minutes away from Times Square and every now and then I will go online and check for hotel bargins. The W comes up often. So my girlfriend and I will check in and be tourists for the night. It's always fun.I like this W but I will pass along some tips. First it is noisy. Expect to hear a drunk or two in the hallway. Second if you have a corner room facing Times Square it will be bright. The hotel needs to install blackout shades badly. Thirdly, it is not as happening as it was a few years ago. The class of people seems to be going downhill quickly. It went from supermodels to baseball capped punks with their girlfriends overnight. ( The W is building in Hoboken. That either means Hoboken is cooler than I thought or that the W is not the brand it used to be).The positives about this hotel? It still has great Time Square views. The staff is still good. The rooms are still cool.

May 18 2008 	Fun Place to Be	I have stayed at the hotel twice - once on pleasure for 5 nights over Thanksgiving in 2007 and once with business for 3 nights in March 2008. My wife travelled with me on both trips and absolutely loved the hotel. The rooms are not large, but I only have the rooms in Asia as a comparison, so they could be large by New York standards. They are equiped with shower, great Bliss tolietries (which are one of the reasons my wife loved the hotel - she has been dedicated to their products ever since), coffee machine and probably the best in-house movie system I have come across. This is great if you want to chill out at night with the Mrs. The mini-bar is expensive but as you leave the hotel on the left hand side is a deli which can serve you breakfast, beer, evening meal or whatever you want, so to be honest we never had to use the mini-bar, if I wanted a drink in the room I just brought up a couple of beers on the way in.As other reviewers have said the lobby area does become a bit of a club/bar at night but this is part of the appeal of the hotel. You have to use the elevator to reach reception and the lobby bar is basically in an open-plan area by reception. There are no windows to the outside so you may feel that you are drinking at 1am when actually it is only 10pm outside. The waitresses are HOT! It is not cheap but not outrageously priced either.The gym is quite small but functional. We ate in the sushi bar on the groundfloor and it was excellent, the bar at the front of the hotel does an excellent seafood platter and combine this with a nice bottle of Sauvignon-Blanc or two and your afternoon is just about full, (as are you). The staff are quite young and very helpful. Friendly, informative and they seem to be genuinely interested in you as a customer. At no point did I feel obliged to tip, to be honest it was a pleasure to do so. The elevators are operated by key-card so security is good.I am one of those people who has to have a window open at night, New York is noisy so if this is you be prepared. If the window was closed the noise was negligent. The hotel is on Times Square which is bright but the blinds on the windows are good. As you would expect there is a good selection of bars and restaurants in the area but the best we tried was Budda Bar in the Meat-Packing District, (take a taxi), it was unbelievable. We also had a great meal in Grand Central Station, I'm sorry but I can't remember the name of the place - its looking over the main concourse.Overall, if you are looking for place to stay as a tourist then I would recommend the hotel. If you are looking for a hotel with large public areas then you may want to try one of the Grand-Dame NYC hotels but you may pay a high price. I would certainly recommend the W Hotel and hope to go back some day.

May 14 2008 	Great classy place	My wife and I stayed here on our honeymoon for 5 nights and absolutely loved the W. It's a great classy place to stay. We had a corner room with views of the Hudson and uptown. Slightly small rooms, not unlike any other New York hotel. Room was always clean. Room service breakfast had amazing Belgian waffles and we got a free bottle of champagne complements of the staff for our honeymoon.

May 12 2008	Times Square in my room	"The hallways are so dark, I feel like I'm going to be mugged." That's a direct quote from my manager and it surely applies at all W's where I've stayed. Aside from that, the rooms are typical W - although they have this sliding bathroom panel, which seemed flimsy. What happened to having a bathroom door?If you stay at this particular hotel, BE SURE to request a room that does not border on the times square movie screens, unless that is the sort of experience you are looking for. Kids might think this is really cool. As I was there for business, all i kept thinking was that time's square was coming into my room and the blinds surely were not keeping it out.I had my jeans sent for valet laundry and the order was incorrectly completed. They promptly took care of it at no charge by 7am the next day. The hotel staff here are great - every single employee I encountered was kind and courteous. and the gym is nice and usable.A good place to stay in Times Square - and I would recommend this hotel over the Westin.

May 11 2008 	Aging Fast	The W Times Square has a great location if you're in the city for theater. Other than that, there are problems... This was my second stay at this property, but the first since 2004. The entry to the hotel is on 47th street, and is only an elevator lobby that takes you up to 7 which is the main lobby (or Living Room) as W likes to say. During the daytime, the lobby is a nice enough space with check in located off in an alcove. At night, the lobby turns into a nightclub. A source of revenue for the hotel - but very limiting to the paying guests who have no public area within the hotel to gather or relax outside of the room.There is also the Whiskey Bar separate from the Lobby on street level (part of Blue Fin Restaurant, I think), but the W feels they also need to turn the lobby into a nightclub as well. It seeems to work for them as it was packed and loud every night. For the hotel guests, it was annoying.The rooms are small and with exception of those ending in 10 or 11, have very limited views (facing either Marriott Marquis or an office building). Rooms ending in 10 & 11 face Broadway north toward Central Park, and if you are on a higher floor, you may even have a Park view. Actually, the rooms ending in 11 seem to have a larger floorplan with a sitting area. There are only 10 rooms per floors with 57 being the highest floor.What I noticed on this visit was how the rooms have aged - not very well. I didn't find them to be dirty, as I had read in previous reviews. Everything was nice & clean. But they did seem very dated. The W is marketed as a trendy, boutique hotel. And they also try to sell a luxury image. I found this hotel failing both categories. The furnishings in the room were pretty beaten up, and just seemed cheap. The 'chair' they use is a white leather-like cube with no arms. Basically, it's an ottoman sitting in the corner with absolutely no function as a chair for lounging. You can physically sit on it, but not for long as it is just not comfortable. Which leaves the bed as the only place in the room to sit. If this were a less expensive property, that would be one thing. But the prices are quite high and this hotel participates in several luxury hotel collections (Amex Fine Hotels being one), which indicates a certain level of luxury and services. With that in mind, I have rated this property with only 3 stars.I'll list a few positives and negatives that stood out:The Good (in addition to location):+ Bell Staff were very attentive and seemed genuinely interested in guest service+ Nice flat panel TV's with nice range of channels (though only a very few were HD)+ A good deli next door, which proved necessary as the Blue Fin restaurant only opened for limited hours. It had good selection of food and reasonable pricing+ Comfortable BedThe Bad:- Rooms were small & furnishings were greatly lacking- Very small bathrooms- Lots of noise coming from hallways into the room (seemed like much of it was hotel staff servicing rooms during the day)- No climate control in the rooms (Forget the thermostat on the wall)- Limited usable public space and restaurant choiceSUMMARY - Great location for theater and a nice, comfortable bed for sleeping. Not especially trendy, aging fast.

May 11 2008 	A 'W'onderful Stay :)	I took my Mother to New York for a weekend for her 50th Birthday and I really wanted to splash out and stay somewhere very nice and with a good location, and The W was just that!The staff couldn't have been any nicer and wished my Mother a happy birthday apon checking in. Later that night they even sent up a piece of birthday cake and a card. That was the icing on the cake for her. (no pun intended :P)We were on the 46th floor ( In the 'Spectacular room) with a view down onto Times Square, the noise wasn't bad at all since we were so high up, and the room had blackout drapes so all the blinking lights and lit up signs didn't bother us during the night.The beds were oh-so-comfy, and we loved the music that was always playing in our room.We ordered room service for breakfast on both of the days and it was delicious! So well prepared and presented. A real treat :)The check in lounge on the 7th floor was fab, always someone around to help us with our luggage, or questions about the city or simply getting us a cab. (Which can sometimes be a hassle downtown)Anyway! The W was a wonderful choice and we can't wait to have another girls weekend and go back sometime soon :)

May 10 2008 	Good hotel despite where it is	I confess: I hate Times Square. It's over-rated and it's impossible to move without falling over particularly dim tourists. I only stayed there because it was convenient for the meetings I was having, and I generally like the Starwood chain for decent hotels and relatively reasonable prices.But The W is actually pretty good. I'm (just) 50 but I liked its modernity and it's well-designed. The rooms aren't particularly big but they're nicely laid-out; and the staff are generally friendly and welcoming.The $8 bottle of water at bedside is one of the less good ideas and they deserve to lose a rating point for that alone, and people who don't like big cities may have found the neon creeping through the blinds at night a bit of a distraction.But generally I liked the corner room I was given --- view of the tacky Square on one side, and the Hudson out to the west --- and I found the food at Breakfast good though certainly not cheap.Overall it was above expectations, and I'd go back on a business trip - though for a vacation I might head either north or south for a touch more civilisation on the doorstep.

May 8 2008 	Nice enough.	First off, I'm not a huge fan of the whole W concept so I may tend to have a negative bias. The negatives first:This hotel tries SO HARD to be hip that it's almost laughable. However, I don't think people who are really hip would ever actually stay in a Times Square hotel. Much less a hotel that is only moderate to high priced by NYC standards. Browsing the gift shop is kind of a giveaway too. Pretty low-end merchandise.The room we had was quite small and the bath room was tiny. The bathroom had a sliding door with a frosted glass panel. It served a dual purpose of seeming hip, while helping to mitigate the tightness of the bathroom. Supposedly our room was an upgrade (and it was a corner room) so the regular rooms must be even smaller. The room was nicely furnished except for some random, cheap-looking throw pillows.Almost all the surfaces in the public areas are black or charcoal gray. This color scheme, combined with the cheesy mood lighting makes it difficult to see. It's annoying, but the W in Murray Hill is even worse as far as that goes (and not as nice in other ways, too). I agree with the other reviewer who said that the bathroom wasn't as maintained as it should have been. If I'm going to have a room that small I want it to be a jewel box. The lobby is an elevator ride up from the front entrance. Then you go to a separate elevator bank to get up to your room. The floors are mislabeled, so that it seems as though you are on a higher floor than you really are. This is only a minor inconvenience.The positives:We had a pretty nice view. The Bliss products that they stock the room with are nice.There is a restaurant right off the front entrance area that is supposed to be pretty fun.There was a pretty long line at check-in and it was handled really, really well. It went quite quickly and the desk staff was friendly and efficient. The bellhops were terrific. Friendly and fast. The concierge was nice, but not all that helpful. He didn't have knowledge of our requests so it was frustrating to watch him surf the internet slower than I could have. However, our requests were probably not standard and we were in a rush, so I can't really fault him. He did the best he could. Housekeeping was also very friendly. Quiet in the halls and they would immediately push the elevator button for you if they saw you coming. A little thing, but evidence of training.Overall, it was a small, dark hotel with trendy decor that only partially distracts from it's shortcomings (lipstick on a pig). But it has a surprisingly nice and professional staff. I would not be disappointed to go back for a short trip.

Apr 29 2008 	Hip Hotel in the thick of Times Square	We booked a king room on the 53rd floor. The rate with tax was $452 per night.We arrived at 1pm. The lobby was chaotic. It was difficult to tell where the line began. After waiting 20 minutes we left and returned to try again around 4:30. Things were moving much more quickly and smoothly then. Check in took less than 10 minutes on our second attempt.If you arrive before 3:30pm I recommend leaving your bags, going about your business and returning in the late afternoon.There is wireless and wired internet in the rooms. It is $16.95 per day.The rooms are small, as expected, and attractively modern and minimalistic. The bathroom has little space for toiletries so a hanging bathroom bag would come in handy. The toilet offers little privacy as the walls and door are translucent glass.There was a hair dryer, iron and ironing board in the room. The mini bar was well stocked with Heineken, wine, booze and more. From the W 1567 Broadway (47th and Broadway) you can walk to the theaters, great restaurants, 7th Ave shopping, MOMA and more. It is as good of a location as you can find. The hotel has a lobby bar with very attractive bar tenders that gets quite lively and a separate club bar called Whiskey that was packed.If you are looking for some real New York nightlife within walking distance try Touch. Clubs come and go but this place was it in April of 08. It is a short walk from the hotel at 240 W. 52nd. Ask the concierge for a complementary admission (don't forget to tip). That card will not only get you in free, it might be the only way to get in on a busy night. The crowd is young and energetic. The DJ gets everyone dancing early. This club was already very busy when we arrived at 11:30pm.This W Hotel isn't nearly as accommodating as the Four Seasons but the location is better. The Marquis has a slightly better location than the W but is a half star below in my opinion.

Apr 24 2008 	Too hip for its own good	This is a hip, contemporary hotel in a great location. It is not terribly user friendly. The elevators are dark, and almost all guests (comedically) search for the button to their floor. The lobby/lounge is so noisy and dark (again) that you can't really hear or see. There's public internet access during the day that disappears once the bar starts going. It's a great place to hang out and people watch, though. The food is generally very good, and the bar is overpriced and the service indifferent, but you still don't mind because the crowd is so interesting. The front desk staff is very good and friendly. The wait staff feels like they're doing you a favor by waiting on you. The room I had was spacious and comfortable. My colleague was not so lucky with a cramped and musky room. Expensive, hip, attitudinal. It's a fine place to stay in Times Square, but I'd suggest other parts of the city if you want a better hotel.

Apr 23 2008 	More Style than Comfort	The W hotel has a great location in Times Square and is hip and stylish, but when my daughter and I stayed there for a shopping and Broadway weekend, we weren't that wowed. First of all, the bathroom was not all that clean, especially on the floor, around the tub, and in all the corners. When you're going to have a white bathroom, it better be clean. We also didn't like the design of the bathroom, which was walled off by white, plastic translucent walls that are far from light- or sound-proof, which creates a lack of privacy as well as a problem if someone is trying to use the bathroom while others are sleeping. I think they were going for some kind of modern look, but I'd far prefer standard, sound-proofed walls! In the sleeping area, many things seemed grimy, dusty, or sticky, including the phones, tables, remote controls and radio. I don't think any of these items had been wiped down for quite some time.  The room was quite small, but I would expect that in Times Square.  I booked on hotels.com, and paid extra to be put on a higher floor, but didn't get that. The front desk said I needed proof that I had paid extra and hotel.com's receipt is suspicously vague on details, so I had no recourse on this matter. Traffic noise is definitely a problem unless you are on one of the top floors. As to the amenities outside of the room. There is only one lounge area, and it is basically a bar. Not family friendly, and not comfortable if you want to hang out or wait for someone. Also, there was not always a doorman, and on the day we checked out there was no one to help open the door (our hands were full) or to help us flag a cab. All in all, it didn't seem like a very friendly or helpful place, especially to families.

Apr 23 2008 	Very so-so	To be fair - all of the hotels in Times Square (and NYC generally) are massively overpriced and not very nice. The W is no exception. Location is excellent - right in the heart of Times Square...however, the rooms are small, in desperate need of fine touches, the bathroom is old and not very clean and the water pressure is horrible. Internect connectivity is so slow its almost useless.On the upside - the staff is competent if a bit lacking in polish and the bar area of the lobby is a great place to meet people and hang out with your friends.

Apr 21 2008 	Good hotel	Good hotel for Times Square. Check in was quick, employees were friendly, room was clean, bed was comfortable and the view west was great.Little advice about the bed. What appears to be a padded head board is actually two removable pillows. We didn't realize this until like 2 in the morning when our feet would hang off the bed. So if you think the beds are short they aren't, the head board pillows take up 5 inches of the length of the bed.Second thing, the bottle of water beside the bed has a label on the top "This bottle is provided as a service to our guest. If the consumed a charge will be billed to your room. For your convenience our staff will refresh daily." The bottle of water is $8.00 bucks. [Side note, I have worked in the hotel industry before... sometimes these bottles will have been in the room for months before they are replaced. Unless the bottle of water is complimentary I would suggest not to drink it.] Other than that it was a good stay.

Apr 9 2008 	Stylish Overpriced Hotel in Great Location	My husband traveled to NYC for work and this was the hotel that was booked for him. I'm glad that we did not pay for this hotel otherwise I would have felt that we overpaid at $400+ per night. Overall, it was a comfortable place to stay in an excellent location in Times Square and close to all the theaters. Mar 24 2008	Dark but funky!	Conde Nast Traveller magazine UK edition April 2008 (page 44) gives a description of a hip New York hotel that is so dark the reviewer cannot find a thing. I'm fairly certain he was describing the W Times Square. The walls are all black, and the lift buttons are extremely difficult to see. If you suffer from poor vision, looking for a family hotel or are just plain old, you should probably give this a miss.Luckily my wife and I have excellent vision and are under 40, and we had a great time. The W is achingly hip and makes no apologies for it. The main lobby has a huge stylish bar filled with the young and beautiful of New York which made it quite noisy on the Friday eve we arrived, but I prefer to think of it as full of life. The staff were incredibly friendly and welcoming. We were booked into the 'Wonderful' Room which is their smallest, but they put us into a corner room with great views, and provided complementary cheeseboard and wine. The room was quite small, but in the middle of New York I had no other expectations, neither was it particularly noisy even with the window open. Seriously, I don't understand people who complain about outdoor noise and lights. You are in Times Square, for crying out loud. You don't like noise, stay out of the city, it's as simple as that.I would point out that clothes hooks in the bathroom were seriously lacking, and the bathrooms could do with a touch-up, but nothing deal-breaking.The location is unbeatable, the metro is right across the street and the half-price theatre ticket booth is just around the corner. The concierges are friendly and informative, pointing us toward the best restaurants and bars in the area. There are 2 convenience stores within a 5-second walk of the front door so you can stock up on treats and drinks, rather than the high-price minibar goods. BTW the tapwater is perfectly drinkable, for all those bottled water snobs out there.Later during the stay we moved up to one of the suites on the 53rd floor, fantastic views from here, nothing rivals the Manhattan skyline at sunrise from a King-size bed!We had breakfast at the Blue Fin restaurant twice and it was excellent both times. Much pricier than the nearby deli, but you get what you pay for.We paid about 175 per night and I would definitely check in here again, in fact I'm very keen on checking out other W hotels in the future.Special thanks go to Walter at the front desk for his good cheer and top-class service, and Dana in the Spa for a great massage. In the end, it's the staff that make the hotel wherever you are, and I have no hesitation in recommending the W. Unless you are allergic to black paint, that is.

Mar 22 2008 	Great Place To Stay !!	I just returned from a three day stay at the W in Times Square and having nothing but nice things to say. The staff had great reccomendations for sightseeing and how to get to our destination. Yes, it's a little dark, yes it's the hip place to be, but I don't know what the big fuss is about. Did you come to NYC to see the sights and sounds or to spend 99.9% of your time stashed away in your room? We had everything we needed in our room; two double beds, frig, bathtub, tv, ironing board, etc...So if you're looking for a place to stay where you can literally step out the door and you're in the middle of Times Sq, this is the place to be. Feb 23 2008 	Fantastic Hotel!	I originally wanted to stay at the Westin Times Square but due to a sudden price increase looked elsewhere. Feb 19 2008 	Contemporary design but outdated building	My wife and I recently spent three evenings at the W Hotel Times Square in New York. We are frequent travelers who prefer upscale hotels with excellent amenities. Having stayed at several W Hotels before (including another W Hotel in New York), we were excited about our upcoming stay. Our rate was approximately $400 per night but included a bonus third night free.The hotel is in an excellent location in the heart of Times Square. The check-in service was quick, though it can be a bit like trying to order a drink in a crowded club (the desk is located just across from the hotels very active bar). You also begin to notice how dark everything is, including the lobbies and the elevators; if you are a person who craves sunlight, your time here will not be pleasant. Once in the room I found it to be an acceptable size (based on NYC standards) and nicely finished. The furniture is contemporary and sleek with a touch of wow factor. The bathroom is well done but lacks privacy. Only a thin plastic wall and matching door separate it from the rest of the room, offering little barrier to light and sounds. Also, the bed used is a far cry from the Heavenly Bed used in other Starwood offerings, offering a surface far below most pillow top mattresses.One item that came to be an issue during my stay was the temperature and ventilation control for the room. Ive read other mentions of problems here on the site and it seems to not be an isolated issue. You may have no problems at all in your room, or you may find yourself in a mini-sauna for the durations of your visit its a gamble. Another issue this hotel does its best to deal with (and gets mixed results for) is the noise level. Double-pane windows keep much of the city noise out, but thin doors mean that you will hear the neighbors as they come and go. Mixed reviews also have to go to the hotel staff. Nice touches abound (such as cupcakes and hot chocolate at the front desk) but a lack of willingness/ helpfulness in addressing problems result in low overall marks for service.After staying in some excellent W Hotel/Starwood properties, as well as some other good NYC hotels, I can only recommend the W Times Square to those who wish for easy access to the hotels on-site nightlife. Despite the convenient location and ultra-hip decor, it cannot make up for the glaring problems at the high price level.

Feb 17 2008 	The W -- Trendy Hotel in Times Square	W Times Square is a very trendy hotel. Upon entering the lobby from the ground floor, you experience a water fall on the ceiling. It's cool! You have to take the elevator to the 7th floor to check in. The elevator plays cool, funky music, not the typical Muzak you here. On Floor 7, you will find the Whatever, Wherever congierge, the living room/bar and check-in. You have to take separate elevators to your room--it's an added safety feature so that bar-goers do not go up to the floors with the rooms. You will have to put your room card in the slot for the elevator to work. The hallways of the room floors are dark--that is one of my only complaints. It goes with the trendy vibe but I think the walls are black, lending to a cavelike feel. If you have poor vision, beware! The rooms are great. The mattresses can't be beat. The linens are soft and the satin comforter is wonderful! Loved the flat screen tv. My only other complaint was the shower. There is only half of a glass door. Kind of strange. The water won't flood over even though you think it will. I would have enjoyed the shower more if there was a full curtain or shower door. There are sliding doors to the bathroom without a lock. There's no fan in the bathroom. I did miss turn down service. For the amount of money, it should be something that is included, not something you have to ask for. I also enjoyed the Bliss products. The Blue Fin offers a tasty breakfast menu. It is a bit pricey but it is located right on the ground floor of the hotel. It's convenient. There are tons of Starbucks around if that is more up your alley. Overall, our stay was great, comfortable and we would return.

Jan 9 2008 	Great Location	I think your experience at this hotel is really the luck of the draw. It's in a fabulous location, obviously, but very different. The lobby is on the 7th floor, elevators open out into what we dubbed as "the dicso". Very funky, dim lighting, vibrant reception staff. Trendites everywhere.
