We complained several times but it was never fixed, or perhaps could not be. Therefore, we had bad nights' sleep as it was so warm, but to open the window (which we did often) was extremely noisy with the traffic and continual sirens from the street below. Many people bring pizzas or coffee from the neighbourhood into the hotel, so don't be surprised to see all the fast-food junk in the corridor (and don't let me even mention the smell).W makes a big deal about its design - don't let it fool you. Dec 10 2007 	Great hotel and experience	My wife and I stayed at this hotel for 1-night visit in the middle of December to experience NYC and see all the sites during the holiday season. Dec 10 2007 	What a let down	As I sat in the lobby waiting for the front desk to sort out my payment, I took in the sights of the extremely fake porters complimenting all the women who came in and fishing for tips (they preyed mostly on the older crowd who looked like they had money). Nov 30 2007 	Terrible Experience	I made reservations in December 2006 for my granddaughters & I to stay at the W for the Thanksgiving Day parade in 2007. Nov 21 2007 	Cool modern decor in awesome location	We got a great deal on the room, which is regularly around $500 and we paid $279. The location, of course, is great. Nov 20 2007 	Worst hotel for the price	This was absolutely the worst hotel for the price I have ever stayed in. Nov 18 2007 	Trendy and expensive with fabulous view	This hotel certainly attracts a different crowd than other touristy hotel. The accent here is on the hip and cool. You can feel it the moment your cab stop at the front entrance. The service is a polite and friendly manner. The lobby is located on the 7th floor in a multicolor bar on the right and the 4 check-in desks on the left.My SPG status scored me a corner room on the 48th floor which a separate rows of speedy elevators brings me there in an ear-popping instance. The elevator and hallway is club-level lighting using spot lights, good for eyesights training. Unfortunately, in the her speedy time to get off the clock, the check-in lady has given me the wrong key to the wrong room. Another speedy ride down the lobby took care of it.My WOW Fabulous room or whatever it is called is well as hip as the entrance. The dark spa-like tone is accented with some trendy touch here and there (white reading couch and red fluffy pillow). The room is larger than the usual NY room but just by a tiny bit. The two large windows flanking each corner provides good daylight to fill the room. The business desk gives a partial direct view down to Broadway (and the building in front) on one side and a great view to the Hudson river on the other (my favorite view). The windows can also be opened (limited) to remove stale air if needed. The room is equipped with a clock-CD alarm and a nice 32" LG LCD screen with more HD programming than I have seen elsewhere. On the bad side, the wall is paper-thin and when you have noisy neighbor, the street sound is next to nothing. The W bed is fabulous, it tied with the Westin Heavenly Bed as my favorite. Turn-down service is performed every day around 6-7PM and the "Not Now" sign is observed.The bathroom is either an exercises of industrial coolness or just trying too hard to be different. I feels that it is more on the former, the attention to the details are not there: the sink is cracked, the shower leaks, screws are exposed. This is not the level of a $600/night room should look like even if it is in the middle of NY. The saving grace is the bath amenities, the Bliss products are superb. A warning for bathtub lovers, there is only standing showers.On the service side, after check-in in, I was thirsty and found that the VOSS water bottle seal has been broken but the bottle is full. I think the previous guess decided that the $4/bottle was too expensive after using it. I called down to the guest service twice but no-one answered, so much for the whenever-whatever service. I let the check-in desk know the next day and by the time that I left, the same water bottle is still there. On my third day, the ice-machine next to my door broke down and spill water all over the front of my door. A call downstairs and a noisy fan was put in to dry it up. The only thing is that they did not shut it off and I had to come out around 11PM to pull the cord so that I can go to sleep. The Blue Fin restaurant serves decent food. I once forgot my wallet on the table while going to my room to get my phone and my waiter noticed it and hide it for me, nice service here.Location wise, it is one of the hot properties in Times Square but getting a cab in rush hour can be a killer.In short, if you want a hip weekend stay, this may be the place for you. Otherwise, there are better alternatives.

Oct 30 2007 	Cool lobby	We have just got back from 4 days honeymoon in New York staying at the W Hotel on Times Square. It wasn't cheap because of it's location, we paid $500 per night, but it was so handy for Broadway shows and shopping and you can easily see the big W on the side of the hotel if you can't remember the block number!Bags can be left before and after check-in for as long as needed and if it's raining they'll loan you an umbrella for the day.All together a very good place to stay, if a little pricey, but if you're only staying for a few days then it's worth it.

Oct 27 2007	Decent hotel in the heart of times square	My husband and I stayed at the W Times Square with our 21 month old daughter for 5 nights. We are Starwood members, so we were able to use our 50% off rack rate coupon; the hotel was about $400/night with taxes (usually $800). Though the W is totally NOT kid friendly, we all had a blast, including our toddler. Everyone from the doorman to the checkin staff were excellent, and went out of their way to help us. They gave us a crib and a fan (to block out the city noise at night) which worked out really well. The Starwood cribs never have bumpers though, which is a total pain!! Her pacifier kept falling on the floor! Next time we stay at a Starwood property, I'll consider bringing a bumper with us. I loved the lobby's stylish decor, and totally felt right at home. The atmosphere is chic and modern, yet welcoming and cozy at the same time. Our only complaint is people under 21 are not allowed in the bar area. Since the "bar area" pretty much takes up the whole lobby, this can be a problem for little kids. My daughter walked about 3 feet away from me whiile I was chatting with the concierge, and the security guard immediately got on my case. We stayed on the 14th floor and our room was not too small. The bed is the most comfortable hotel bed ever! Much better than the Westin "Heavenly Bed" if you can imagine that.... I love the use of space and various design elements, but sometimes the W sacrifices function for style. For example, the bathroom door does not lock (!) and the bathroom walls and door are made out of varigated translucent glass, so if you turn out the bathroom light at night, the entire hotel room is lit up. Stupid design, but it sure does look nifty. Also, the bedside tables are beautiful, but have zero storage space. Not even a single drawer to stash your books. I've stayed in a lot of hotels, most of which have really ugly hallways. The W probably takes the cake for "worst hotel hallways known to mankind" though. I think they are supposed to look hip and modern, but in reality they are just ugly black tunnels with absolutely no sense of grace or "flow". Really quite shockingly bad considering how well designed the rest of the hotel is. We walked from the hotel to Soho ( a long walk, but very fun) and from the hotel to the Met and the upper West side. Times square is a great central location to explore the city!

Oct 17 2007	Bring a Flashlight	The Fantastic Suite was a bit shy of fantastic. My wife and two daughters stayed for three nights. Oct 12 2007 	Very chic	Stayed here with my girlfriend during one of our first stays in New York (decided to look into the Westin after). The hotel is extremely chic and very trendy! Sep 11 2007	Wicked W	A five night visit to New York with our twin daughters to congratulate them on A level success before they go off to University. Sep 11 2007 	Amazing hotel stunning views!!!	We have stayed in several hotels in NY and this is by far the best! we were on 46th floor and had a corner room so had 2 views which were amazing and looked fab day and night, this was over times square, you cant get much better than that!!! Sep 8 2007 	Great	We are just an average couple, both work very hard, vacations are few and far between and we had a great time at this hotel. Sep 6 2007	very modern	Very nice hotel. Great modern hotel. Everything is a little dark because of the style but this is a happening hotel. The bar in the Lobby was awesome. Good location and excellent service.

Aug 27 2007	Great customer service	Stayed 3 nights and were very pleased with the staff responsiveness to all requests. They have an excellent can-do attitude which was refreshing. The rooms are small with minimalistic decor. The bathrooms are very tiny- with a stall shower and no countertop space for personal toiletries. We found space for our stuff on the rack below the sink. The bed was very comfortable, decent closet space with safe, and the Bliss amenities were excellent.The location is terrific located on 47th just off Broadway so everything was accessible by foot. The only problems we noted were the connecting room doors are very thin and we heard every conversation held next door- and the dark hallways and elevators, while attractive made it difficult to navigate.We'd stay there again, but would suggest if you are older and/or have any vision problems e.g., reading menus in candlelight, you'll have problems in the elevators and hallways so consider another hotel.

Aug 27 2007 	Tries Too Hard to be Hip	My 20-something wife and I stayed here for a weekend getaway to celebrate her birthday, and were very impressed with the location and friendly service. Unfortunately, even with these factors working for it, W New York - Times Square tries too hard to be trendy and ends up pulling off a forced style that's neither cutting-edge nor inviting. The hotel's futuristic "living room" felt more like a nightclub than a lobby, and the pulsating techno music and light show blasting on the suspended pillars only added to this effect. Another thing that hit us as soon as we walked in was the floral air-freshener scent permeating the entire building. This might have been pleasant were it not so overwhelming. After discovering that our room wasn't ready at check-in, we left our bags with a polite concierge and walked around Times Square. The desk associate said she would call me when my room was ready, but after 3 hours and no call we headed back, ready to take whatever room they had. A high-speed elevator sped us to the 44th floor and discharged us into a dark, spaceship-like hallway with black walls and extremely low lighting. It was like walking into a laser tag building. I was hoping our room would be more inviting than the hallways, but the steel-gray color scheme and cold metallic accoutrements made the already tiny space feel closed and uninviting. One of our pillows was stained and dirty, and the chipped paint and worn fixtures throughout hinted to frequent use, infrequent maintenance or both. All services inside and outside the room will cost you a pretty penny on top of the mint you've already paid for the room itself. Even the bottled water, which is free in most of the lower-tier Sheraton hotels, was $6 a bottle. Yikes! For a hotel rated so high by Starwood I expected much more. On the bright side our "spectacular room" view lived up to its billing, and the shower was great. The location is superb, but for the price there is better to be had in midtown Manhattan. I probably "W"on't be staying here again.

Aug 26 2007 	Great Visit	My husband, son (7 yrs) and I stayed at the W in Times Square for 2 nights in early August. The service was excellent - very friendly and attentive (without being in your face). We stayed on the 50th floor and had a great view straight down Broadway. The room was very quiet and comfortable - the beds were SO COZY! We enjoyed dinner at the hotel restaurant one evening. The food was excellent - the sushi was particularly good. We will definitely consider staying there again on our next visit to NYC.

Aug 11 2007	Always love this Hotel	I travel alone frequently and I love this hotel. I love the corner rooms for the great views, the VERY comfortable bed, the great shower and just the location for a little times square mayhem. I've stayed here several times and have never been disapointed. I'm not sure if the average family would appreciate it, but I love the place.

Aug 9 2007 	Perfect for an experience of Manhattan!	Me and my family have just returned from a 9 night stay in the 'W' Hotel in the middle of Times Square. I have to say, that despite some of the reviews on here, I found it an absolutely fabulous stay and none of us wanted to come home! The maid service, concierge assistance, decor, quality of the rooms and the staff in general were all absolutely fantastic. The only down sides I can think of where when we received a phone call on around the 7th day to ask if anybody had been smoking in the room as the smoke detectors had been activated. We mentioned that none of us had smoked or ever smoked in our lives, they still proceeded to charge 200 to the account. We realised this under the 'account review' facility on the television in the room and we quickly alerted this to their attention and they quickly removed it. However, they had put it under the subject of 'restaurant charge' which I thought was rather sneaky, so make sure you check your account quite reguarly and make sure your stay is totalled up correctly. Also on the last day the toilets blocked in both of our rooms but the maid service was quick and it was fixed within the hour, so that wasn't a problem. On regard to the room, the showers also slightly overflowed in both rooms, but only slightly and bath mats are provided. It was my mother's and my birthday whilst we was there, and we received a teddy bear, a bottle of champage, balloons and two slices of cake which was very generous of them. I think this may have something to do with the fact that my father had had a lot of contact with one of the staff prior to arrival asking questions about New York in general as it was our first visit. Her name was Lydia Chaperone and she was incredibly helpful and made our trip perfect for us. She is definitely a credit to the hotel, so I would always ask for her assistance. Kelly on the concierge desk also got us into some great restaurants and shows during our stay and gave us some great advice which would benefit us financially instead of simply thinking about the hotel's income from ticket brokers etc. The location of the hotel is fantastic - right in the centre of Times Square and a couple of blocks away from Broadway. I can't really comment on the value of the hotel, as my father and mother paid for a suite and then from the points earnt at starwood hotels, they paid for our room with those. I personally think you get value for money as the rooms are quite big for a city and the staff were absolutely brilliant. However, my father suggested that next time if we were to come again, we may rent an apartment as it would most likely work out cheaper, but for first time New Yorkers, it's a great way to get a feel for the city and they guide you along the way with the best things to see and do. Manhattan is an absolutely fantastic place to be. It is the ultimate city in my opinion and I have visited many. Central Park provides a calm from the hectic city life and places such as Soho and Greenwich Village are not too busy as the main areas too and are great for a coffee and a walk to get a feel for New York. The people were very friendly too.All in all a great break and such a refreshing taste of life. If not a little crazy! But that's the way New York is, and that's what makes it so special.

Aug 9 2007 	The W Hotel in Times Square	We just returned from a trip to The W in Times Square and had a great time during our first trip to New York because of the excellent service there! The first and best thing I have to say about the hotel is that the staff is so friendly and very accomodating. I had Michael at the concierge desk helping me, and together we planned the entire trip and he took care of arrangements for everything - even VIP seating at Yankees Stadium! Even an odd request for a restaurant that has white truffle macaroni & cheese didn't phase them, they had a list for me the next day. The maids and front desk clerks are all very polite and professional as well. Two different nights they sent us bottles of champagne with chocolate-covered strawberries, on the house, and they also had a great doggy nanny service (yes, they take pets!)The rooms are small (we got an upgraded room but it was still tiny), but we knew NYC hotel rooms are tiny going in and the way they have the rooms decorated, they feel a lot bigger than they are. We had huge windows overlooking Times Square, and the room has block light walls and mirrors all over to give it an open feeling. The room (and the hotel) are decorated beautifully ... very modern and trendy, yet somehow classic as well. They were working on their lobby/living room but even through construction it is a stunning space. And the rumors are true - the best beds EVER, you are surrounded by down and the sheets were divine. Very soft, after a long day in the sun walking it was nice to slip into those cool sheets!Now to the (minor) negative things that prevented me from giving a 5-star rating - our air conditioning went down to 65 the first night, but after that it would stop running if we turned it below 69. We like quite a chilly room (especially with the heavy comforters on the bed) and the AC didn't really seem to keep up all the time. Another complaint is we saw a silverfish in the bathroom, it ran under a barely see-able crack in the floor before we could kill it but that was the only one we saw. Surprised us because the room and hotel look immaculate otherwise.Our only other complaint would be the noise - we were given a room right across from the maid's closet and in the mornings all we could hear were them constantly opening and closing the doors, getting stuff out, talking, vaccuuming, etc. There wasn't a lot keeping hallway noise out of the room. Also, you can hear the traffic from the street below. It never kept either of us from sleeping, but very light sleepers may want to be aware you will faintly hear honking and sirens all night long.Overall, not bad - we'd definitely stay here again but would request a room far away from elevators and maid's closets!

Aug 6 2007 	Very Cheesy	Aside from the "trying way too hard to be trendy" atmosphere, the things that really make you roll your eyes are upstairs past the "living room" (aka lobby lounge). You must proceed to a higher floor to check in. I must admit my wife and I were a little intimidated by them, but secretly we could not stop staring at the beautiful people surrounding us. May 15 2007 	Close to Broadway theatres functional but not cheap.	I would generally approve of the hotel, but some technical caveats definitely apply. My wife and I stayed 4 nights (Thursday to Monday in mid-May, 2007). First of all, I booked through the Starwood hotel chain website, which seemed to make sense after poking around for endless hours looking at various hotel and booking options. The comparatively reasonable cancellation policy on their website appealed to me, and (prepare to contain yourself) you can redirect your Starwood points, or whatever they are, to certain other loyalty programs like Aeroplan. So Im sure I saved two percent on the whole deal, and all those hours of travel surfing were not in vain. Note that to do this, you have to sign up in advance for a preferred guest card that they mail out to you, but its free to sign up. Anyway, for what was ostensibly a better than average room (i.e., corner room on 38th floor looking west across the Hudson river) we forked out $429 a night (plus taxes made it around $490 a night). Having never been to NY before we had no idea if this represented a value proposition when compared to other similarly pricey hotels. The hotel is newish, though the odd sign of wear is now visible. The staff did their jobs well on the few occasions we had to actually interact with them (ee.gg., at check in, to get a cab, breakfast servers in restaurant downstairs, send up a guy with replacement room key when ours did not work, leave bags behind for the day on our day of departure, buying stuff in the trendy hotel shop). The room was clean, large enough not to bump into things, the tap water was quite drinkable, the shower had good water pressure, there were lots of towels (some of which can be sacrificed to keep the shower from soaking the whole bathroom floor), the king bed was comfortable, the flat screen TV hanging on the wall had numerous channels and a DVD player (who stays in to watch videos whilst in NY, anyway?), there was a little el cheapo CD player, two nice comfy robes, and also an astonishing array of W brand crap that you can buy, laid out right there in the room like so many bags of chips. And, of course, an over-priced mini bar. We really did enjoy coming back to the room after pounding the NY pavement all day and falling onto the big plush bed, though I appreciate this sounds cheesy. Note that you will need top quality ear plugs at this hotel. The north end of Times Square is right below you, very brightly lit, full of much honking and many all-night sirens, and as a bonus the clowns down the hall on Saturday night will try to drain the ice machine (at least I think thats what they were doing), shout at each other, and then lock themselves out of their room, in which room there may be a roommate, but there is only one way to find out if they are in there. Mind you, once you block out all the noise you can really appreciate the nice bed. We had the feather pillows, and they were a touch squishy, good for stomach sleepers, but I think next time Ill ask for foam. Basically it is a good hotel, but I dont quite get who the target market is. I am assuming the hotel is probably too expensive for most youthful lounge-and-club hipsters at whom the incessant sound track in the common areas seems to be aimed. The lighting in the elevators is so dim I actually had to bend over to read the numbers on the buttons (theres brail on them, though, so I had that to fall back on). The hotels location is ideal for catching Broadway shows nearby, and quite central for most of the top 10 touristy things. Most people there looked as I imagine we did  vaguely annoyed with day 3 of the whole tangerine wheatgrass cool-as-zen W scene, but also happy to be in NY and able to afford a good bed and good ear plugs. Other things in NY that warrant special mention: the Staten Island ferry (seems to depart on the hour and half hour, great views, its free, but they make you get off and then on again at the Staten Island end before coming back to Manhattan); the view from the top of the Rockefeller centre (a swift $17.50 each plus tax; maybe go at odd hours so as not to line up; good shopping nearby); and in the far-from-free category, attending the Metropolitan Opera (buy your tickets way in advance from the Met website for box office pick-up, and then phone to make a 6 p.m. reservation at the very nice Gran Tier restaurant thats also in the opera house (note that the restaurant crowd is dressier than average NY opera attendee) and then before finishing your very nice dinner, be sure to arrange for your waiter to pre-order your intermission chocolate souffl (we found the house champagne was quite doable with it) and then go back to your table at intermission and enjoy it while the mob lines up at the bar. And note that the ladies room at the Met will have a long line just before show time so get the female in your party in line maybe 20 minutes before curtain.)

Apr 10 2007 	Where is the Wow?	We did 5 nights here in Feb for a long weekend and were disappointed with some aspects of the W.The location is great to get out & about from, there are a few subway stops nearby & cabs right outside plus Times Square is just around the corner.I would say that most of the money has been spent on the communal areas & the room we had left a lot to be desired. We had a quick dance in the lifts inbetween each floor, on our own of course! It was all very Sex in the City stylee with a price tag to match. Your looking at around $12 a drink, which soon stacks up if you are thirsty & want more than a glass of ice.We have stayed in NYC before & are aware that space is at a premium so I wasn't expecting a big room. I was however hopeful of heating in the winter & also a quiet room at night. There was a massive aircon unit in the corridor outside out room that clanked & clunked all night long. The room itself was a little bit tired, considering this is referred to as 5 star, it isn't. There was a stain on the quilt, the bathroom had bits of mould on some of the grout & was freezing to step out of the shower into. The bliss toiletries were nice & were replenished every day. The gym has an assortment of free weights & a couple of cardio machines, there are no showers/sauna or steam.I had a deep tissue massage while we stayed here & felt the benefit the next day, in fact I'm still feeling it now after 7 weeks. I would recommend a trip to Michael if your back/shoulders are knotted, he put me through pain but it was worth it! They have heated massage beds, which was a first for me but v.nice.The restaurant has a good menu & is worth a visit if you can't be bothered to venture too far. As someone else has mentioned, there is a deli about 2 doors up the road (going away from Times Square) and I would highly recommend it for coffee & breakfast, cold drinks to put in the mini bar (the mini bar is a rip-off $12 for bottled water) and the selection of hot food etc is fantastic. If I had a deli like that in London I would stop shopping/cooking. If you carry on walking in the same direction across a couple of blocks you will end up at Hells Kitchen, there are loads of places to eat round here we tried the Chelsea Grill which had a nice vibe.I could go on & on about the great places to eat in this big city, but thats for you to find out or have fun trying!Overall the W was ok, if I'd known how over-rated it is I would have booked something else.

If you score a room on a high floor (goes up to 54th flr), there's a good chance you'll be able to see NJ, the hudson river, and the entire city.Internet service was $17 per 24 hr. or $6 for 30 min. Overrall this is your above average NYC W Hotel. In comparison to other hotels in the city within the price range, it is good.

Apr 4 2007	A Perfect New York W Weekend	I stayed at the W over a weekend and actually loved it. I had been to the hotel lobby bar for drinks and have admired how stylish it is. Staying at the hotel was even better. I booked a superior room which is a step above the basic "wonderful" room. The room was quite roomy with a partial view of Times Sq. There was an HD flat TV. As usual the bed and bathroom were high-grade Starwood quality. As with other Ws, the Bliss bathroom products are some of the best I have seen. As guests of the hotel, we didn't have to pay the $20 cover charge at the Whiskey club downstairs which was a nice extra (even though the club was on the cheesy side playing mainstream hip hop for a suburban looking crowd).So why 4 rather than 5 stars? Mostly it is an issue of price. The $450 price tag for a nice room - while OK for NYC these days - does not feel like great value. You could stay at a Four Seasons in Istanbul for this kind of money. But then again, as New Yorkers like to say, nothing compares to NYC. And no boutique chain compares to the consistent quality of the W.

Mar 29 2007 	Loved the atmosphere	The Hotel's location was grt, the room was small but beautiful,made you feel like you were in a spa. Loved the lobby, the water feature was beautiful. Mar 11 2007	Too much effort on OUR part...	First, for a NY hotel, the price was right. The room was clean. Mar 4 2007 	Nice stay.	This was my second visit to W Times Square. I was disappointed with my first (about a year ago). But I am all for second chances. Mar 3 2007 	Seems to be for businessmen/designed by men?	My husband and I stayed at this hotel for one night. We liked certain things about it such as the cool waterfall effect as you walk in, the bed was comfortable, the large HDTV was great, the elevators were good, and the staff and service was attentive. We ordered breakfast to be delivered to the room at 8 AM, and our order arrived a few minutes early and was perfect. The food was quite good. The thing that bothered me the most was that the sink had almost no room to spread out my makeup items for application, there was a makeup mirror but it was mounted way too high for a woman who is, like me, average height (5'4"), and the lighting in the bathroom was way too dim to see what I was doing! They provide nice, plush bathrobes, found in the closet, but there was no hook to hang it up in the bathroom. (The bathroom had a pocket door instead of a regular door.) The room itself had several lights, but all of the lights were dim. We find that to be very annoying. The room was very small, hardly larger than the king-sized bed, with decor that was kind of austere and high-tech, not at all comfortable or homey. There were 2 chairs in the room, but neither one was comfortable. Our room was obviously designed for very short stays! We never would have wanted to stay in that room for more than the one night. The decor gave us an uneasy, edgy feel instead of the relaxing effect we had been needing & hoping for. We heard a LOT of noise from the hallways late at night. A drawerful of snacks is in the room; I had to stop my husband from taking any because he did not realize that we would be charged for them....he thought they were included in the price of the room! No way! A plus is that right next door there is a nice deli with all kinds of food, snacks, sandwiches and drinks available. I had a roast beef sandwich from that deli and it was great! The bottom line is that we would not stay here again due to the negatives that I mentioned..

Feb 21 2007 	Classy Hotel	Just back from Stay in The W, Times Square, it is a classy hotel, with great service and very central. The rooms were very comfortable, lovely beds. Would definitely recommend it to anyone, will stay again next visit to New York. The Staff were very helpful and friendly!

Jan 29 2007 	thrilled with the W! Jan 26 2007 	W Times Square	We have just returned from our second stay at the W Times Square. The first stay was outstanding and the second just as good. Jan 16 2007 	incredible hotel	I was very impressed with this hotel. The service was wonderful- everyone was friendly and helpful. Employees were willing to take the time to give us helpful advice on restaurants, etc.The rooms were impeccable. Everything looked very new and had a modern flair. This is the nicest place I have stayed in New York (I have also stayed at the Renaissance Times Square.) The size of the room was quite adequate- we had space to move around. I was able to request a room with a view- we had a view of Broadway below. I was also able to request a room with a bathtub- most of the rooms here only have showers.There was only one chair in the room- at the desk. This presented a small problem when we ordered room service because one of us had to sit on the bed and the other in the chair and eat at the table provided with the room service. We were in a bit of a hurry but I am sure they would have provided a chair if we had time to request one.The rooms were elegant and a soft cd is playing when you walk in, and plays constantly throughout your stay (there is a cd player.)The hotel also hosts a restaurant- the blue fin- which was also impressive. The atmosphere was like a los angeles scene but also very relaxing. The food was incredible. I ordered the filet mignon, medium well. It came out perfect. I often have problems with medium well steaks in even five star restaurants, but not here. Every portion of the meal was wonderful- down to the dessert. Much thought went into the preparation and creation of each course. The Whiskey Nite Club is also in the hotel. Even on Sunday, this place was a place to be. It has a unique atmosphere and a vip section one can reserve for parties. The music is basically top 40 dance music, with not much variation. It was worth checking out. There are not many seats there, so be prepared to stand. There is a coat check for $2 per coat. As for some other things about the hotel- it is in a great location. The valet parking was worth it, but was expensive- $62 per night. It goes on a 24 hour basis- so if you arrive before check in, you can still check your car and have until the same time the next day to get it back. However, there are no in-out privileges with the car. The room-service breakfast was good quality as well. It was expensive- we paid close to $100 for breakfast, and each only had one basic meal with only one extra juice and one extra order of bacon. That included the tip.We had a slight problem with the bill- we were charged for an umbrella from the mini-bar that we didn't take. A short call to the hotel remedied this immediately.I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone staying in New York. You can't beat the accommodations, the staff, the luxury, the location, and the atmosphere. After coming to this hotel, we will probably always stay here when coming to New York.We will also check out other W hotels worldwide when traveling other places!

Jan 13 2007 	Pretty Bad	Once again I went with an American Express "Fine Hotel" - and once again dissapointed.Firstly, I believe I read their website, and about how they're all about the linens and beds... If it bothers you, I'd request a higher floor. The 37th Floor was not quite high enough to avoid the flashy billboards (er, video screens) from Times Sq.As to Location, fantastic. You're right there, in the middle of it all, and I'd recommend it for young couples/singles, but I wouldn't recommend it for families.Check-in/reception is actually on Level 7 - You take the elevators up to Level 7 (every time), and from there you take your designated elevator to your floor.Food was good, but certainly not worth the expense, and well, you're in NYC - get out there and hit one of the many, MANY fabulous restaurants.I would recommend any of my single friends to stay, but I've actually stayed at The Time, a couple of years ago, and I would recommend that first. It's also in the mix (just off Times Sq), and is quiet, well appointed, and friendly.Speaking with Concierge, and Reception is extremely difficult as afternoon turns to evening. They're right in-front of the bar, in an wide-open hard-walled area. I found it rather unpleasant coming back from a full day in the city, and having all that noise to deal with in the 'lobby' of my hotel.My final thoughts - too expensive for what you get, unless you have money to burn, I'm sure there are better options (including The Time).

Jan 10 2007 	This hotel provides a life changing experience	What can I say? Love NYC and this is the best yet. Mentioned at check in that it was my wife's 30th and in the time it took us to have a brief drink in the bar before our baggage was taken to our room, complimentary champagne and chocolate strawberries had been delivered to our suite. I was delighted at this attention to detail and swift thought and practice - excellent customer service.We recieved nothing than top quality service from every member of staff at this establishment. I recommend this hotel with my word, and on that you have a promise. With my word in mind, there were just some minor points that did cross my mind - and that is all they did. Although we had a room on the corner block facing Times Square, I wondered what value and view would be offered by accomodation at the back of the hotel.The Ice machines were noisy - and I mean noisy. Not a problem for us at all but those poor peeps in the two rooms in between the ice generator must have been cursing....Drinks are expensive - and I mean expensive. I don't mind shelling out for ambience but $44 and tip for 2 glasses of wine and a sprite did make me wonder. However - this is class. From start to finish. Jan 5 2007 	Less than Expected	We just returned from fabulous trip in NYC for New Year's Eve! Everything is very dark and you always feel like you're in a maze because you go from one elevator to another to get where you're going.Check-In: Pretty smooth & friendly. The lobby is great, dark and loud like a cool lounge/club. When we had originally booked, we were assured by the GM we would get an upgraded room high floor room with a view of times square. When we arrived, they had given all those rooms away, so we were left without a view. The entire purpose of staying at the W was to get a great view of the crowds. This was very disappointing. Room: We had an upgrade to the standard rooms (I think they call them 'cool'). Again, modern design but our room needed love. There were many signs of wear and tear and no signs of upkeep. The rooms are fairly small but very different design from other hotels. Had it been very well maintained, it has wow-potential.Service: Great. Everyone is very laid back and helpful, kind of like a great neighbor. Probably the best part of the hotel. Food: We ordered breakfast for Jan 1. Nothing spectacular, pretty basic bacon and eggs but we paid about 5 times what we would've had we walked to the nearest breakfast place.Gym: They claim the W has the best gym. Not the best, but definitely great. Individual tvs on all machines, they provide purified water, towels, earphones, fruit and a lovely view of times square.All in all, would we go again? Several of the staff did mention they were undergoing renovations in the rooms (much needed) in the new year. After that, we'd go again. We expected more for such a reputable brand.

Nov 21 2006	Nice rooms great location	Stayed there 4 nights before departing for Italy. Room very comfortable, bed great. Nov 16 2006 	Loved the W Times Square	We booked The W for a girls weekend hitting concerts, theatre, and shopping . We come up several times a year for both business and pleasure and are quite at home here. We couldn't believe it when they came to get us in less than an hour.The room was definitely NYC small. Almost too small. And the bathroom was a tight fit. Someone had mentioned earlier about the confusion over the elevators. Lot of people and good music. We ended up talking to a group of people at the bar who turned out to be a favorite band of ours. Small world. Drinks are a bit pricey but no surprise in NYC. Nov 14 2006 	What ever When ever - that is this hotels moto and they exceeded it !!! The rooms were small, but that's expected being that it's NY. But what really got to us was the PAPER THIN WALLS...even the walls WITHIN the room (ie. walls / doors to the bathroom). The door to the bathroom is like one of those japanese paper-made sliding doors that doesn't even close all the way so you literally have no privacy whatsoever. We could hear EVERYTHING that was going on next door on both sides of our room. Conversations (at normal talking level..in other words, they weren't talking loud or yelling), TV, the water running...even VERY PERSONAL situations if you know what I mean. It was very difficult to sleep at night!Other frustrating things about this hotel: the hallways are pitch black w/ these funky blue lights or some other dim color lights; You have to take 2 elevators to get to your room; We needed assistance from the bellman 4 times during our stay, and each time (and I'm not exxagerating), we had to wait at least 10 minutes to get someone to help us; and when they did finally come to help us, they acted like we were bothering them! One of us in our group even tried to get one of the bellman's attention and the bellman walked away to a room and slammed the door on our face!! Lastly, the guys outside helping you to get cabs NEVER greeted us unless there was a door they could open or some way they could get a tip from us.... It was disgusting. Positive point: the staff that worked at the check-in counter were all extremely helpful & courteous! Whenever we needed help with our room key, or with Fed Ex mail, or even needing an umbrella (it started pouring outside on 1 day)...they went out of their way to assist us promptly. So kudos to them! They made our stay bearable. But overall, what I initially thought was a cool, friendly & service-oriented hotel, turned out to be so not what I expected! The W / Times Square Hotel just comes in a "pretty package" w/ great marketing...but the service overall is not acceptable and the quality of the hotel is mediocre. Frankly, I think they try WAY too hard to be trendy....that they forget that all their guests want is to be comfortable, feel pampered....& feel right at home. For us, it was actually "work" to stay at this hotel and NOT very comfortable at all! We will never come back to this hotel.

Nov 4 2006	Great location - hotel is okay	I stayed here before and returned because we had a great view from our room. We did not have a great view from our room this time and we were not told of any extras. The rooms are small but they are nice. The location is outstanding but I can do without the W attitude. The staff really do believe they are doing you a favor by doing their job which is kind of disappointing. My second visit to this hotel was a substantial drop off in quality of service and attention to detail from my first visit. In the end it was nothing special which was kind of a letdown after such a positive first visit.

Oct 31 2006	OK hotel but service is terrible	Nice enough rooms, ok hotel but everything there costs a fortune (someone else has commented on the $49 croissants!) and $17 a day for internet access in the room.Service was dreadful, maids ignored do not disturb signs, concierge was never there and getting a taxi out of the doorman was near to impossible.Not sure I would return in a hurry - there are other hotels which are just as nice for the money.

The beds are comfortable and the Bliss spa products nice, but not enough to make up for the price and the fact that everything is "tries too hard" trendy, from the room service menu (bound like a stack of paint color samples) to the overly friendly staff with a "whatever whenever policy" that means "good marketing, but you really can't get what you want when you want it, especially if you want quick room service or an elevator. " Meeting rooms are too dark; food is very good.
